loans.name: Juliette

texts.fr: A. Juliette est née en 1962 à Ouidah, ville historique du Bénin. Il y a 20 ans environs que Juliette vit à Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à AKOUTA Basil un chauffeur, Juliette est mère de quatre enfants. Deux autres enfants sont à sa charge. Tous les enfants ne sont pas scolarisés. Juliette vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Cadjèhoun. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Juliette n'a fait que le cours primaire. Il y a près de 20 ans que Juliette vend du pain accompagnée de la mayonnaise à son domicile. Juliette mène également comme activité secondaire, la vente de bouillie (aliment local fait à base d'amidon de maïs). C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Juliette s'approvisionne. Juliette est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. C'est dans l'optique d'augmenter son fonds de roulement afin d'agrandir son activité que Juliette sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Juliette A. was born in 1962 in Ouidah, historical city of Benin. Juliette has lived for about 20 years in Cadjèhoun, a city area of Cotonou, financial capital of Benin. She is married to Basil AKOUTA, a driver, and mother of four children. She is also taking care of two foster children. All the children are not attending school. Juliette lives with her husband and the six children in Cadjèhoun. The couple is providing together for the family's expenses. Juliette graduated only from primary school. For almost twenty years Juliette has sold bread with mayonnaise from her home. Juliette is also running a second business, selling bouillie, a local food product, prepared with corn meal. Juliette buys her supplies in Dantokpa, Benin's international market. Juliette is ALIDé's old client and she fully repaid her previous loans. Now she is requesting a third loan, in order to increase her operating funds and to enlarge her business.

Translated from French by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy bread and mayonnaise

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en: Iyabo is 56 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a commercial driver. She sells cellophane bags at retail prices to her customers. She hawks her cellophane bags within her community in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. She has been in this business for a long time. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more cellophane bags to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cellophane bags to sell

loans.name: Ela

texts.en:
Ela N. is a 54-year-old woman living in the town of Asaga.  She is married and has 8 adult children.  To make a living, Ela owns & operates a bakery.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from baking & selling a variety of confectioneries such cookies and cakes in the local community.  Ela has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 400 WST a month from these activities.

In 2009, Ela joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Ela is now requesting a loan of 1000 WST which will be used to invest in expanding the business.  This will be the 1st loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD.  Ela plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: We Hope To God Group

texts.en:
Here are Matha T., Rugiatu B. and Aminata J.. These local entrepreneurs of the small town of Waterloo named their group We Hope to God. This will be their second loan from SMT/Kiva. With the help of the previous SMT/Kiva loan, these entrepreneurs’ businesses and individual lives improved. Having repaid their last loan successfully, they are requesting a new loan of SLL 800,000 for each to further strengthen their businesses. 

The leader of this group of three is Matha T. on the left. Matha was born in Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone; she is approximately 55 years of age. Matha is divorced with three children. Two of her children have already completed Senior Secondary School and the last is in Junior Secondary School I. Matha sells firewood and charcoal. She has been in this type of business for two years now – before, she was selling fish. With her share of the loan, she will use part of it to buy a truck full of firewood and part as fare to transport the wood to her house.

loans.use: Use part of the loan to buy a truck full of firewood and part as fare to transport the wood

loans.name: Namataba Development Group Of Mukono

texts.en:
Agnes M. is 38 years old and the leader of her group in Mukono. She is a widow and cares for her six children with ages ranging from 6 years to 17 years. Additionally, she supports three orphans.  

For five years,  Agnes has participated in the businesses of brick laying and fish selling. Being involved in both industries has allowed her to diversify her interests. She would like to use the loan amount of 300,000 USH to purchase more supplies and tools for brick making. One day, Agnes hopes that she will be able to sponsor all of her children’s educations to the university level.

loans.use: More supplies and tools for brickmaking

loans.name: Ganhuyag

texts.en:
Ganhuyag is 26 years old and lives with his wife and son in the Khovd province of western Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. Ganhuyag and his friend operate a car repair business in their town. He began this business in 2005 while working as an employee at another car repair business. His wife is unemployed and is attending accounting courses at the local university in order to increase her chances of getting a job in the near future. Ganhuyag says, “If my wife gets a job, it will be a great help for the family. Until then, it is my responsibility to support my family.” He is requesting a 500,000 tugrug (~350 USD) loan in order to purchase paints and parts for his business and also to pay tuition fees for his wife’s accounting course.


About XacBank
XacBank was founded in 2001, and listed its first loan on Kiva in January 2009. It is the largest microfinance organization in Mongolia, but also has mainstream commercial operations. XacBank has the vision, scale and innovation to develop and implement new solutions to poverty. It is currently utilizing Kiva’s 0% lending interest rate to return 9% of interest paid from borrowers to them in the form of a savings account at the end of their loans. This not only allows borrowers to gain financially, but also encourages them to save.

To get regular updates from XacBank, please join our lending team: http://www.kiva.org/team/xacbank_mongolia

To lend to more Mongolian borrowers, please click here:http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&queryString=Mongolia&status=fundRaising&gender=All&sectors[]=All&regions[]=All&sortBy=Expiring+Soon

loans.use: To purchase paints and spare parts

loans.name: Wael

texts.en:
Wael lives in Al-Nusairat, between Gaza and Dier al Balah. He is married with three children: Zaki, 6; Nadeen, 3; and Rula, 1.

Wael works in a hotel for a monthly salary of 300 USD, and he also owns a taxi that he operates in the middle area of Gaza Strip. He has owned this taxi for two years.

Wael has requested 1,000 USD to do some maintenance on his taxi before winter. He appears in the photo next to his taxi.

loans.use: To pay for taxi maintenance

loans.name: Bulamubwoka Group Of Mukono

texts.en:
Shaminah N. is the leader of her group in Mukono. She is 30 years old and married with four children — the oldest child is 14 years old and the youngest child is 6. She also cares for one orphan as well, her deceased sister’s child, and pays for all five children’s educations. 

Shaminah sells charcoal and has been doing so for seven years.  She attributes her success in the enterprise to her stall’s highly trafficked location and her good customer service. She is hopeful that the loan of 300,000 USH will allow her to increase inventory and thereby increase sales. One day Shaminah hopes to build and own a residence for her entire family.

loans.use: More inventory for her charcoal business

loans.name: Leatuvai

texts.en:
Leatuvai F. is a 57-year-old woman living in the town of Taga. She is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Leatuvai owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting & harvesting fruits & vegetables for sale. Leatuvai has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 500 WST a month from these activities.

In 2007, Leatuvai joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leatuvai has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1250 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. Leatuvai is now requesting a new loan of 1500 WST which will also be used to purchase general farm supplies & equipment. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Leatuvai plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay tuition fees for her children.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase general farm supplies & equipment

loans.name: Seela

texts.en:
Seela S. is a woman living in the town of Sapini Siufaga. She is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Seela owns & operates a fishing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from harvesting & selling ocean-caught fish in the local community. Seela has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 400 WST a month from these activities.

In 2008, Seela joined SPBD to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Seela has successfully repaid a previous loan of 1500 WST from SPBD. This previous loan was used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets. Seela is now requesting a new loan of 2000 WST which will be used to purchase more fishing equipment including hooks & nets. This will be the 3rd loan taken out by the borrower from SPBD. Seela plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SPBD:

SPBD's mission is to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fishing equipment including hooks & nets

loans.name: Taiwo

texts.en: Taiwo is 42 years old and married with two children. His wife is a hairstylist. He makes and sells cellophane bags at retail prices to his customers within his community in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. He has been in this business for a long time. He is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more materials to make more cellophane bags to sell. With this business he hopes to meet the basic needs of his family. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more materials to make more cellophane bags to sell

loans.name: Shahri

texts.en:
Shahri has a small business selling office supplies at the market “Dehkon” in Tursunzade, Tajikistan. Her little kiosk is filled with attractive, reasonably priced items that appeal to many customers. Shahri has been in business for about 14 years. She likes what she sells and has developed a stable enterprise. Currently Shahri has requested a loan of 5,000 Somoni to help purchase a new supply of items to sell. She thanks all lenders for supporting and encouraging her. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low-income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing office supplies to sell.

loans.name: T. Evelyne

texts.fr: A. T. Evelyne  est née en 1949 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Evelyne vit depuis environs 20 ans à Cadjèhoun à Cotonou. C’est une veuve qui a six enfants à charge, dont quatre sont ses propres enfants. Certains enfants sont scolarisés. Evelyne vit seule avec ses enfants et assure seule leurs charges. Evelyne n’a pas été à l’école. Pour faire face à ses besoins quotidiens, Evelyne vend depuis près de 15 ans, des céréales (maïs, etc.) à son domicile, et aussi par le système de distribution. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Evelyne s’approvisionne. Evelyne est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà bénéficié de deux crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. En vue d’accroître davantage son activité et d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire en ces période de préparation des fêtes de fin d’année, Evelyne sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Evelyne T. A. was born in 1949 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has lived in Cadjèhoun in Cotonou for the last 20 years. She is a widow with six children in her care, four of whom are her own children. Some of these children attend school. Evelyne lives on her own with the children and she alone provides for them. She herself did not go to school. In order to cover their daily needs, for the last 15 years Evelyne has sold cereals (e.g., corn) from her home and also through the distribution system. She stocks up in Dantokpa, Benin's international market. Evelyne is a former client of Kiva Field Partner, ALIDé, having already received two loans that she has repaid without any problem. In order to grow her business and increase her sales leading up to the year-end holiday period, Evelyne is asking for a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 50-kilogram sacks of corn

loans.name: Lola

texts.en:
Lola H. is 49 years old. She is married with five children. Lola is selling office supplies and supplies for school. The trading place is located in the central market. She has a wide range of goods and the majority of her customers are schoolchildren. In comparison with other big stores selling office supplies, Lola’s prices are lower and more attractive. She repaid her previous loan ahead of schedule and now she wants to take another loan because of the high demand for her goods. She requests 5,000 Somoni for purchasing the office supplies for selling. Lola has been a client of IMON for several years with the positive credit history and promises to repay this loan in a timely manner and thanks everyone for support.

loans.use: Purchasing office supplies to sell.

loans.name: Yanjinsuren

texts.en:
T. Yanjinsuren is 48 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Gobi-Altai province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. Her youngest son is 21 years old and currently attends the university. Yanjinsuren operates a clothing trading business out of a rented stall at the local market in her town with the help of her oldest daughter. She purchases her products twice in a month from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia and transports them back to her province. 

Yanjinsuren started selling clothes in 2005, and has previously received two loans in order to improve her business. The loans have helped her to grow her business and she has proven to be a very trustworthy borrower. Yanjinsuren continues to work hard and grow her business further, and today her working capital exceeds 2,000,000 tugrugs (~1400 USD). She is optimistic about the future and hopes to one day own her own workplace. Yanjinsuren is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug (~700 USD) loan to purchase winter clothes to sell at her clothing business.

loans.use: to purchase winter clothes to sell

loans.name: Saliu

texts.en: Saliu is 41 years old and is married with 4 children. His wife sells clothes and he sells vegetables and potatoes at the front of his house at retail prices.  He is happy because the demand for his vegetables and potatoes will increase during this festive season. Saliu has been in this business for a long time. He hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more vegetables and potatoes to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables and potatoes

loans.name: Ozoda

texts.en:
Ozoda is an extremely hard-working and energetic woman. Every day she works hard in order to improve her children's lives. For more than 3 years she has sold children's clothing in various colors, styles, and sizes at the local market.  Thanks to her high-quality workmanship and good taste, she is getting more and more orders. Ozoda hopes that her business will keep growing so that she can maintain a comfortable life for her family, especially for her children. To make that possible, she has applied for a new loan that she will use to buy more clothing to sell. With this purpose Ozoda requests $1500 USD. She promises to repay the loan on time with no violation. Ozoda is counting on your help. Be an important of the growth of Ozoda’s business.

loans.use: To increase shop inventory.

loans.name: Séraphine

texts.fr: G. Séraphine est née en 1971 à Bohicon, dans le département de l’Atlantique au Bénin. Séraphine  vit depuis près de 18 ans au quartier Cadjèhoun à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Séraphine est mariée à CHIAKPE Gilbert, un chauffeur. Le couple à sept enfants à charge, dont cinq sont leurs propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés et vivent ensemble avec leurs parents à Cadjèhoun. Séraphine vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Séraphine n’a fait que l’école primaire. Il y a environs 11 ans que Séraphine vend des œufs, des pâtes alimentaires et du riz de façon ambulante. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Séraphine fait ses achats. Séraphine est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui rembourse bien ses crédits. Séraphine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’augmenter le volume de ses articles et de satisfaire plus la demande des consommateurs. Séraphine ambitionne élargir son secteur d’activité dans l’avenir.
texts.en:
G. Séraphine was born in 1971 in Bohicon, in the county of Atlantique in Benin. For the past 18 years,Séraphine has lived in the neighborhood of Cadjèhoun in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Séraphine is married to Chiakpe Gilbert, a driver. The couple has seven children in their care, 5 of whom are their own children. All of the children attend school and live with their parents in Cadjèhoun. Séraphine and her husband take care of the needs of their family. Séraphine only attended primary school. For about 11 years, Séraphine has sold eggs, pasta and rice throughout the town. She supplies herself in Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. Séraphine is an old client of ALIDé and has fully repaid her previous loans. Séraphine is requesting a third loan from ALIDé, in order to increase her stock and satisfy the needs of her clientele. Séraphine's ambition for the future is to expand her business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase eggs and spaghetti

loans.name: Dilbar

texts.en:
T. Dilbar has had her own business for 15 years. She runs a small store in which she sells teenager’s clothing at the market. She and her husband have five children. Lending services from IMON have been a key support for Dilbar as she developed her business. She has proven to be a great client and has maintained a perfect payment record. Dilbar is requesting a loan of 5000 Somoni to boost her available capital and allow her to purchase new inventory. We are grateful for the opportunity to further assist in the success of this dedicated entrepreneur.

loans.use: To increase shop inventory.

loans.name: Alipong

texts.en:
Alipong H. is currently in the business of selling groundnut paste and tomatoes and is requesting a loan to purchase bags of charcoal for sale. Alipong is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is an accountant. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a permanent house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 35 years old, married with 2 children. Her husband sells clothes. She has a grinding machine that she uses to grind tomatoes, peppers, and beans. Her stall is located at the front of her house. The demand for her services is high. She has been in this business for 5 years. She hopes for a loan amount of 30,000 NGN to purchase a grinding machine to enable her to serve her customers better. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase one grinding machine

loans.name: Antwan

texts.en:
Antwan is a Palestinian man living in Nablus city in the northern West Bank. He is 55 years old and married with four adult children. He is an ambulance driver working for the Palestinian Red Cresent.

Antwan has requested 1,000 USD from FATEN to pay some debts that are due and to replace them with only the FATEN loan which has convenient payments that meet his income.

Antwan appears in the photo at the FATEN office in Nablus.

loans.use: To pay some debts

loans.name: Francis Lemein

texts.en: Francis K. is 26 years old. He is a married father of one school-going child. Francis has been practicing farming on his farm for the last seven years. His farm is in a very productive area within Narok. His customers buy his farm produce in wholesale and they normally come from the Capital city, Nairobi. Francis learned about KADET through an awareness done by KADET staff in his area. This will be his second loan which he is planning to use to buy a new species of potato called “sangi” which research has proven can do very well in this area and have better yield. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming to meet the demand for his farm produce. Francis’s future hope and dream is to become a large-scale farmer and have his own farm machinery. He believes he is young and quite energetic thus he can do more if supported financially. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy a new potato species called "sangi"

loans.name: Tusobola Development Group Of Mukono

texts.en:
Teopista K. is 40 years old and is the leader of her group in Mukono. She is married and cares for her three children and four orphans.

Teopista has been running a retail shop operation for ten years and generates 70,000 UGX per week from the business. Right now, her capital levels are low and she would like to use the loan amount of 300,000 UGX to boost business and increase levels of inventory.

loans.use: To buy more inventory

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is 45 years old, married with 6 children. She sells eggs and is also a fashion designer and wishes to add selling sarongs because the demand is high. She has been in the business for the past 17 years. She assists her husband with her profit. She is requesting the loan amount of N80,000 to purchase sarongs and tailoring material to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Pone

texts.en:
Pone R. is currently in the business of selling bread on her veranda and is requesting a loan to buy more items like groundnut paste, cakes, biscuits, etc. to sell. Pone is 36 years old and is married to a husband who is a tailor. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a retail shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy more items like groundnut paste, cakes, biscuits, etc. to sell

loans.name: Rashad

texts.en:
Rashad is a young Palestinian man raised in a big family with three brothers and two sisters. Now he is married with one baby girl.

Rashad started his business five years ago and, with continuous improvements in his equipment, his business is developing. He is a DJ and conducts parties in Bethlehem city, wedding and big events.

Rashad has requested 3,000 USD in order to buy big speakers and other equipment necessary for his business. He appears in the photo at the FATEN office.

loans.use: To buy new equipment

loans.name: Cidalia Alberto

texts.pt:
Cidália Alberto M. nasceu no Distrito da Namaacha, fronteira com a Suazilândia, Província de Maputo, tem 34 anos de idade, solteira e mãe de 2 filhos de 3 e 14 anos de idade, o mais velho vai a escola. Fez nível médio, não continuou por não ter conseguido o ingresso a faculdade. Vive na casa própria em Boane com seus filhos e sustenta sua mãe e sobrinha, enviando um rancho mensal.

Saiu de Namaacha para Boane em 1992, é docente na Escola Primaria de Boane e é quadro do Ministério de Educação há 7 anos. Foi formada pelo Instituto de Magistério Primário da Matola e faz em media 8 horas de trabalho por dia. Tem um salário mensal de 3.749.00mt que aplica nas despesas familiares e ainda poupa algum com as suas amigas através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).

Já teve empréstimo no banco comercial BIM e mais tarde através de seus colegas conheceu a Hluvuku, tendo preferido aproximar e solicitar o seu 1º empréstimo. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 13.000.00mt para compra de material de construção (cimento, ferro, tubos, e material de canalização) para ampliar e canalizar agua para sua casa. O empréstimo anterior foi de 13.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.

Futuramente pretende solicitar novos créditos para poder renovar e ampliar ainda mais a sua residência para oferecer melhores condições de habitação aos seus filhos.
texts.en:
Cidália Alberto M. was born in the district of Namaacha on the border with Swaziland in the province of Maputo. She is 34 and is the mother of 2 children who are 3 and 14. The oldest one goes to school. She studied until secondary school and didn't continue because she wasn't admitted to college. She lives in her own home in Boane with her children and supports her mother and niece by sending them money every month.

She left Namaacha for Boane in 1992 and teaches primary school there. She has worked for the Ministry of Education for 7 years. She received a degree from the Instituto de Magistério Primário in Matola and works 8 hours a day. She makes a monthly salary of 3,749 meticais and uses it to pay for her family's expenses and saves some of it with her friends through a traditional rotating savings system known as Xitique.

She has had a loan with the commercial bank BIM and later became familiar with Hluvuku through her colleagues and requested her first loan. This is her second loan, and it is for 13,000 meticais. She will use it to purchase construction materials like cement, iron, pipes, and sewer equipment to put plumbing in her home. Her previous loan was for 13,000 meticais and was used for the same purpose.

In the future, she hopes to request more loans to be able to improve and expand her home more so she can offer better living conditions to her children.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase construction materials (cement, iron, and plumbing equipment)

loans.name: Biyinzika Development Group B Of Mukono

texts.en:
Sylvia N. is the leader of her group in Mukono. She is 24 years old and is married with two children. In addition to taking care of her children, she also helps support her parents. Sylvia owns a retail shop operation and would like to use her loan of 300,000 USH to purchase more inventory. Some of her debtors have recently had trouble keeping up with their payments, so she requires an additional capital infusion to keep inventory levels stable.

In the future she will be much more careful concerning who she extends credit to and will work with the debtors to arrange repayment schemes. With hard work and determination she hopes to one day be able to afford her own plot of land.

loans.use: More Inventory

loans.name: Temitope

texts.en:
Temitope is a member of LAPO microfinance's Mokola branch. She owns a hairdressing business offering hairstyling services in a location which is very favorable for most of her customers. She has been in this business for about 11 years.

She is 35 years old, married with 3 children. She plans to expand her business by adding the sale of hair extensions and other hair cream. She is requesting the loan amount of N150,000. She hopes that this loan will help her build a business that will be profitable and provide benefits for her family. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase hair extensions and hair creams, etc.

loans.name: Luis Alberto

texts.en:
Luis Alberto C. is 39 years old and has been married to Marina Acevedo for more than 16 years. They have three children, the eldest of whom is 21 and in college; they also have a 12-year-old in middle school, and a 6-year-old in primary school.

Luis started his business 15 years ago, working as a peddlar selling traditionally-woven bedspreads and hammocks. He marketed his products at low prices and built up a loyal clientele with his high quality.

With the profits, Luis has bought two motorcycles to transport his products and sell them across the city. Luis will use his loan to purchase more goods, such as bedspreads and linens to sell at a higher profit.

loans.use: more merchandise to sell

loans.name: Lucia Gabriel

texts.pt:
Lúcia Gabriel C. nasceu em Boane, Província de Maputo, tem 39 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 5 filhos de 17, 15, 11, 07, 03 anos de idade destes os 4 mais velhos vão a escola. Fez somente 5ª classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família em Boane e sustenta mais 2 sobrinhos que vivem com ela.

Mudou se de bairro de Mahubo para a sede Distrital de Boane em 1988 com a sua família, devido a guerra de desestabilização. Actualmente é negociante e dona do seu próprio negocio a mais de 10 anos, trabalha das 7h as 17h com ajuda de seus filhos. Vende mais amendoim, feijão manteiga, arroz e outros, onde consegue um rendimento de cerca de 1.000.00mt por dia que aplica nas despesas familiares e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária e Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku quando inaugurou a sua sucursal de Boane e decidiu solicitar o seu primeiro empréstimo. Este é o seu 5º Empréstimo no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (amendoim, feijão manteiga, açúcar e outros) para reforçar o seu negócio. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 5.000.00mt, 8.000.00mt, 10.000.00mt e 15.000.00mt todos para a mesma actividade. 

No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para poder terminar a sua obra e adquirir mobiliário para a sua residência.
texts.en:
Lúcia Gabriel C. was born in Boane in the province of Maputo. She is 39; married; and the mother of 5 children who are 17, 15, 11, 7, and 3. Her three oldest children go to school. She only studied through 5th grade and didn't continue due to the lack of financial resources. She lives in her own home with her family in Boane and also supports 2 nephews who live with her.

She moved from the neighborhood of Mahubo to the district of Boane in 1988 with her family due to the war that destabilized the country. She has now owned her own business for more than 10 years and works from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. with the help of her children. She sells peanuts, beans, butter, rice, and other products. She earns an income of 1,000 meticais per day which she puts towards her family's expenses and saves some in her bank account through Xitique (a traditional rotating savings system).

She has never had a loan with another bank. She became familiar with Hluvuku when the branch in Boane was inaugurated and she decided to request her first loan. This is her 5th loan and it is for 20,000 meticais. She will use it to buy products (peanuts, beans, butter, sugar, etc) to strengthen her business. Her previous loans were for 5,000, 8,000, 10,000, and 15,000 meticais, and they were all used for the same activity.

In the future, she would like to request more loans to be able to finish her home and to acquire furniture for it.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell food products (peanuts, margarine, etc.)

loans.name: Meding

texts.en:
Meding J. is currently in the business of selling fresh vegetables in the market and is requesting a loan to buy bread and groundnut paste to sell. Meding is 35 years old and is married to a husband who is a primary school teacher. She has 5 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy bread and groundnut paste to sell

loans.name: Nicolás Ramón

texts.en: Nicolas is 47 years old and has been married to Nilda for over 17 years. They live in their own home and have three children of school age. Nicolas worked at a market for 7 years, saving up money to open his own stall to make more profit to support his family and provide them with a comfortable home. Nicolas will use the loan to buy bedspreads, sheets and hammocks to sell from his stall.

loans.use: bedspreads, sheets, and hammocks to sell

loans.name: Bassam

texts.en: Bassam is a Palestinian living in Al-Fawar Refugee Camp near Hebron city. He is married with four children whose ages vary between 3 and 10 years. Bassam is a police officer in the Palestinian National Authority. He established his grocery store to cover the growing expenses of his family. Bassam requested 3,000 USD to buy a variety of products and children’s games for his grocery store to meet the Eid Al-Adha expected demand. Bassam appears in the photo at his grocery store.

loans.use: To purchase some merchandise for his store

location.town: Al-Fawar Regugee Camp, Hebron, West Bank

loans.name: Leap Children Group

texts.en:
Vivian S. is a leader of a group of 5 borrowers called 'LEAP children'.She is a high school graduate who’s fending for herself and her family through business. Vivian doesn’t have a child herself but she cares for a little sister. She lives in the V.I community, Gbarnga city, Bong county, Liberia.

Her business is the sale of slippers. She buys slippers wholesale and sells retail to residents of her community. Vivian has been running this business for 3 years, and she is hoping to improve to have a real shop in the future. She gives customers low prices in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.

She sometimes faces difficulties in purchasing her goods in US dollars because she sells in Liberian dollars. Vivian needs this loan to purchase new goods to grow her business. She dreams of buying land and building a house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase new  goods to improve business

loans.name: Tuwalu

texts.en:
Tuwalu K. is currently in the business of selling bread on her veranda and is requesting a loan to buy bread and groundnut paste to sell. Tuwalu is 30 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to educate her children up to the university level.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations.

BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: buy bread and groundnut paste to sell

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 35 years old, married with 5 children. Her children are excelling in school. She sells cooking oil at retail prices in front of her house. She is happy because she does not have to pay rent for a stall. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profit during this season. She has been in the business for a long time. She hopes for the loan amount of 30,000 NGN to purchase more cooking oil to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Sembwi

texts.en: Sembwi N. is 61 years old, is married to N., and they have three children. Sembwi is a farmer and she does the farming on her own piece of land which she has been doing for the last seven years. Sembwi learned about KADET from other women who had already registered as members in KADET and later on she joined. This will be her second loan which she is planning to use to plant potatoes and carrots which normally do well in her area due to good climatic conditions. She hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to buy dairy cows to supply milk for her family and also to sell to her neighbors to supplement her income. Sembwi’s dream is do large-scale farming and attain financial independence. She is a hardworking woman who is determined to achieve her set goals despite her age. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To plant more potatoes and carrots

loans.name: Fatenah

texts.en:
Fatenah was one of the first borrowers from FATEN’s Hebron branch. She has taken more than ten loans that began with 150 USD.

Fatenah’s business started with FATEN and gradually grew. Now her business is the main source of income for her family which consist of eight members. She even helped her husband to begin work as a taxi driver.

Fatenah has requested 3,000 USD from FATEN to buy some products for her shop since Eid al-Adha is very close.  She appears in the photo at her store.

loans.use: To purchase some products for her grocery store

loans.name: Nelson Moises

texts.pt:
Nelson Moisés M. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, tem 32 anos de idade, casado e pai de 1 filho de 4 anos de idade. Fez somente 8ª classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras por parte de seus progenitores. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e uma sobrinha, sustenta ainda sua mãe que vive em casa de seus irmãos enviando algum valor para ajudar nas despesas de casa.

Nunca saiu de Boane, depois de ter construído a sua residência, passou a viver com sua família constituída. Trabalha como caixa nas bombas de combustíveis PETROMOC há mais de 5 anos e em regime de turnos. Para alem do trabalhão formal tem um negócio próprio onde vende bebidas alcoólicas, refrigerantes e outros. Nesta actividade consegue um rendimento de cerca de 5.000.00mt por mes que aplica nas despesas familiares e ainda poupa algum no Banco Comercial BIM.

Já teve empréstimos com a Associação Guê-gue-gue (instituição de tipo caixa comunitária de poupança e credito) e não, não tendo se sentido confortável com a metodologia de grupo solidários, decidiu parar. Mais tarde, através de comentários de amigos ouviu falar da Hluvuku e optou por aproximar para se inteirar das condições e modalidades. Este é o seu 4º empréstimo no valor de 12.000.00mt com qual pretende comprar produtos ( vinhos, cerveja, refrescos, sumos e outros ) para aumentar a mercadoria de seu estabelecimento. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 4.200.00mt , 7.200.00mt e 10.000.00mt todos para a mesma actividade.

Tem como objectivo com este empréstimo, melhorar a condições alimentares em casa e apostar na educação da sua esposa e filho. No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para concluir a sua obra e oferecer o melhor conforto a família.
texts.en:
Nelson Moisés M. was born in the district of Boane in the province of Maputo. He is 32, is married, and is the father of a 4-year-old son. He only studied through the 8th grade and didn't continue because of his parents' lack of financial resources. He lives in his own home with his family and a niece. He still supports his mother, who lives in his siblings' house by sending her money to help with her expenses.

He has never left Boane. After he built his home, he lived with his family there. He has worked as a cashier at a gas station called Petromoc for 5 years. Besides this formal job, he also has his own business where he sells alcoholic beverages, soft drinks, and other items. Through this activity, he earns 5,000 meticais per month that he uses to pay for his family's expenses and also saves some in the commercial bank, BIM.

He has had loans with an association called Guê-gue-gue (a community bank with savings and credit), but not feeling comfortable with the methodology of support groups, he decided to stop. Later, through friends' comments, he heard about Hluvuku and decided to approch them to find out about their practices. This is his 4th loan, and it is for 12,000 meticais. He will use it to buy products like wine, beer, soft drinks, juice, etc., to increase his merchandise. His previous loans were for 4,200, 7,200, and 10,000 meticais, and they were all used for the same activity.

As a goal for this loan, he wants to improve the food situtation in his home and to support the education of his wife and son. In the future, he hopes to request more loans to finish his home and to offer more comfort to his family.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell products (beer, wine, soft drinks, etc.)

loans.name: Armando Anreasse

texts.pt:
Armando Andreasse Manombo nasceu no Distrito de Marracuene, Província de Maputo, tem 59 anos de idade, casado e pai de 10 filhos cuja idade já não se lembra, 3 destes vão a escola. Fez somente 4ª classe do antigo sistema de educação, não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e ainda sustenta 2 netos que vivem com ele. 

Saiu de Marracuene para o Distrito de Boane a muitos anos trás com a sua família a procura de melhores condições de vida. Trabalha como operador de máquinas pesadas numa pedreira desde 1961 e tem um salário mensal de 4.600.00mt que aplica nas despesas familiares e ainda poupa algum na sua própria casa. A esposa faz venda de produtos de primeira necessidade, como forma de incrementar a receita familiar.

Nunca teve empréstimos com outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigos, e este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (ferro, cimento, areia e outros) para dar continuidade com a sua obra. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 5.00,00mt e 10.000,00mt para comércio e habitação, respectivamente.
 
No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para concluir a sua obra e oferecer melhor conforto para a sua família.
texts.en:
Armando Andreasse Manombo was born in the district of Marracuene in the province of Maputo. He is 59, married, and the father of 10 children whose ages he doesn't remember. Three of his children go to school. He only studied through 4th grade of the old education system and didn't continue due to the lack of financial resources. He lives in his own home with his family and also supports 2 grandchildren that live with him.

He left Marracuene for the district of Boane many years ago with his family in search of better living conditions. He has worked as a heavy equipment operator in a quarry since 1961 and makes a monthly salary of 4,600 meticais. He uses this money to pay for his family's expenses and still saves some at his house. His wife sells basic products as a way of increasing their family's income.

He has never had a loan with another bank. He became familiar with Hluvuku through friends. This is his 3rd loan, and it is for 10,000 meticais. He will use it to purchase construction materials (iron, cement, sand, etc) to finish building his home. His previous loans were for 5,000 and 10,000 meticais and were used for his business and his home, respectively.

In the future, he would like to request more laons to finish his home and to offer more comfort to his family.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, iron, etc.)

loans.name: Francisco

texts.pt:
Francisco João D. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, província com o mesmo nome, capital de Moçambique, tem 24 anos de idade, solteiro e sem filhos. Fez 10ª classe apenas não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa da Irmã e não sustenta ninguém.

Saiu do bairro Hulene em casa dos pais para o bairro Patrice Lumumba (outro bairro da cidade Matola) em casa da sua irmã. Trabalha no Hospital Central de Maputo (maior hospital do pais) ha 4 anos, faz 8h por dia e tem um rendimento mensal de 2.093.00mt que aplica no seu sustento particular e poupa algum na sua conta bancária. 

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de seu vizinho e este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (chapas de zinco, blocos e areia) para poder cobrir uma parte da sua obra.

Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo, para poder aceder a mais créditos no futuro para concluir sua obra e comprar mobiliário.
texts.en:
Francisco João D. was born in the city of Maputo in the province of the same name, which is the capital of Mozambique. He is 24, single, and doesn't have children. He studied through the 10th grade and didn't continue because of the lack of financial resources. He lives in his sister's house and doesn't support anybody financially. He left the Hulene neighborhood where his parents live for the Patrice Lumumba neighborhood (another neighborhood in the city of Matola) where his sister lives. He has worked in the Central Hospital of Maputo (the biggest hospital in the country) for 4 years. He works 8 hours a day and makes a monthly income of 2,093 meticais, which he applies to his expenses and saves some in his bank account. He has never had a loan with another bank. He became familiar with Hluvuku through his neighbor, and this is his first loan for 10,000 meticais. He will use it to buy construction materials (metal sheets, bricks, and sand) to be able to put a roof on part of his house. He promises to pay back his loan on time to be able to request more loans so he can finish his house and buy furniture.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (metal sheets, sand, etc.)

loans.name: Sabari Group

texts.en:
Fanta K. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called Sabari. She is married with 4 children between 25 and 32 years old; their educational levels range from 7th to 9th grade. Due to poverty, Fanta herself is illiterate. She also cares for 2 daughters in law.

Fanta lives around the Gbarnga Central market but works in the market in Gbarnga, Liberia. She sells general goods. She buys them wholesale; then she sells them retail in the Gbarnga Central Market. Fanta has been operating this business for four years, and hopes to improve the shop in the future. She always gives customers discounts in order to encourage them to continue buying from her. Fanta needs this loan to purchase additional goods that will improve her business. She dreams of giving her children a better education and building a house for them.

loans.use: purchasing additional goods to improve business

loans.name: Seyi

texts.en: Seyi is 34 years old. She is married with a child. Her husband is a photographer. She runs a salon where she makes lovely hairstyles for her customers. She also sells salon materials like shampoo, hair extensions and cream. She has been in this business for a long time. She is happy because profits will increase in the upcoming festive season. She is requesting a loan of 30,000 NGN; she will use the money to purchase more salon materials to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing more salon materials to sell

loans.name: Maria Helena

texts.pt:
Maria Helena C. nasceu na Província de Maputo, capital de Moçambique, tem 51 anos de idade, casada e mãe de 2 filhos de 32 e 18 anos de idade todos trabalham já não vão a escola. Fez somente 3ª classe não continuou por falta de condições financeiras por parte dos pais. Vive na casa própria com a sua família, e não sustenta mais ninguém. 

Nunca saiu de Maputo. Possui um estabelecimento comercial onde vende produtos alimentares ha mais de quinze anos. Movimenta um volume de 15.000,00mt e ganha um rendimento de cerca de 3.500,00mt que aplica no sustento da família e pagamento de crédito e popa algum dinheiro na sua conta bancária.

Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de suas amigas e este é o seu 5º empréstimo no valor de 12.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, pedra, areia e mão de obra) para ampliação da sua casa. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 6.000.00mt, 6.000.00mt, 7.200.00mt e 11.200.00mt para compra de mobília, electrodomésticos e outros bens de uso doméstico.

No futuro pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para continuar com a ampliação da casa e comprar mais imóveis para sua residência.
texts.en:
Maria Helena C. was born in the province of Maputo, the capital of Mozambique. She is 51, married, and the mother of 2 children who are 32 and 18. Both of them work and don't go to school. She only studied through the 3rd grade and didn't continue because of her parents' lack of financial resources. She lives in her own home with her family and doesn't support anyone besides them. She never left Maputo. She has a business where she has sold food products for more than 15 years. She has a sales volume of 15,000 meticais a month and earns a monthly income of 3,500 meticais a month, which she uses to support her family, pay for credit, and saves some in her bank account. She has never had a loan with another establishment. She became familiar with Hluvuku through her friends, and this is her 5th loan, which is for 12,000 meticais. She will use it to buy construction materials (cement, stone, sand, and labor) to expand her home. Her previous loans were for 6,000, 6,000, 7,200, and 11,200 meticais, which she used to purchase furniture, appliances, and other domestic goods. In the future, she hopes to request more loans so she can continue expanding her home and to buy more furniture for it.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction material (cement, stone, and labor)

loans.name: Helena

texts.pt:
Helena Henriques B. nasceu na cidade da Matola, Provincial de Maputo, tem 44 anos de idade, viúva e mãe de 6 filhos de 29, 27, 21, 17,15 e 5 anos de idade, 3 destes continuam a estudar. Fez somente 4ª classe do antigo sistema de educação e não continuou por falta de condições. Vive na casa própria com seus filhos e sustenta também a sua mãe, enviando alguns géneros alimentícios.

Nunca saiu da cidade, juntou se ao seu marido quando tinha 17 anos e iniciou uma actividade comercial há 3 anos como forma de aumentar a renda da família. Tem feito uma viagem por semana para africa do sul ou Suazilândia, onde compra os seus produtos. Gere um negocio com volume de 20.500,00mt. vende mais batata Reno e cebola e rende cerca de 10.000.00mt por mes que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).

Já teve empréstimos com algumas associações de crédito, tendo de seguida decidido mudar por vários motivos. Conheceu a Hluvuku através de uma vizinha e este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 10.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (batata, cebola, ovos e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 4.500.00mt, 5.000.00mt e 7.500.00mt todos para a mesma actividade.

Futuramente pretende solicitar mais empréstimos para concluir a sua obra e fortificar ainda mais o seu negócio.
texts.en:
Helena Henriques B. was born in the city of Matola in the province of Maputo. She is 44; a widow; and the mother of 6 children who are 29, 27, 21, 17, 15, and 5. Three of her children are in school. She only studied through the 4th grade of the old educational system and didn't continue due to the lack of financial resources. She lives in her own home with her children and also supports her mother by sending her food. She never moved from her city. She married her husband when she was 17 and started her business 3 years ago as a way of increasing her family's income. She makes a trip every week to South Africa or Swaziland, where she buys her products. She has a sales volume of 20,500 meticais and sells potatoes, white wine, and onions. She earns around 10,000 meticais per month and applies it to her home's expenses and saves some through a traditional rotating savings system known as Xitique. She has had loans with other credit institutions but decided to switch for various reason. She became familiar with Hluvuku through a neighbor. This is her third loan, and it is for 10,000 meticais. She will use it to buy products (potatoes, onions, grapes, etc) to increase her quantity of merchandise. Her previous loans were for 4,500, 5,000, and 7,500 meticais and were all used for the same activity. In the future, she hopes to request more loans to finish her home and to strenghthen her business further.

Translated from Portuguese by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products (potatoes, onions, etc.)

loans.name: Fatimo

texts.en: Fatimo is 40 years old. She is married with 5 children. Her husband sells motor spare parts to support his family. To help, she sells drinks at retail prices to her customers. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more of a profit during this season. She hopes to become a major drink distributor in the future. She is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN; she will use the money to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing more drinks to sell

loans.name: Elizay

texts.en:
Elizay L. currently sells cooked food in a restaurant. Elizay is 20 years old and is married to a husband who works as a policeman. She has 2 children, both of whom go to school.

Elizay is requesting a loan; with the money, she will purchase soft drinks, water and packed juice to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

About BRAC:

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and the empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, all of which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchasing soft drinks, water and packed juice

loans.name: God Will Make A Way Group

texts.en:
Romans D. T. is the leader of a group of 5 borrowers called God Will Make a Way. He is a 29 year old 10th grade student who is fending for himself through business.

He has 2 children, aged 1 and 7 years old respectively; the oldest child is in kindergarten.

He lives in the Iron Gate Community, which is at the entrance of Gbarnga Bong County, Liberia. He sells general goods. He buys them wholesale and sells them at retail prices to members of his community. Roman has been running this business for 4 years, and hopes to improve his shop in the future. He always sells new goods in order to encourage customers to continue buying from him. Roman needs this loan to purchase new goods to improve business. He dreams of giving himself and his children a better education.

loans.use: purchasing new goods to improve business

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret N. is currently in the business of selling items including sugar, cooking oil, and beans in a shop and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar and cooking oil to sell.

Margret is 18 years old and is married to a husband who is a mechanic. She has no children. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for rental purposes.

About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a Palestinian man living in Al-Thahria Village near Hebron city in the south of West Bank. He works at Alia Hospital, a government hospital, and works as head of all gophers, cleaners and janitors.

Mohammad has four sons and one daughter, two of whom are working while his daughter is studying at Abudees University and the youngest son is at high school.

Mohammad has requested 3,000 USD to pay for the tuition of his fourth son since he has been accepted by the medical college in Egpyt and this been his dream since he was a child. So Mohammad decided to take the loan to pay for his son’s tuition.

Mohammad appears in the photo at the FATEN office.

loans.use: To pay for his son's university tuition

loans.name: Adeola

texts.en:
Adeola is 33 years old and is married with three children. Her husband sells stationery.

Adeola has a salon where she makes lovely hairstyles for her customers. She also sells salon materials like shampoo, hair extensions and cream. She has been in this business for a long time.

Adeola is happy because of the festive season and her profits will increase. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more salon materials to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more salon materials

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia A. O., 29, sells water in the Magongo-Chaani area. She applied to the water company to get a pipe to do this business, was granted the outlet and has been operating for one year. While the business has been successful and her location in a residential area is advantageous, there has been water rationing due to the drought in Kenya and that has been a challenge for her. She is using her loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to purchase a storage tank so that she can draw and store water at night when there is no rationing. She would like to grow her business to have more water outlets, and ultimately buy rental houses in this growing area. Lydia is married to a mechanic and they have four children -- three girls and a boy ranging in age from 3 months to 11 years old. She would like to see her children get good educations and good jobs. She views herself as hardworking and honest.

loans.use: To purchase a water storage tank

loans.name: Ngoja

texts.en:
Ngoja M., 30, has a retail shop selling secondhand bed linens. The shop is located in Kongowea marketplace, a suburb of Mombassa, and sells mattress covers, curtains, bath towels as well as leather shoes. His clientele is primarily women and he has both repeat and walk-in customers. He has been in this business for ten years, previously working in a bed linens shop.

Ngoja is using this KES 40,000 loan to expand his offering to include mosquito nets, comforters and bed covers. He would like to expand and have a second location.

Ngoja is married with one child, 2 1/2 years old. His highest goal is for his family to have a good education. He is hardworking, sells good products, and is honest.

loans.use: To offer a wider inventory including nets, comforters and bed covers

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
Saida A. is currently in the business of selling various items in her shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more items such as bags of salt and boxes of soap to sell.

Saida is 20 years old and is married to a husband who is a business man. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel.

About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase items such as bags of salt and boxes of soap to sell

loans.name: Ikechi

texts.en:
Ikechi is 40 years old and is married with a child. He is engaged in the making and selling of bags and has been in business for the past eight years.

Ikechi believes that making good and quality bags will increase his sales. In order to achieve this, he is requesting the loan of N50,000 to purchase more material. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase material to make more bags

loans.name: Moses

texts.en: Moses N. K., age 28, has a grocery stand in a residential suburb of Mombassa called Magongo-Bokole. He has had the stand for a year and a half and operates it with his brother. They offer vegetables, fruit, maize, paraffin and baked goods and their customers are local families. Moses is using this loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to open another business, a DVD/video rental shop in a neighboring town. Moses is married and his wife works at an export manufacturing facility. They have a girl and a boy, ages 2 and 5 years old. Moses dreams of being a successful businessman and educating his children. He says he offers good service, works hard and is honest.

loans.use: To open a new DVD and video rental kiosk

loans.name: Nenyo

texts.en: Nenyo R. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local beer and is requesting a loan to purchase materials to use. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children’s settlement. Nenyo is 40 years old and is widowed. She has seven children and her children do not go to school. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase brewing materials

loans.name: Dasola

texts.en:
Dasola is 27 years old and is married with three children. Her husband is a bricklayer.

Dasola sells groceries retail to make a living in Ibadan, Oyo State and has been in this business for a long time. She is happy because of the high season and she hopes to make more profits during this season.

Dasola is requesting a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Josphina

texts.en: Josphina L. is currently in the business of brewing local alcohol and selling beer and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. Josphina is 42 years old and is married to a health worker. She has eight children of whom six are attending school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel (restaurant). About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Henry

texts.en:
Henry, 31, has a successful metal-fabrication shop with six employees. The shop specializes in brake linings, clutch re-facing and vehicle repairs. He is well located in a business area and his customers are a mix of new and repeat clients. He has had this business for five years and was previously employed in someone else's shop.  

His biggest business challenge is that he needs more machines, particularly a pressing machine, to produce more clutch facings. He is using his 50,000 Kenyan shilling loan to purchase raw materials. His goal is for his shop to grow and employ more mechanics.  

Henry is married and has a boy and a girl, ages 8 months and 3 years. His dream in life is that his children get a good education. His customers say he is a skilled metal worker, honest, hardworking and enterprising.

loans.use: Raw materials for metal fabrication

loans.name: Juan

texts.en: Juan A. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and peeled, dried cassava and is requesting a loan to stock beans and fish to sell. Juan is 40 years old and is married to a businessman. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock beans and fish to sell

loans.name: Jamiru

texts.en:
Jamiru is 33 years old and is married with two children. His wife has a grocery store that she also uses to support the home.

Jamiru sells VCDs and rechargeable phone cards both wholesale and retail to his customers. He has been in this business of five years.

Jamiru hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell. He hopes to own a rechargeable phone card company in the future. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more rechargeable phone cards to sell

loans.name: Mahoussi Hélène

texts.fr: H. Mahoussi Hélène est née le 17 Décembre 1958 à Brazzaville  au Congo, pays voisin du Bénin. Mahoussi Hélène vit depuis près de 28 ans au quartier Attakè à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à HOUESSOU Richard un maçon, Mahoussi Hélène est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Mahoussi Hélène vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Mahoussi Hélène a été à l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire. Il y a environs 20 ans que Mahoussi Hélène vend de la nourriture (riz accompagné de sauce et du poisson frit) à l’école primaire publique de Vèkpa à Porto-Novo. Mahoussi Hélène mène comme activité secondaire, la vente de tissus, par le système de distribution. C’est au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo, et aussi à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, que Mahoussi Hélène fait ses achats. C’est la première fois que Mahoussi Hélène sollicite de crédit à ALIDé. Ce crédit lui servira à augmenter son fonds de roulement et à agrandir son activité.
texts.en:
H. Mahoussi Hélène was born December 17th, 1958 in Brazzaville, in the Congo, the country next to Benin. For the past 28 years, Mahoussi Hélène has lived in the neighborhood of Attakè in Porto-Novo, the government capital of Benin. Mahoussi Hélène is married to Houessou Richard, who is a mason. She is the mother of two children, both of whom attend school. Mahoussi Hélène helps her husband pay for the family's expenses. Mahoussi Hélène was educated just through secondary school. For about 20 years, Mahoussi Hélène has sold food (rice with sauce and fried fish) at the public primary school of Vèkpa à Porto-Novo. Mahoussi Hélène also runs a secondary business, selling fabric through her distribution system. Mahoussi Hélène supplies herself from the market in Ouando, in Porto-Novo, and also in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. This is the first time that Mahoussi Hélène has requested a loan from ALIDé. She will use this loan to increase her business' funds and grow her business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sacks of rice and sauces (fresh tomatoes, onions, spicy peppers, pepper)

loans.name: Anna Anyango

texts.en: Anna is 45 old and owns Ann's Linen Boutique. She sells clothes to walk-in customers at the Sunbeam exhibition in the city centre in Nairobi city. She has done this business for the last 20 years.  She had a loan of KES 20,000 and she repaid it fully.  Her business challenge is the strong competition.  Now, she is using the proceeds of a loan of KES50,000 to buy more clothes to take advantage of the Christmas holiday because of the increase in demand.  She wants to own more shops and be the main supplier.  Anna is a widow with five sons ranging in age from 18 to 24 years. She describes herself as hardworking, smart, social and outgoing.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to resell.

loans.name: Hidia

texts.en:
Hidia S. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and charcoal and is requesting a loan to stock tomatoes and onions to sell.  

Hidia is 26 years old and is married to a teacher. She has three children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy tomatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria B. is currently in the business of selling maize flour and sorghum in the market and is requesting a loan to buy more bags of maize flour and sorghum.  Maria is a 45-year-old widow.   She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a wholesale shop.


 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more bags of maize flour and soghum.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary is excited to take a Kiva loan. She sells cooked foods. She is 37 years old and married with four children. She has been in business for seven years. She loves cooking and she always wants to meet her customer's demands. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. She is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs. She say thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Ademola

texts.en: Ademola is 47 years old and married with three children. His wife is a fashion designer. He sells stationery at retail prices to his customers. He has been in this business for a long time. He hopes to own a supermarket in the future. He hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more stationery items to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more stationery to sell

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.fr: Z. Antoinette est née vers 1973 à Dangbo dans le département de l’Ouémé au Bénin. Antoinette vit depuis près de 18 ans à Vakon Azohoué non loin de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à NOUNAGNON Alain un soudeur, Antoinette est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Antoinette vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari, et supporte avec son mari les charges de la famille.
