Antoinette n’a pas été à l’école. Pour se prendre en charge, Antoinette vend de la nourriture (riz accompagné de sauce et du poisson frit) de façon ambulante. C’est au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo que Antoinette s’approvisionne. Antoinette a déjà obtenu de ALIDé, trois crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. C’est pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et accroître son activité que Antoinette sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Z. Antoinette was born in 1973 in Dangbo, in the county of Ouémé in Benin. For the past 18 years, Antoinette has lived in Vakon Azohoué, not far from Porto-Novo, the gorvernment capital of Benin. Antoinette is married to Nounagnon Alain, a welder. She is the mother of four children, all of whom attend school. Antoinette lives with her children and husband. She and her husband take care of the family's expenses. Antoinette did not attend school. In order to take care of the family's needs, Antoinette sells food (rice with sauce and fried fish) throughout town. Antoinette supplies herself in the market of Ouando in Porto-Novo. Antoinette has previously taken three loans with ALIDé, all of which were fully reimbursed. In order to increase the funds for her business and grow her business, Antoinette is requesting a fourth loan with ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sacks of rice and sauces (fresh tomatoes, onions, spicy peppers)

loans.name: Amparro

texts.en:
Amparro sells various types of food from a stand just outside the Town Hall of Nindiri, which is about 20 minutes from CEPRODEL’s office in Masaya. She has been selling food for seven years, though her business used to be much smaller. She is requesting the loan to buy ingredients such as flour and sugar as well as other items to sell like sodas and candies. 

With her loan, Amparro hopes to improve her business. She would like it to grow little by little. Before she opened her food stand, Amparro sold bread “ambulante,” which means while walking around the streets.  Amparro, 48, is single with three children. All three are still in school. She has been working with CEPRODEL for two years. This is her fourth loan with CEPRODEL.

loans.use: To buy basic ingredients, sweets and sodas

loans.name: Ingrind

texts.es:
La socia INGRIND pertenece al banco comunal “MERCAMUEBLE” y vive en la ciudad Imperial del Cusco. 

La socia tiene 29 años de edad, es conviviente, tiene un hijo varón. El mayor estudia en el jardín y ella esta embrazada. Ella tiene un pequeño negocio de fabricación (taller de carpintería).  y venta de muebles 

Ella alterna sus actividades del hogar con la fabricación de muebles como escritorios, roperos, sillas, mesas, camas, etc. La socia tiene un stand de venta de muebles en el mercado “MERCAMUEBLES” ubicado en el primer paradero del distrito de San Sebastián de la provincia del Cusco. Ya son varios años con esta actividad y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone para en su trabajo.
       
La socia requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital del negocio de fabricación y venta de muebles, ella quiere comprar más materia prima (madera) y materiales para el acabado del muebles como tiner, laca, lijar, cola de carpintero, etc. 

La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Ingrind belongs to the Mercamueble Communal Bank. She lives in the Imperial city of Cusco. She is in a common law marriage, and she has a son. He is in preschool, and she is pregnant. She has a small business (carpentry shop) of making and selling furniture. She alternates her activities between the home and making furniture like desks, wardrobes, chairs, tables, and beds, etc. She helps her husband make and sell the furniture. She has a furniture selling stand in the Mercamuebles Market, which is located at the first bus stop in the San Sebastián province of Cusco. She has been doing this for many years. It has gone very well for her thanks to all of the effort she puts into her work. She needs a loan to increase the capital in her business of making and selling furniture. She wants to buy raw material (wood) and materials like thinner, shellac, sandpaper, and glue, etc. for finishing the furniture. She is grateful for the opportunity of the loan, and she promises to pay it back on time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase business capital for her business of making and selling furniture

loans.name: Nyiva

texts.en: Nyiva is 31 years old and sells children's clothes to walk-ins and frequent customers at Gikomba market. This is an open-air market just outside the city center. She started this business in 2004 and has borrowed KES 20,000 and repaid successfully. Her business challenges are competition and insecurity in the market.  She is using the proceeds of the loan of KES50,000 to buy more children's clothes in preparation for the holiday season.  She wants to be a wholesaler.  Nyiva is single and describes herself as hardworking, jovial and social.

loans.use: To buy more clothes.

loans.name: Aubaine Plus Group

texts.en:
Aubaine Plus is a group of owners of small businesses chaired by Marie. Its members are jointly responsible for loans granted by Kiva to grow their businesses.
Marie Mudiangu is determined to be a successful businesswoman. She sells peanuts in a market to the north of Kinshasa. Since 1979 she has acquired solid experience in this area and works hard with good management skills. She dreams of one day opening a peanut facility. She would also like to achieve financial independence through her business that earns her $240 per month. She works to the best of her abilities and uses her contacts so that she might achieve her goals. Marie is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having obtained and repaid four loans. She will increase her stock of merchandise with her next loan by buying 2 50kg sacks of peanuts and reselling them at a profit. 49 years old, Marie is married and the mother of five children, whose ages range from 20 to 30 years old.

loans.use: To purchase 2 50kg sacks of peanuts to resell at a profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is 40 years old and has been a widow for many years. She has three children aged 14, 16 and 18 and she also takes care of one dependent from another family. Florence lives in the Kicukiro district of Kigali.

Florence has owned a business selling soft drinks, snacks and milk for the past four years and employs three people in her business. The store is open from 6 a.m. to 9 p.m. every day except Sunday.

Florence is a proven entrepreneur. She repaid her first loan in full and on time and now she is requesting her second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company so that she may keep growing her business. She plans to add some new goods such as juice, cakes and other delectable food supplies.

With this loan, if her plan is successful, Florence will save the additional profit and reinvest it in her business. Also, she will save a portion for her family's future in order to be more financially stable and to live less worried about money all the time.

loans.use: To add goods such as juice, cakes and other delicious foods

loans.name: Kacu

texts.en:
Kacu F. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and groundnut paste. She is requesting a loan to purchase brewing materials like yeast, pipes etc. 

 Kacu is 32 years old and is married to a soldier. She has three children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase brewing materials like yeast, distilation tubes etc

loans.name: Clé Du Ciel Plus Group

texts.en: Clé du Ciel Plus is a Community Bank made up of 32 members whose chairwoman is Madeleine W.. These members are united for the same goal: to grow their businesses with loans received from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC. Madeleine sells 10-kg sacks of corn flour. She began her business in 1982. After hard work and good management, she succeeded in making the business thrive thanks to the accumulated profits. Madeleine is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having obtained and repaid four loans. She will increase her stock of merchandise with her next loan by purchasing ten 10-kg sacks of corn flour and reselling them at a profit. Madeleine is 50 years old, married and the mother of 3 children, whose ages range from 18 to 29.

loans.use: to purchase 10 10-kg sacks of corn flour to resell at a profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Alice

texts.fr: H. Alice est née le 8 Juillet 1972 à Brazzaville au Congo, Etat voisin du Bénin. Alice est mariée à SINGBO Médard un infirmier. Le couple a trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. C’est depuis 8 ans que Alice vit au quartier Sainte Anne à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Alice a été à l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire. Après avoir arrêté les études, Alice a  appris la couture. Alice exerce ce métier depuis 17 ans. Alice vend également des produits de beauté et des tissus dans son atelier à Attakè à Porto-Novo. C’est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, et au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo, que Alice s’approvisionne. Alice est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé qui a bien remboursé les deux premiers crédits qu’elle a obtenus de ALIDé. C’est pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et agrandir davantage son activité que Alice sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
H. Alice was born on the 8th of July, 1972 in Brazzaville in the Congo, the country next to Benin. Alice is married to Singbo Médard, a nurse. The couple has three children, all of whom are attending school. For the past 8 years, Alice has lived in the neighborhood of Sainte Anne in Porto-Novo, the government capital of Benin, with her children and husband. Together the couple pays for the family's expenses. Alice attended school just through secondary school. After finishing her studies, Alice studied dress/ clothes making. Alice has been in this business for 17 years. Alice sells beauty products and fabrics from her store in Attakè in Porto-Novo. Alice supplies herself in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, and in the market of Ouando in Porto-Novo. Alice is an old client of ALIDé and she fully repaid the two previous loans she obtained from ALIDé. In order to grow the funds for her business, and grow her business, Alice is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase beauty products (body cream, bath soaps, lip cream, moisturizer, perfumes, etc.)

loans.name: Funmi

texts.en: Funmi is 50 years old and married with four children. Her husband is a commercial tailor. She sells groceries and drinks to earn a living. She is a hard working woman. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Jesca's Group

texts.en: N. Jesca is the leader of her lending group in Namuwongo Bukasa. She is a single mother of four children aged 11, 9, 7 and 5 years. She divorced her husband a few years ago. All her children are in school. She is a clinical officer and has been working in a clinic in Namuwongo for four years. She is able to make 40,000/= profit a week. She is successful because she is effective in her service. In the future, she would like to start up another clinic and educate all her children to the University level. Jesca needs a loan to help her with buying more medicine to increase her stock. This will help her from having shortages. Jesca is such a hard working and determined lady.

loans.use: To buy more medicine to increase her stock

loans.name: Aylen

texts.es:
La señora Aylen, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Shatojinas Laboriosas”, Distrito de Shatoja, Provincia del Dorado, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 40 años, es madre de 03 hijos, que aun dependen de ella.

Aylen, se dedica a la venta de pescados frescos, hace 08 años atrás, cuenta con 10 piscigranjas, ubicada a varios kilómetros de la cuidad, donde cría sus pescados, ya que llevada por la intención de ayudar a su familia en sus ingresos económicos, no dudo en hacerlo, por lo que hoy en día continúa con el mismo negocio pero ya en mayores cantidades y variedad de  especies.
Con este préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, comprará alimentos para mantener sanos a sus pescados: bocachico, palometas, toa, gamitada, tilapias, toyo, pejerey para así mantener nutridos y así satisfacer el exigente gusto de su clientela. 

Ella nos manifiesta su complacencia por pertenecer muchos años a un grupo de mujeres que le ha ayudado a superar dificultades que en algún momento tuvo que pasar pero que ahora los enfrenta con mucha fortaleza.
texts.en:
Aylen is a member of the communal bank called Shatojinas Laboriosas, in the district of Shatoja in San Martin. She is 40 years old, and married with 3 children who depend on her. Aylen has worked selling fresh fish for the last 8 years. She counts on 10 fisheries, located several kilometers outside the city where the fish are raised. She started this business to help increase her family's income, and she has no doubt done that as today she continues to work selling fish, but in greater quantities and with more variety. With this loan, she will purchase the food and nutrients she needs to keep the fish healthy, making sure they meet the demand of her customers. Aylen says she is content to belong to a group of women who have helped her overcome difficulties in the past, and who now provide a great deal of strength.

Translated from Spanish by Emily Charnes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food and nutrients for the fish she raises and sells

loans.name: Tinu

texts.en: Tinu is 48 years old and married with five children. She sells shoes and bags in front of her house in Ibadan, Oyo state. She has been in this business for a long time. She is very determined to lift her business and family above poverty. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more shoes and bags to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.fr: A. Dorcas est née vers 1978 à Avrankou, dans le département de l’Ouémé au Bénin. Dorcas vit à Vakon Azohouè non loin de Porto-Novo, et est mariée à DJOÏ Jonas, un chauffeur. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Dorcas vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Depuis près de 20 ans, Dorcas vend des légumes et des condiments de sauce à Ouando à Porto-Novo. C’est à Ikpinlè et à Dangbo, au Sud du Bénin, que Dorcas fait ses emplettes. Dorcas a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. En vue d’accroître son activité et de mieux satisfaire les demandes des consommateurs, Dorcas sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Dorcas envisage acquérir sa propre parcelle et construire plus tard sa maison, grâce à ses économies.
texts.en:
A. Dorcas was born in 1978 in Avrankou, within the county of Ouémé in Bénin. Dorcas lives in Vakon Azohouè, not far from Porto-Novo, and is married to Djoi Jonas, a driver. The couple has four children, all of whom are attending school. Dorcas lives with her husband and children. Together, Dorcas and her husband pay for the family's expenses. For the past 20 years, Dorcas has sold vegetables and sauces in Ouando, which is in Porto-Novo. Dorcas purchases her supplies in Ikpinlè and in Dangbo, in the south of Benin. She has previously benefitted from 3 loans with ALIDé, all of which she fully repaid. In order to grow her business and better satisfy the needs of her clientele, Dorcas is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé. Dorcas hopes to purchase a parcel of land and later build her own home, with the help of her business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase various vegetables and sauces

loans.name: Mapamboli Plus Group

texts.en:
Marc K., age 29, is the president of the Community Bank "Mapamboli Plus," which is composed of 28 members united in solidarity to receive loans from Kiva through MFI HOPE DRC with the goal of developing their businesses.

Marc is single. He runs a cell phone booth. He has been in business since 2001. He manages his cell phone booth in an area located northeast of the city of Kinshasa. He is a loyal client of FMI HOPE DRC. He has already received four different loans and has repaid them properly. With the aim of increasing his profits, he intends to use the next loan to buy prepaid phone cards to sell. Each week, his business brings in a profit of $50. His ambition is to open a general store.

loans.use: To purchase prepaid phone cards to sell in order to increase profits

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Starting Point Group

texts.en:
Particious F. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Starting Point. She is a high school graduate and a single mother of a year-old child.
She lives in the Bassa community, Gbarnga city, Bong county, Liberia.
Her business is the sales of general goods. She buys general goods wholesale and sells retail to residents of Bassa community, Gbarnga city, Bong county, Liberia.
Particious has been running this business for seven years and hopes to move her business to a store in the future.
She sells quality goods and entertains her customers in order to encourage customers to continue buying from her.
Transporting her goods from the wholesale depot to the business area is the only difficulty Particious faces.
She needs this loan to purchase more goods to improve business. 
Particious dreams of giving her and her child a better education.

loans.use: To purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Jenny Jovita

texts.es:
Jenny  M.  es socia del Banco Comunal Picoaza.  Este  banco está conformado por mujeres  de todas las  edades.  Picoaza es un pueblito ubicado a diez  minutos al norte de Portoviejo en la provincia de Manabí en la región costa de Ecuador, ésta  provincia es  muy  conocida por su gastronomía, las playas y los ceibos (árboles únicos de la región) y ésta localidad no podía ser la excepción pues es un lugar muy comercial, aquí  encontramos muchos  distribuidores de productos agrícolas,  consumo, ropa, etc.

Nuestra socia	es soltera y tiene un niño  de cinco años  de nombre  Steven, su casa es propia y en ella tiene una distribuidora de maquillajes,  perfumes y,  bisutería en general, cuenta  con un buen número de clientes fijos por los productos de buena calidad que distribuye.
 

Jenny  va a usar el credito obtenido para comprar  cremas, maquillajes, bisutería y todo en cosméticos para la época navideña para ofrecer más y mejores productos a sus clientes.  Su sueño es continuar con su negocio para mantener a su familia y para en el futuro mejorar su casa.
texts.en:
Jenny M. is a member of the Picoaza communal bank. The bank is made up of women of all ages. Picoaza is a small town located ten minutes north of Portoviejo in the province of Manabí, in the coastal region of Ecuador. This province is well known for its cuisine, beaches and ceibo trees (unique to the region). It is also a commercial center, with many distributors of agricultural products, consumer goods, clothes, etc.

Jenny is single and has a 5-year-old son named Steven. She has her own house from which she operates her business selling makeup, perfumes, and costume jewelry. She has many regular customers because of the high quality of products she sells.

Jenny seeks a loan to purchase creams, makeup, costume jewelry and all types of cosmetics, to be able to offer her clients more and better products for the Christmas season. Her dream is to continue with her business to maintain her family and, in the future, improve her house.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase creams, makeup, and costume jewelry

loans.name: Latifat

texts.en: Latifat is 32 years old and married with five children. Her children are excelling in school. She sells bags of rice at wholesale prices to her customers. She has been in this business for 10 years. She is a friendly woman and she uses her friendly skills to attract more customers to her stall. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to make more profit during this season. She hopes for a loan of 60,000 NGN to purchase more bags of rice to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of rice to sell

loans.name: Emma

texts.es:
La señora Emma, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Shatojinas Laboriosas”, Distrito de Shatoja, Provincia del Dorado, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 48 años y es madre de 06 hijos, 03 que aun dependen de ella.

Su espíritu luchador que siempre le ha caracterizado y las ganas de salir adelante con sus propios medios le ha valido para iniciar su propio negocio de venta de Anticuchos y lleva 05 años en el negocio, ubicada al frente de la Plaza, en un ambiente muy bien acondicionado, donde hay mucho movimiento y poco a poco fue haciéndose muy conocida entre sus clientes y hoy nos cuenta que le va muy bien en este tipo de actividad.  En la actualidad, continua con el mismo negocio y esta muy contenta con el trabajo que realiza.
 
Con este préstamo de S/. 1,800.00, comprará insumos como arroz en sacos, huevos, gallinas criollas para sus juanes, asimismo utensilios de cocina para brindar un servicio de calidad y remplazar a los antiguos.

Emma, se siente muy tranquila y contenta con lo que hace  y  agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Emma belongs to the "Shatojinas Laboriosas" community bank in the Shatoja District in the province of El Dorado in the city of San Martin. She is married, is 48 years old and is a mother of 6 children, 3 of which still depend on her. Having always been known as a fighting spirit and the desire to get ahead by her own means, she started her own business selling anticuchos (grilled meat skewers and kebabs). She has been in the business for 5 years, that which is located in front of the Plaza. It is a good environment where there is much movement and gradually is becoming well known among her customers. Today she tells us that she's doing very well in this business. Today, she continues with the same business and is very pleased with her work. With this loan, she will buy inputs such as bagged rice, eggs, chickens and kitchen utensils to provide better quality service and replace the old utensils. Emma is very calm and content with what she does. She thanks the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for contributing to the fulfillment of her dreams and goals.

Translated from Spanish by Zal Bilimoria, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice, eggs, chickens and utensils for her stall

loans.name: Toma Yvonne

texts.fr: G. Toma Yvonne est née le 16 Octobre 1975 à Aguégué dans le département de l’Ouémé au Bénin. C’est à Sagbokossou à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, que Toma Yvonne vit. Toma Yvonne vit dans ce quartier depuis une vingtaine d’année. Toma Yvonne est une veuve qui est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Toma Yvonne vit seule avec ses enfants et supporte seule les charges de la famille. Toma Yvonne n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il y a environs 15 ans que Toma Yvonne  vend des poissons frits accompagnés de l’akassa (aliment local fait à base d’amidon de maïs) de façon ambulante et à l’école Sagbokossou. Toma Yvonne s’approvisionne au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo. Toma Yvonne  a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Dans l’optique d’étendre son activité et de satisfaire plus sa clientèle, Toma Yvonne sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Toma Yvonne G. was born on October 16, 1975 in Aguégué in Benin's Ouémé department. For the last twenty years she has lived in the Sagbokossou neighborhood in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Toma Yvonne is a widow and mother of three children, all of whom attend school. She lives on her own, with her children, and she manages all the family expenses alone. Toma Yvonne did not attend school herself. For about the last 15 years she has sold fried fish and "akassa" (a local food made from corn starch) both door-to-door and at Sagbokossou school. She stocks up at Ouando market in Porto-Novo. Toma Yvonne has already had two loans from Kiva Field Partner, ALIDé, and she repaid them without difficulty. With a view to extending her business and better satisfying her clientele, she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy wholesale fish

loans.name: C4353 Abishyizehamwe Group

texts.en:
Bertine is 28 years old and is married with five children. She lives in Kimironko, located in Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Bertine's business is located in the busy and popular Kimironko Market.

Bertine is the president of a group called Abishyizehamwe. This is the group's third successful year in the business of selling secondhand and gently-worn clothing. The hours of their business require that they work from early in the morning until late in the evening depending upon customer traffic on any given day.

The members of this group, after having the idea of improving their business and increasing their sales, are requesting their first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. With this loan, these members plan to carefully source and then purchase various different and attractive styles of used clothes. This new variety in their offering will hopefully attract more customers as well as earn more profit for Abishyizehamwe.

With this profit, they will reinvest in their business so that in the future, loans are not necessary. They will be able to rely on equity and cash-on-hand. Also, they all plan and hope to continue taking care of their families.

loans.use: To purchase additional used clothes for sale

loans.name: Teresa Victoria

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Manuelita Sáenz se reúne en barrio Jocay de la ciudad de Manta en la costa de Ecuador, Manta es el primer puerto atunero de Sudamérica es una zona de mucho movimiento económico.

La señora Teresa Z.  es oriunda de Quevedo en la provincia de Los Ríos, llegó a vivir a Manta hace 20 años, aquí  formó su familia, actualmente se encuentra casada  y tiene tres hijos jóvenes universitarios, el esposo es de profesión chofer que trabaja en un taxi en la ciudad.

Teresita es una mujer dedicada a la costura, de profesión modista, se preparó cuando era muy joven sus padres fueron los que la impulsaron a que estudie y se prepare, se graduó en  esta profesión y desde hace 5 años trabaja en éste arte, confecciona ropa deportiva, vestidos de novia y ropa intima,  en su casa  tiene un pequeño taller, ella diseña los modelos de sus prendas,  cuenta que ahora el  negocio está un poco bajo porque algunas personas prefieren comprar la ropa ya confeccionada por eso opto por confeccionar y entregar a almacenes para que comercialicen sus diseños, cada prenda tiene un costo de 30, 50 o 70 dólares dependiendo del diseño y la complejidad de confeccionarlo.

 Teresa está solicitando un nuevo préstamo a la Fundación para invertir en  la compra de  telas, hilos, botones, cierres, y otros implementos para la confección de sus prendas  y entregar a tiempo los  nuevos pedidos, para ello  ella  viaja hasta la ciudad de Guayaquil  y Portoviejo para adquirir la materia prima por un costo aproximado de 800 hasta 1000 dólares en cada  compra.
texts.en:
The communal bank, "Manuelita Sáenz" meets in the Jocay neighborhood in the city of Manta on the coast of Ecuador. Manta is the first tuna port in South America and it is an area with a lot of economic activity.

Señora Teresa Z. is a native of Quevedo in the province of Los Ríos. She came to Manta to live 20 years ago and formed her family here. She is currently married and has three young children who are in college. Her husband is a taxi driver in the city.

Teresita is a woman who makes a leaving by sewing and designing. She learned when she was very young and her parents motivated to study and practice. She graduated and has worked for more than 5 years in this field. She makes athletic clothing, wedding dresses, and lingerie. She has a workshop in her home where she makes her designs. She tells us that her business is a little low right now because some people prefer to buy clothing that is already made, and that is why she chose to make and deliver her designs to department stores. Each piece of clothing costs $30, $50, or $70 depending on the design and how complex it is to make.

Teresa is requesting a new loan from the Fundación to invest in the purchase of fabric, thread, buttons, zippers, and other items to make her clothing so she can deliver her orders on time. She will travel to Guayaquil and Portoviejo to acquire these materials at a cost of approximately $800-1,000.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase supplies like fabric, thread, zippers, buttons, and more to make her designs

loans.name: Maria Mairena

texts.es:
María Mairena tiene 26 años se divorció del padre de sus dos hijos hace algún tiempo, vive con ellos y con su madre  que enfermó  y  la dejó  en silla de ruedas,  en el centro de la urbe mantense donde ha podido sobresalir a pesar de los múltiples inconvenientes, debido a su situación tuvo que dejar de estudiar para dedicarse a trabajar  en horarios de la tarde y noche porque en la mañana se dedica a los quehaceres del hogar, al cuidado de sus niños y de su madre; una prima le ayuda con el cuidado de los niños cuando ella sale a trabajar.

María Mairena asistió a las reuniones del Banco comunal incentivada por su cuñada, le gusto mucho los beneficios otorgados por la Fundación y desde ese momento formó parte del mismo,  ella  se dedica a la  venta puerta puerta  en su localidad ofreciendo  ropa para damas, caballeros y niños, ropa de cama, etc.,  inició su  negocio con el primer crédito de  trescientos dólares obtenidos de la fundación, para abastecerse de  mercadería ella viaja cada mes a Guayaquil y trae un aproximado de 900 dólares en cada compra,  manifiesta que tiene ya sus clientes fijos.

Con el préstamo solicitado va a comprar  más mercadería como pantalones, camisetas, blusas, calcetines, interiores, ropa de cama, etc.  para damas, caballeros y niños para incrementar su negocio y contar con un stock surtido para sus clientes para la época navideña.
texts.en:
María Mairena, 26, has been divorced for some time now. She lives in dowtown Manta with her two children and her mother, who is confined to a wheel-chair due to illness. She has managed to get ahead little by little despite many difficulties. Because of her situation, she had to leave school and go to work during afternoons and evenings because during the morning she has to do her domestic chores, take care of her children and her mother. A cousin babysits for her when she goes to work. Her sister-in-law motivated María Mairena to attend communal bank meetings and she liked the benefits the Foundation offered very much. So, from that moment, she became a member. She sells clothing door-to-door. She began her business with help from her first, 300 dollar, loan from the foundation, which she used to buy stock inventory. She travels to the city of Guayaquil each month to get her merchandise and brings back about 900 dollars worth each time; she tell us that she has regular customers. With the requested funds she wants to buy merchandise like pants, t-shirts, blouses, socks, underwear, bed linens, etc. for women, men and children to increase her inventory and have varied stock available for her clients during the Christmas season.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pants, blouses, shirts, socks, underwear, bed linens, etc. for women, men and children.

loans.name: T. Danielle

texts.fr: H. T. Danielle est née le 10 Février 1966 à Brazzaville au Congo, Etat voisin du Bénin. Danielle vit à Attakè à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, depuis 29 ans. Mariée à GBODOGBE Luc un transformateur, Danielle est mère de trois enfants tous scolarisés. Danielle vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Danielle est allée à l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire. Pour se prendre en charge, Danielle vend des divers (papier hygiénique, sucre, sardine, conserves, insecticides, enveloppes, etc.) du riz, maïs et de la farine de manioc devant son portail à Attakè. C’est depuis 20 ans que Danielle mène cette activité. Danielle s’approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, et au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. Danielle a bénéficié de deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. En vue d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’accroître davantage son activité pour faire face à la demande de la clientèle en période des fêtes de fin d’année, Danielle sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Danielle ambitionne acheter plus tard, une parcelle et construire sa propre maison.
texts.en:
T. Danielle H. was born February 10th, 1966, in Brazzaville, Congo, a country next to Benin. For the last 29 years Danielle has lived in Attakè of Porto-Novo, administrative capital of Benin. She is married to Luc GBODOGBE, who works in a cashew nuts' transforming factory, and she is mother of three children, who are all attending school. Danielle supports her husband with family's expenses. She attended secondary school. To provide for her household she sells in Attakè, by her door, different items (toilette paper, sugar, sardines, cannery, insecticides, envelopes, etc.) as well as rice, corn and manioc flour. Danielle has run this business for twenty years. Danielle buys her supplies in Cotonou, financial capital of Benin, as well as at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. Danielle was granted from ALIDé two previous loans, that she fully repaid. In order to increase her operating fonds and to be ready to satisfy her customers for the end of the year business, Danielle requests a third loan to ALIDé. Danielle wishes to be able in the future to buy a piece of land and build her own house.

Translated from French by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy different items (sugar, cannary, rice, corn, etc.)

loans.name: 5190 Abishyizehamwe Group

texts.en:
Jean marie vianey is 30 years old and he is single.  To save money, he lives with his parents in Nyarugenge, a region of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda. Here Jean marie vianey is the group representative of seven people in a group called Abishyizehamwe.

Jean marie vianey is new to the business of buying and selling spare parts. Though he is a bit of a novice in this industry, his business is running well and he works hard to make it successful, working every day except Sunday from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. His business employs two other people as helpers.

The reason why Jean marie vianey is requesting a loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders is to expand his business by purchasing more and different spare parts for sale. Prior to requesting this loan, Jean marie vianey's monthly profit was approximately 150,000 RWF (~250 USD). If his expansion strategy is successful he expects to earn more profit which he will reinvest in his business.

Jean marie vianey also he plans to get married someday, which is not inexpensive and he is saving for that as well as for having a family.

loans.use: To purchase more spare parts

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina is 45 years old and married with three children. Her husband is an engineer. She has a restaurant where she sells drinks and cooked foods like rice, beans, and yam. She has been in this business for a long time. She sells for long hours to enable her to meet the basic needs of her family. She hopes for a loan of 60,000 NGN to purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to cook and sell

loans.name: Rébecca Adeline

texts.fr: H. Rébecca Adeline est née le 12  Octobre 1978 à Abidjan en Côte d’Ivoire, Etat voisin du Bénin. Mariée à KLIDJOHOUN Vincent, un électricien bâtiment, Rébecca Adeline est mère de trois enfants, et a un autre enfant à charge. Rébecca Adeline vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Gbodjè à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Rébecca Adeline a arrêté très tôt les classes et a appris la coiffure. Rébecca Adeline mène cette activité de coiffure depuis deux ans et a son atelier devant sa maison. Rébecca Adeline vend également des mèches, des sacs pour dames et des cartes de recharges téléphoniques dans son atelier. C‘est à Djègan-Kpèvi à Porto-Novo que Rébecca Adeline s’approvisionne. C’est la première fois que Rébecca Adeline sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qui lui servira à accroître la taille de son activité.
texts.en:
H. Rébecca Adeline was born on October 12, 1978 in Abidjan in Cote d'Ivoire, a country near Benin.  Married to KLIDJOHOUN Vincent, a building electrician, she is the mother of three children.  She lives together with her children and husband in Gbodjè in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin.  The children are all in school. Early on, Rébecca Adeline stopped going to class and learned to style hair. She has been working in hairstyling for two years and has her salon in front of her house. She also sells hair extensions, women's bags, and mobile phone recharge cards in her salon. She gets her supplies in Djègan-Kpèvi in Porto-Novo. This is the first time that she has requested a loan from ALIDé. The loan will be used to expand her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Hair extensions and phone cards to sell

loans.name: Yasmina

texts.es:
La socia YASMINA pertenece al banco comunal “HATUN S.”. El nombre del banco comunal es de origen del idioma Quechua, “HATUN” significa “Grande” y “S.” significa “Corazón” que traducido al español significa “Corazón grande”.

La socia tiene 30 años de edad, es conviviente, tiene un hijo varón de un año y ellos viven en la ciudad Imperial del Cusco. La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el pequeño negocio de lavandería, nuestra socia tiene un convenio con hoteles de la ciudad, los hoteles llevan a su lavandería de la socia a lavar sabanas, cubre camas, manteles y ropa de los turistas que se hospedan en los hoteles. Ya son varios años con esta actividad y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo, nuestra socia es una mujer luchadora y emprendedora pues con mucha voluntad se dedica al negocio y piensa en aumentar su capital de negocio comprando más productos como detergente para lavar más ropa.     
 
La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Yasmina belongs to the community bank "Hatun S.", which means "Big Heart" in the Incan language of Quechua. Yasmina is 30 years old, is in a common law marriage, and has a one year old son. They live in the imperial city of Cusco. Yasmina balances the running the household with the responsibilities of her small laundry business. She has an arrangement with the hotels of the city in which the hotels bring their laundry and she washes the sheets, bed covers, blankets and clothes of the tourists staying in the hotels. She has done this work for several years and it has gone very well thanks to all of the effort she has put into her work. She is an enterprising woman who has fully devoted herself to the business and now wants to increase her business capital in order to buy more products like detergent so that she can wash more clothing. She is grateful for the opportunity offered through these loan services and commits to paying back the loan on time.

Translated from Spanish by Colleen Godfrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working capital by buying more products like detergent

loans.name: Mercedes Trinidad

texts.es:
En el bello puerto marítimo de Manta en la Provincia de Manabí encontramos  el banco comunal Manuelita Sáenz, este banco está formado por mujeres emprendedoras en busca de mejores días para su familia.

Mercedes esta felizmente casada tiene dos hijos solteros, ella vive en Manta en el barrio 11 de Noviembre, su casa  es propia en  ella ha improvisado un espacio para poner su negocio de calzado, lleva cinco  años realizando este  trabajo que ama y no ha pensado en realizar otra actividad, sus ventas las realiza a sus vecinos de la  localidad  con facilidades de pago por lo que  sus clientes la visitan en casa para comprar y escoger de la gran variedad que oferta.

Para mantener surtido su negocio ella viaja a Guayaquil periódicamente,  compra a los distribuidores  para obtener mejores  ganancias, sobre todo trabaja con calzado colombiano porque son de buena calidad y es lo que sus clientes más solicitan, su hermana queda a cargo del negocio cuando ella vija a traer mas  mercadería.

Mercedes está solicitando un nuevo préstamo para realizar la compra de calzado casual y deportivo para esta época del año que es la mas importante en cuanto  a las ventas, su meta es seguir trabajando con los comerciantes mayoristas para obtener buenas ganancias  y seguir incrementando su negocio sin quedar mal con los pagos del préstamo que la Fundación Espoir le esta entregando.
texts.en:
The Manuelita Sáenz communal bank is in the beautiful port city of Manta, Manabí province. It's members are enterprising women who seek ways to improve life for their families. Mercedes is happily married and the mother of two unmarried sons. She lives in Manta's 11 de Noviembre neighborhood in her own home. She has equipped an area of her house as a shoe store. She has been in this line of work for 5 years; she loves it and has no plans to go into any other type of work. Her sales are to neighbors and she offers them comfortable payment plans so her customers visit her in her house and choose from the wide variety she offers. To keep her store stocked, she travels periodically to Guayaquil to buy from distributors so that her profits will be better. Her main product is Colombian shoes because they are of high quality and what her customers ask for. When she travels to get more merchandise, her sister stays in charge of the store. Mercedes is asking for new financing to buy casual and sport shoes for this season which is the most important where sales volume is concerned. Her goal is to continue to work with wholesalers in order to get the best profits and continue to expand her business without failing to repay the loan which Fundación Espoir is granting.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy footwear for women, men and children for the Christmas season.

loans.name: Rosa Esther

texts.es:
Rosa Esther  es socia D. Banco Comunal Picoaza,este  banco está conformado por mujeres  de diferetnes  edades.  Picoaza es un pueblito ubicado a diez  minutos al norte de Portoviejo en la provincia de Manabí en la costa de Ecuador, ésta  provincia es  muy  conocida por su gastronomía, las playas y los ceibos (arboles únicos de la región) y ésta localidad no podía ser la excepción pues es un lugar muy comercial, aquí  encontramos muchos  distribuidores de productos agrícolas,  consumo, ropa, etc.

Rosa vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos de 19, 16 y 7 años en su vivienda propia ubicada en la Avenida Kennedy en el centro de la comunidad de Picoaza, su cónyuge es ayudante de albañilería  
 
Nuestra socia es dueña de una tienda de ropa para damas, caballeros y niños vende vestidos, blusas, medias, pantalones, etc. que los adquiere en varios mercados de Guayaquil para vender en su localidad, en Portoviejo y otras ciudades de Manabí.

A  Rosa le gusta trabajar con  la  Fundación ESPOIR  por los múltiples  beneficios  como el emergente (en casos de emergencia) y por la facilidad de pago  de los créditos (quincenal).  También por la capacitación donde aprende conjuntamente con su hija sobre educación familiar y otros temas.

El crédito solicitado lo usará para incrementar su negocio comprando  mercadería surtida para damas, caballeros y niños como pantalones, blusas, camisetas, calcetines, interiores   para la temporada navideña.
texts.en:
Rosa Esther is a member of the Picoaza communal bank whose members are women of different ages. Picoaza is a little town located about ten minutes north of Portoviejo in Manabí province on Ecuador's coast. This province is very well knows for its gastronomy, its beaches and the ceibo tree (the striking green giant Ceiba trichastandra) which are unique to the region. This place is no exception for there are many distributors of agricultural products, clothing, consumption, etc. Rosa lives with her husband and their three children: 19, 16 and 7 years old, in their own home on Kennedy Avenue in downtown Picoaza. Her husband is a masonry helper. She owns a clothing store where she sells clothing for women, men and children: dresses, blouses, hosiery, pants, etc., that she gets from various markets in Guayaquil to resell in her locality, in Portoviejo and in other cities in Manabí. Rosa likes to work with Fundación ESPOIR because of the many benefits, like the emergency fund (for emergencies) and the ease of payment schedules (every two weeks). She also likes the training sessions where she, together with her daughter, learns about family education and other subjects. The financing requested will be used to buy merchandise for women, men and children like pants, blouses, t-shirts, socks, underwear, for the Christmas season.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pants, blouses, t-shirts, socks, underwear for women, men and children.

loans.name: Folake

texts.en: Folake is 40 years old and married with two children. Her husband is a journalist. She sells groceries and drinks to earn a living. She is a hard working woman. She hopes to own a supermarket in the future. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Déglo Tétédé Victoire

texts.fr: D. Déglo Tétédé Victoire est née en 1974 à Louho à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Victoire vit dans ce quartier depuis sa naissance. Mariée à ZOUNMENOU Emmanuel un ferrailleur, Victoire est mère de trois enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. Mais seulement un enfant est à leur charge. Victoire vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Victoire n’a pas été à l’école ; elle a appris et exerce la coiffure depuis près de 10 ans. Victoire vend également des produits pour cheveux (défrisants, pommades et huile pour cheveux, mèches, etc.) et également des cartes de recharges téléphoniques dans son atelier. C’est à Ouando à Porto-Novo que Victoire s’approvisionne. Victoire a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé et qui ont été bien remboursés. Victoire sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’accroître la taille de son activité pour mieux faire face aux besoins de ses clients.
texts.en:
D. Déglo Tétédé Victoire was born in 1974 in Louho in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She has been living in this district since birth. Married to ZOUNMENOU Emmanuel, a scrap metal merchant, she is the mother of three children. The children are all in school. But only one is in their care. Victoire works in aid of her husband to support the family. Victoire did not attend school. She learned hairstyling and has been working in this trade for almost ten years. She also sells hair products (straightener, ointments, oils, hair extensions, etc.), as well as mobile phone recharge cards, in her salon. She gets her supplies in Ouando in Porto-Novo. She has already benefited from two loans from ALIDé that were repaid. She's requesting a third loan from ALIDé, in order to augment her working capital and to expand her business, so as to cope better with the needs of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Boxes of hair extensions and hair products, and phone cards

loans.name: El Cruce Hacia El Futuro (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal El Cruce, se encuentra en el barrio del Cruce, perteneciente a la parroquia  de Sinincay en la ciudad de Cuenca, Sinincay se encuentra al noroeste de la ciudad, sus atractivos turísticos son su Templo Colonia, el Cerro de Cabagana, la Laguna de Pizarro, etc., sus habitantes han aprovechado los recursos de la naturaleza como son los yacimientos de arcillosos que son la materia prima para la fabricación de teja y ladrillo, su gente es cálida siempre quieren salir en adelante y buscan la mejor manera de trabajar para darles un futuro mejor a su familia.

La Sra. Elsa M. es socia del banco comunal El Cruce, perteneciente a la parroquia de Sinincay, tiene 45 años de edad, se encuentra divorciada hace 16 años tomando la decisión porque su esposo viajo al extranjero para darles un mejor futuro pero jamás regreso, ha procreado 4 hijos de 27, 25, 23 y 14 años de edad, su primer y tercer hijo se encuentran casados y uno de ellos aun vive en su casa ayudando económicamente, su segundo hijo trabaja y le ayuda en su casa, su ultima hija estudia en el colegio Ciudad de Cuenca, fruto del esfuerzo de su trabaja a podido construir su casa.

Elsa tiene un negocio de venta de almuerzos, lleva trabajando 2 años vende en la comunidad y también cuenta con una clientela trabaja desde muy temprano para poder tener su producto listo al medio día, tiene una gran amistad con todas las compañeras del banco comunal, se encuentra en el ciclo 14 trabajando con su bankito y nos comenta que le han ayudado mucho para superase con su familia y en su negocio, con el nuevo préstamo que le entrega la FUNDACIÓN ESPOIR, va a invertir en su negocio comprando productos para la elaboración de sus almuerzos, su meta es  llegar a tener una tienda de víveres en su casa. 

La Sra. Rosa P. es socia del banco comunal El Cruce, vive en la comunidad del Cruce del Carmen, perteneciente a la parroquia de Sinincay, tiene 42 años de edad, se encuentra casada y ha procreado 6 hijos de 27, 25, 21, 13, 12 y 3 años de edad, su primara hija se encuentra casada y vive independientemente, su segundo y tercer hijo trabajan y le ayudan económicamente, su cuarta hija estudia en el colegio Ecuador, su quinto hijo estudia en el colegio Monsalve Pozo, su esposo trabaja en la construcción, siendo merecido el esfuerzo de varios años de trabajo han logrado construir su casa propia.

Rosa trabaja desde hace 2 meses en el bar del colegio Monsalve Pozo y nos comenta que le va  bien, tiene una gran amistad con todas sus compañeras del banco comunal, se encuentra en el ciclo 14 trabajando con los prestamos de la fundación y comenta le han beneficiado en la superación de su hogar, con el nuevo préstamo que la FUNDACIÓN ESPOIR, le hace entrega va a invertir en su hogar, su meta es de llegar a arreglar mejor a su casa.

La Sra. Gladys Ullaguari es socia del banco comunal El Cruce, vive en el barrio Santa Ana del Cruce que es perteneciente a la parroquia de Sinincay, tiene 57 años de edad, se encuentra casada y ha procreado 7 hijos de quienes no se acuerda las edades, sus cuatro primeros hijos se encuentran casados tres de ellos viven independientemente, solo una hija casada vive en su casa pero aparte, dos de sus hijos estudian en el CECAP, un hijo trabaja y le ayuda para el pago de agua y luz, su esposo trabaja en la construcción, con el esfuerzo de muchos años de trabajo han logrado construir su casa propia aunque nos comenta que es pequeña pero muy cálida.

Gladys trabaja en su negocio vendiendo frutas, tiene un puesto propio en el mercado, lleva trabajando en su negocio hace 2 años y nos dice  que hay semanas buenas y malas pero siempre hay una pequeña ganancia para llevar el pan a su hogar, su horario de trabajo es de 8 a.m. a 5 p.m., tiene una gran amistad con todas sus compañeras del bankito, se encuentra en el cuarto ciclo y nos comenta que los prestamos le han beneficiado en su negocio, con el nuevo préstamo que la FUNDACION ESPOIR, le entregará va a invertir en su negocio y para ayudar a su familia, su meta es de llegar a arreglar su casa.
texts.en:
The communal bank, "El Cruce" is located in the neighborhood of El Cruce, which belongs to the parish of Sinincay in the city of Cuenca. Sinincay is in the northeast part of the city. Its tourist attractions are the Colonial Temple, the Cabagana hill, the Pizarro lagoon, etc. It's inhabitants have made the most of the natural resources here like the clay deposits that are the raw material for making tile and bricks. The people here are warm and always wnat to get ahead and look for the best way of working to give their families a better future.

Señora Elsa M. is a member of the communal bank, "El Cruce," which belongs to the Sinincay parish. She is 45 and has been divorced for 16 years. She made this decision because her husband traveled abroad to give them a better future and never came back. She has 4 children who are 27, 25, 23, and 14. Her first and third sons are married and one of them still lives in her home and helps her financially. Her second son works and helps her at home. Her youngest daughter goes to the high school in the city of Cuenca. As a fruit of her labor, she has been able to build her home.

Elsa has a business selling lunches, and she has sold them for 2 years in her community. She also has a clientele and works starting very early to be able to have her lunches ready at noon. She has great friendships with all of the members of her communal bank. They are on their 14th loan, and she tells us that it has helped them get ahead with their families and their businesses. With the new loan that Fundación Espoir is offering her, she will invest in her business by buying products to make her lunches. Her goal is to start a grocery store in her home.

Señora Rosa P. is a member of the communal bank, "El Cruce," and lives in the community called Cruce del Carmen. It belongs to the parish of Sinincay. She is 42; married; and has 6 kids who are 27, 25, 21, 13, 12, and 3. Her first daughter is married and lives independently. Her second and third sons work and help her financially. Her fourth daughter studies at Ecuador high school. Her fifth son studies at the Monsalve Pozo high school. Her husband works in construction, and because of his years of hard work, they have managed to build their own home.

Rosa has worked for two years at the snack bar of the Monsalve Pozo high school, and she tells us that it is going well for her. She has a great friendship with all of the members of her commmunal bank. They are on their 14th laon and she tells us that it has helped her improve her home. With this new loan from Fundación Espoir, she will invest in her home. Her goal is to make some repairs to her home.

Señora Gladys Ullaguari is a member of the communal bank, "El Cruce" and lives in the Santa Ana del Cruce neighborhood, which belongs to the Sinincay parish. She is 57, married, and has 7 children whose ages she doesn't remember. Her first four children are married and three of them live independently. Only one of her married daughters lives in her house but she lives in a separate area. Two of her children study at CECAP, and one son works to help her pay the water and light bill. Her husband works in construction. Through many years of work, they have managed to build their own home. She tells us that it is small but very warm.

Gladys has a business where she works selling fruit. She has her own stand in a market. She has done this for 2 years, and she tells us that there are good weeks and bad weeks, but there is always a little profit so she can take food to her home. Her work schedule is from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. She has a great friendship with all of the members of her bank. This is her fourth loan, and she tells us that her loans have benefitted her business. With this new loan from Fundación Espoir, she will invest in her business to help her family. Her goal is to make some repairs to her home.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, oil, meat, apples, oranges, and food in general

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is 42 years old and married with six children. She is a hard working woman and she hopes to excel in her business. She sells iced fish at retail prices to her customers. She hawks her iced fish within her community in Ibadan, Oyo State. She has been in this business for a long time. She hopes for a loan of 50,000 NGN to purchase more iced fish to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more iced fish to sell

loans.name: Clara Naida

texts.es:
La socia CLARA NAIDA pertenece al banco comunal “HATUN SONCCO”. El nombre del banco comunal es de origen del idioma Quechua, “HATUN” significa “Grande” y “SONCCO” significa “Corazón” que traducido al español significa “Corazón grande”. ( please click here Quechua)

La socia tiene 48 años de edad, es casada, tiene tres hijos varones, la socia esta sacando adelante a su familia haciendo estudiar a sus tres hijos en la universidad, ellos viven en la ciudad Imperial del Cusco. La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el pequeño negocio de venta de productos de belleza. Ya son varios años con esta actividad y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo, nuestra socia es una mujer luchadora y emprendedora pues con mucha voluntad se dedica al negocio y piensa en aumentar su capital de negocio comprando más productos de belleza como aretes, collares, y perfumes para estas fiestas navideñas y venderlas aun precio cómodo. 
 
La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Clara Naida is a member of the Communal Bank “Hatun Soncco”, which means “Big Heart” in the Quecha language. She is 48 years old, married, and the mother of three sons. Clara lives in the imperial city of Cusco and strives to support her family and help with her children’s university expenses.

She divides her time between her household activities and her small business selling beauty products. Clara has been engaged in this line of work for many years and has done very well thanks to all of her hard work. She is a strong-willed, enterprising woman who is dedicated to her business. Clara wishes to increase her business capital so that she can buy more beauty products such as earrings, necklaces, and perfumes for the Christmas festivities. She plans to sell them at affordable prices.

Clara is grateful for the opportunity provided to her and promises to complete her payments on the respective due dates.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her inventory of beauty products for the Christmas season

loans.name: Hidayatou Akankê

texts.fr: A. Hidayatou Akankê est née le 23 Juin 1978 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Hidayatou Akankê vit depuis près de 20 ans au quartier Tokpota à Porto-Novo. C’est une célibataire avec trois enfants à charge. Tous ses enfants sont scolarisés. Hidayatou Akankê vit seule avec ses enfants, et supporte seule les charges de la famille. Hidayatou Akankê n’a pas été à l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Hidayatou Akankê vend depuis près de cinq ans, des fournitures d’électricité à Tokpota à Porto-Novo. C’est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, que Hidayatou Akankê fait ses approvisionnements. Hidayatou Akankê a obtenu une fois de crédit à ALIDé, crédit qu’elle a bien remboursé. C’est dans l’optique d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’agrandir son activité, pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, que Hidayatou Akankê sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
A. Hidayatou Akankê was born on June 23, 1978 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin.  For nearly 20 years, she has been living in the Tokpota district in Porto-Novo.  She is unmarried and has three children to support.  All of the children are in school.  She lives alone with her children and is the only one supporting the family.  Hidayatou Akankê did not go to school.  To provide for herself and her children, she has been selling electrical supplies for five years in Tokpota in Porto-Novo.  She gets her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She once obtained an ALIDé loan, which she has repaid.  With regard to augmenting her working capital and expanding her business, in order to make her customers happier, she's requesting a second loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Electrical supplies and equipment

loans.name: Marie Madeleine

texts.fr: B. Marie Madeleine est née en 1965 à Dangbo, non loin de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à DOSSOU Mondji un chauffeur,  Marie Madeleine est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Marie Madeleine vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari à Djègan-kpèvi à Porto-Novo, depuis près de 6 ans. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Marie Madeleine n’a fréquenté que le cours primaire. Pour se prendre en charge et satisfaire aux besoins de ses enfants, Marie Madeleine vend depuis environs 4 ans, des gâteaux d’arachides (fait à base d’arachide et du sucre) à son domicile et aussi de façon ambulante. Marie Madeleine mène comme activité secondaire, la vente de maïs. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à Bohicon dans le Zou au Bénin, que Marie Madeleine s’approvisionne. Marie Madeleine a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Marie Madeleine sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de l’institution, afin d’agrandir davantage son activité et de mieux faire face aux besoins de la clientèle.
texts.en:
Marie-Madeleine B. was born in 1965 in Dangbo, not far from Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She is married to Mondji DOSSOU, a driver. Marie-Madeleine is the mother of four children, all in school. Marie-Madeleine has lived with her children and her husband in Djègan-Kpèvi in Porto-Novo for the last six years. The couple together takes care of the family’s expenses.

Marie-Madeleine only attended elementary school. In order to take care of herself, and to meet the needs of her children, Marie-Madeleine has been selling peanut cakes (made from peanuts and sugar) for the last four years. She sells from her home and door-to-door. As a second activity Marie-Madeleine sells corn.

Marie-Madeleine gets her goods from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and in Bohicom in the Zou County of Benin. Marie-Madeleine has already received two loans from ALIDé, which have been fully repaid. Marie-Madeleine is requesting a third loan from the institution in order to increase her activity and to better meet her customers’ needs.


Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sugar and baskets of peanuts.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella is 40 years old and married with five children. She is a hard working woman. Her children are doing well in their trade and school. She sells colorful sarongs at retail prices to her customers. This is the high season for sales and she hopes to meet the demands of her customer. She hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more cosmetics and hair extensions to sell

loans.name: Purity

texts.en: Purity is a single lady with two children aged 8 years and 5 years, respectively. In order to raise her family, she sells baby/children's clothes by the roadside. She has done this business for the last five years. She started her business by borrowing KES 20,000, which she has paid successfully. Her business is currently booming and she is requesting a loan of KES 50,000 to buy more baby clothes. Her major challenge is the location of her business, which is not very safe and provides no shelter. Her dream is to be financially stable and be able to move to a better house with her children. In five years time, she wants to open a boutique and venture into the shoe business. She describes herself as a hardworking woman.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita is 30 years old and married with two children. She sells used clothes. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. This is the high season for her business and she hopes to make more profits. The demand for her used clothes is high by those in her community that cannot afford new clothes. She hopes for a loan amount of 80,000 NGN to purchase more used clothes to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Eugénie Déli

texts.fr: D. Eugénie Déli est née en 1958 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à ZINSOU Antoine, un chauffeur, Eugénie Déli est mère de trois enfants. Eugénie Déli a en plus de ses enfants, un autre enfant à charge. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés et vivent ensemble avec leurs parents au quartier Djègan-Kpèvi à Porto-Novo. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Eugénie Déli n’a fait que le cours primaire. Depuis près de 20 ans, Eugénie Déli vend de la nourriture (riz, haricot, akassa : aliment local fait à base d’amidon de maïs) et également de la farine de manioc à son domicile. C’est au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo que Eugénie Déli s’approvisionne. Eugénie Déli a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. C’est afin d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et accroître son activité pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, que Eugénie Déli sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
D. Eugénie Déli was born in 1958 in  Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin.  Married to ZINSOU Antoine, a driver, she is the mother of three children.  In addition to these, she has another child in her care.  All of the children are in school and live together with their parents in the Djègan-Kpèvi district in Porto-Novo.  The couple provides for the family jointly.  Eugénie Déli attended primary school only.  For nearly 20 years, she has been selling food (rice, beans, and akassa: a local food made with corn starch) and also cassava flour, out of her home.  She gets her supplies at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo.   She has already had two ALIDé loans, which were repaid.  To augment her working capital and to expand her business, so as to satisfy her customers further, she's requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sacks of rice and beans, sauce condiments, cassava flour

loans.name: Mathilde Sica

texts.fr: G. Mathilde Sica est née en 1954 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mathilde Sica réside à Djassin à Porto-Novo depuis environs 17 ans. Mariée à GUENDEHOU Bernard, un douanier, Mathilde Sica est mère d’un enfant qui est scolarisé. Mathilde Sica vit ensemble avec son enfant et son mari. Mathilde Sica vient en aide à son mari dans les charges de la famille. Mathilde Sica a été à l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire. Depuis 8 ans, Mathilde Sica vend des tissus à son domicile et aussi de façon ambulante. C’est à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin, que Mathilde Sica s’approvisionne. C’est la première fois que Mathilde Sica sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’agrandir son activité, pour mieux satisfaire la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de la clientèle en cette période de préparation des fêtes de fin d’année.
texts.en:
G. Mathilde Sica was born in 1954 in  Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin.  She has been residing in Djassin in Porto-Novo for about seventeen years.  Married to GUENDEHOU Bernard, a customs agent, she is the mother of one child who is in school.  She lives together with her child and husband.   She works in aid of her husband to support the family.  Mathilde Sica attended primary school only.  For eight years, she has been selling cloth out of her home and also door-to-door.  She gets her supplies in Lomé in Togo, a country neighboring Benin.  This is the first time that she has requested a loan from ALIDé in order to augment her working capital and to expand her business.  She can then satisfy the burgeoning customer demand during the preparations for this year-end holiday period. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bolts of cloth (Bazins, Vlisco, Hitarget, etc.)

loans.name: Noemi

texts.es:
La socia NOEMI pertenece al banco comunal “HATUN SONCCO”. El nombre del banco comunal es de origen del idioma Quechua, “HATUN” significa “Grande” y “SONCCO” significa “Corazón” que traducido al español significa “Corazón grande”. ( please click here Quechua)

La socia tiene 22 años de edad, es conviviente, en sus brazos tiene a su hijo que tiene un año de nacido y ellos viven en la ciudad Imperial del Cusco. La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con el pequeño negocio de venta de papas y verduras que lo trae de la ciudad de Abancay del departamento de Apuricma. Ya son dos años y medio con esta actividad y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo, nuestra socia es una mujer joven, luchadora y emprendedora pues con mucha voluntad se dedica al negocio y piensa en aumentar su capital de negocio comprando más verdura y papas.  
 
La socia se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
NOEMI, 22, is a member of the "HATUN SONCCO" communal bank. The name of the bank is from the Quechua language. "HATUN" means "Big" and "SONCCO" means "Heart" so, translated into Spanish, it means "Big Heart." She lives with her life partner and carries their son, who is a year old, in her arms. They live in the imperial city of Cusco. She alternates her household chores with a small vegetable and potato selling business. She brings the merchandise from the city of Abancay, Apuricma department. She has had this line of work for the last two-and-a-half years and has done very well thanks to all the effort she puts into it. She is a young, hard-working, enterprising woman who, with much dedication, sees to her business and intends to increase her working capital buying more vegetables and potatoes. She is grateful for the opportunity this means offers her and pledges to repay in a timely fashion.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vegetables and potatoes.

loans.name: Marina

texts.es:
La señora Marina, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Shatojinas Laboriosas”, Distrito de Shatoja, Provincia de San José de Sisa, Departamento de San Martín. Es casada, tiene 56 años y es madre de 08 hijos, todos ya independientes.

Ante la necesidad de aportar al ingreso económico del hogar, motivada por ella misma, emprendió un pequeño  negocio de venta de abarrotes con un capital de S/. 300.00 obteniendo muy buenos resultados desde un inicio por la calidad de sus productos, sus precios cómodos y la buena atención al cliente. En la actualidad continua con el mismo negocio ubicada en su propia casa, donde sus principales clientes son los vecinos de su barrio.

Con este préstamo de S/. 1,500.00, comprará  más productos para surtir su negocio como arroz y azúcar en kilos, huevos en javas,  insumos para el aseo personal y limpieza del hogar, gaseosas en paquetes, golosinas  y otros productos para mantener contenta a su clientela.

Hoy se siente muy feliz de la labor y servicio que brinda y agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos, por apoyar a personas como ella que quieren trabajar y salir adelante, espera que sigan así por mucho tiempo y ayuden a muchas familias y mujeres emprendedoras.
texts.en:
Marina belongs to the Shatojinas Laboriosas Communal Bank in the Shatoja district, San José de Sisa province, San Martín department. She is 56, married, and has eight children who are now independent. Facing the necessity of supporting the household and being self-motivated, she started a small business of selling groceries. She started it with 300 PEN, and she has gotten results from the beginning because of the quality of her products, the reasonable prices, and the good attention she gives to the customers. She currently continues with the same business, which is located in her own house. Her main customers are her neighbors. She will use this loan for 1,500 PEN to stock her business and buy more products like kilos of rice and sugar, crates of eggs, personal hygiene products, household cleaners, packs of soft drinks, sweets, and other products to keep her customers happy. She now feels very happy about the work and service that the Manuela Ramos Movement offers. She is grateful to them for supporting people like her who want to work and get ahead. She hopes they continue this way for a long time and help many families and enterprising women.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy groceries to increase her products

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en: Vincent sells medicine to earn a living in Benin City, Edo state.  He is 51 years old and married with four children. His wife sells foodstuffs to support the family. He has been in this business for a long time. He is requesting a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more medicine to sell. He hopes to own a maternity home in the future. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine to sell

loans.name: Edelmith

texts.es:
La señora Edelmith, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Shatojinas Laboriosas”, Distrito Shatoja, Provincia del Dorado, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 26 años y es madre de 02 hijos, los 02 que aun dependen de ella.

Edelmith, por iniciativa propia con  su primer crédito de S/. 300.00 emprendió su negocio de venta de leña, ubicada en un ambiente muy bien acondicionado, al fondo de su casa. Lleva 01 año en el negocio y pese a eso hoy en la actualidad cuenta con una clientela ya fidelizada que a diario acuden a su casa, donde ella los atiende con el carisma y la amabilidad que le caracteriza. Con este préstamo de S/. 800.00, comprará leña en tercios y en cantidades.

Se siente aun con mucha fortaleza para continuar trabajando y seguir adelante y asegurarse una  vejez tranquila. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  con el cumplimiento de sus sueños y metas.
texts.en:
Edelmith belongs to the Shatojina Laboriosas Communal Bank in the Shatoja district, Dorado province, San Martín department. She is 26, married, and has two children who are still dependent upon her. On her own initiative, Edelmith used her first loan for 300 PEN to start her business of selling firewood. It is located in a very well equipped area in the back of her house. She has been in this business for one year. She currently has loyal customers who come to her house daily. She tends to them with her characteristic charisma and kindness. She will use this loan for 800 PEN to buy firewood by the “tercio” (100 pounds). She still feels she has lots of strength to continue working and to get ahead to assure herself of a tranquil old age. She is grateful to the Manuela Ramos Movement for contributing to the fulfillment of her dreams and goals.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy firewood by the "tercio" (100 pounds)

loans.name: Macaulay

texts.en: Macaulay sells frozen foods at retail and wholesale prices to his customers. He is a hard working man and he hopes to lift his business and family above poverty. This is the high season for his business and he hopes to make more profit. He is 44 years old, and married with five children. His wife sells sarongs to support the family. He hopes for a loan of 100,000 NGN to purchase more frozen foods to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Fatimata

texts.fr: P. Fatimata est née en 1961 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Fatimata vit depuis environs 30 ans à Djèrègbé, sur la route de Porto-Novo. Mariée à KIKI Nicodème, un mécanicien, Fatimata est mère de deux enfants. Un parmi les deux enfants est scolarisé. Les deux enfants vivent ensemble avec leurs parents. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Fatimata n’a pas été à l’école. Il y a de cela 10 ans que Fatimata mène comme activité, la vente d’ustensiles de cuisine (bols en séries, glacières, plastiques, bassines, casseroles, assiettes en séries, etc.) à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est au Nigéria, Etat voisin du Bénin que Fatimata s’approvisionne. Fatimata a obtenu déjà, deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. En vue d’augmenter son fonds de roulement et d’agrandir davantage sa marchandise, pour mieux écouler ses produits en période de fêtes de fin d’année, Fatimata sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
P. Fatimata was born in 1961 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin.  She has been living for about thirty years in Djèrègbé, on the road to Porto-Novo.  Married to KIKI Nicodème, a mechanic, she is the mother of two children.  One of them is in school.  The two children live together with their parents.  The couple supports the family jointly.  Fatimata did not go to school.  For ten years, she has been running a business selling kitchen utensils (nested bowls, insulated containers, plastic ware, tubs, pots and pans, nested dishes and plates, etc.) at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin.  She supplies herself from Nigeria, a country neighboring Benin.  She has already obtained two loans from ALIDé and has repaid them.  With the aim of augmenting her working capital and to expand her inventory further, in order to sell more goods during this year-end holiday period, she's requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Kitchen utensils (bowls, nested dishes, coolers)

loans.name: Luzgarda

texts.es:
