loans.name: Rizalito

texts.en:
Rizalito D. is from the village of Tagdo, Mambajao Camiguin Province. He is 40 years old. Rizalito is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Rizalito owns and operates a business venture in the service sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing a coconut grinding service in the local community. Rizalito has been engaged in his business for over 13 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rizalito joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rizalito successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to invest in expanding the business. Rizalito is requesting a new loan of 11000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Rizalito from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of his children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria C. is a simple and loving woman to her husband and children as well as to her fellow poor women in their community inside and outside KIVA's field partner in the Philippines, ASHI. Maria has been dreaming of nothing more than giving her children a better kind of living and supporting her group members and center members in ASHI alleviate their poverty. Living up to these personal expectations gives her courage to bear paying the interest rate required by ASHI for every loan she requests and attending the weekly center meetings.

Maria is also determined to grow her business and profits to be able to meet the demands of her family, which includes five children, whose ages range from three to 15. Maria wants to earn enough business profit, in addition to her husband’s sporadic income being a farm laborer, that she will be able to support the education of her children until they graduate from college.

The opportunity ASHI offers for poor women to access loans for a business is Maria’s key to achieving her dreams in life, and people around the world wanting to support her endeavor gives her reason to hold on to her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase cattle to raise

loans.name: Ramona

texts.en:
31-year-old Ramona E. is requesting a loan through ASHI to buy cattle to raise and breed. Through this business, she can maximize the wide, verdant land in her backyard and profit from it. She also wants to support her previous and ongoing business, which is manufacturing “nipa” (a leaf of a palm) as a native roofing material through her loan. Proceeds of this business supply Ramona and her family with their daily basic needs. Her husband is a just a laborer and his income is too small for Ramona and her three children to depend on.

With the all of her problems at home brought about by poverty, Ramona’s membership in ASHI had helped her in so many ways aside from having access to loans. The camaraderie she had found from among her co-members in ASHI has diverted her disappointments to happiness. She found herself laughing at problems and later on realized laughter was a very good solution for them. Despite the many adversities she has encountered, Ramona has remained strong and determined to achieve her dreams for her three children, who are aged from eight to 12 years old.

loans.use: To purchase cattle to raise and to finance her nipa manufacturing business

loans.name: Zaida

texts.en:
Zaida is a dressmaker. She skillfully tailors dresses for her customers in much the same way that she way she tailored gaps in her life because of poverty. Since there is no way to turn back time, Zaida wanted to start building a life for their two children, who are aged from 13 to 16 years old, that is different from the ones she and her husband had in the past.

While Zaida is a tailor, her 41-year-old husband is a small-time photographer who also at times drives a motorcycle (one of the common means of transportation in their village). As Zaida intends to do in her tailoring, her husband wants not to just capture the special moments of his customers and carefully bring them to their desired destinations, but he also wants their children to taste the best offerings of life and to be able to reach their own dreams someday. Zaida feels very blessed having a husband and children that are very supportive and loving. With that, she courageously took the risk in growing her business and has gotten larger loans through ASHI.

With the loan Zaida is requesting now, she wants to put up her own dress shop and purchase a large volume of textiles needed for her business. She is not only the one that is excited to see her business growing; her husband and two children are exited too. Proceeds from this business will be Zaida’s means to support the education of her children until graduation from college.

loans.use: To start her own dress shop

loans.name: Rita

texts.en:
Since the death of her husband a long time ago, Rita D. faces life’s challenges brought about by poverty alone, working to enable her two children to survive. Now she is 55 years of age and still facing a lot of adversities in life that sometimes makes her weak. However, the thought of her children having low educational attainment and less opportunity to get a good employment enables her to regain strength to continue fighting and win the battle against poverty. Her eldest child is 31 years old and has an income from driving a tricycle (a motorcycle with a sidecar that is used as people’s means of transportation), which Rita bought using a previous loan; her younger child is 27 years old and a waiter.

Still, Rita wants to have her own business and help her children. She hopes that her business of fattening cattle (a cow can be sold for as much double its price after two to three years) will grow and becomes sustainable someday through loans she can obtain from ASHI with the support of its partner, Kiva. Rita knew that, because she is poor, her children have nothing to inherit when her life is over, but having a sustainable business for them to manage and continue will enable them to be more secure in their own lives.

loans.use: To purchase two cows to raise and sell

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

texts.en:
M. Nguyễn Thị (10102130025) is a 40-year-old female living in the town of Đông Anh - Hà Nội. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. To making a living, M. operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. M. has been engaged in this business for over 2 years and earns approximately 2.000.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2006, M. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. M. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,452,000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. M. is now requesting a new loan of 5,450,000 VND, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. The loan will be the fifth loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA. M. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

M. Nguyễn Thị (10102130025) là 40 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Đông Anh - Hà Nội. Cô ấy đã lập gia đình và có 2 trẻ ở độ tuổi đi học. Để kiếm sống, M. Tham gia công việc kinh doanh của gia đình. Công việc kinh doanh hoạt động tại lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi heo để bán. M. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 2 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, M. kiếm được khoảng 2.000.000 VND một tháng.

Vào 2006, M. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. M. đề nghị khoản vay lần đầu tiên từ SEDA. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.450.000 VND. Khoản vay hiện tại sẽ được sử dụng để mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này. Khoản vay sẽ là 5th khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA. M. dự định sẽ sử dụng nguồn thu nhập bổ sung từ công việc kinh doanh cải thiện điều kiện sống chung của gia đình người vay.

Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam

*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva. ."

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita C. is a 52-year-old single woman who lives in Pinagkamaligan, Tanay Rizal. She blessed with two sons and two daughters. The eldest is 20 years old and youngest is 8 years old. Two of her children are in college students and the rest are in elementary grades.

Lolita has been in the business of buying and selling jewelry and accessories for almost 10 years now, since she received her first loan from ASHI, which amounted to Php 5,000. Now, Lolita wishes to apply for her 8th loan from ASHI, amounting to Php 20,000, to be used in the same business. With the bigger loan, the volume of commodities she will sell will be increased and she can help many people from her village have access to commodities with less effort and time.

Lolita is very optimistic that she will be able to manage her business well and have it grow. She hopes to provide a better education for her children. All of these children she has right now are just a couple of adopting from her nearest relatives. As a single old woman, she believes that there will be nobody to take care of her when she becomes very old unless she has money; that’s why she still makes great effort to seek opportunities to have savings for her old age.

loans.use: To purchase silver rings, necklaces, bracelets, watches, and other accessories

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị

texts.en:
X. Nguyễn Thị (10102130026) is a 44-year-old female living in the town of Đông Anh - Hà nội. She is married and has 2 school-aged children. To making a living, X. operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising fish for sale. X. has been engaged in this business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2.000.000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2004, X. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. X. successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,876,000 VND from SEDA. This previous loan was used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. X. is now requesting a new loan of 5,014,000 VND, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future. The loan will be the 8th loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA. X. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Rowena's Group

texts.en:
Rowena D. R. is a woman with the bravery and strength of mind to rise above poverty. She is 33 years old and the mother of two, both males; one is in high school and one is in grade school.  She lives in the active town of Tanay, in the Rizal province in the Philippines. She is married to Ariel, who is 38 years old and a driver.

Rowena came to her mind of joining ASHI for the dreams and a bridge to support her in her business.  She needed to work and look for a living to support the needs of her children because the business became the main source of income and she receives good income for their future savings in case of emergency. She also earns extra income from her pedicure and manicure business. In 2006; she decided to join ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. During her membership in ASHI, she was noted for her excellent performance in terms of responding to her responsibilities in the organization.

Now Rowena is requesting a loan of Php20,000 pesos as additional capital for her business. Specifically, the amount will be used to pay for  perfumes, towels, underwear for men and women, blouses, jeans, t-shirts, shoes, bags, slippers, and many others similar items. She has regular customers and she also receives and accepts orders.

Rowena hopes to send her children to school until they finish college and find the finest jobs. She also hopes to expand her business and be able to have more stock. She also dreams of having her own AVON Dealer outlet and to have own house and lot.  She even aspires to having a space in the market.

loans.use: To purchase Avon products to grow her business

loans.name: Arceli

texts.en:
Arceli F. is a 69-year-old woman from the mountainous town of Jala-jala, in Rizal Province, in the Philippines. She is a loving mother of two children. The eldest, Genalyn, is 27 years old and a college graduate. Her daughter, Ayumilyn, is 6 years old and a nursery student. She is married to a driver, Reylan F..

For her loan, she is requesting Php 25,000 pesos as additional capital to buy and sell rice. This loan is one big help for her business, enabling her to gain more profits to be able to have future saving and provide the needs of the family.

In 2003, she joined ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and Kiva partner in the Philippines. She was full of determination to lift her family up from poverty. Now that she has gradually fulfilled her dreams, she hopes to have more capital to be able to access many markets in the nearby towns. She also wants to have a big store to retail or wholesale rice in their village to provide the needs of her fellow men. She desires that she extend help for her granddaughter to finish her studies until college, and like other families here in the Philippines, she also wants to have a comfortable house to live in.

loans.use: To purchase 16 cavans of rice worth Php 25,000.00 to expand her business

loans.name: Shukhrat

texts.ru: Шухрат Махмадиев проживает в городе Душанбе. Возраст 36 лет. Холост. Шухрат более 3 лет предоставляет услугу такси по городе Душанбе. Кредит просит для доплаты и ремонта автомашины, т.к. он еще не полностью выкупил автомашину. На полученную прибыль хочет сыграть свою свадьбу.
texts.en:
Shukhrat M. lives in the city of Dushanb. He is 36 years old and unmarried. Shukhrat has been working as a taxi driver in Dushanb for more than three years. He is asking for a loan to finance the payment and repairs of his car, because he has not yet made the car payments in full. He wishes to use the profits to plan his wedding.

Translated from Russian by Anastasia Uglova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Car payments and repairs

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a 47-year-old woman who is married with five children aged 15 to 21 years. All her children go to school. She resides and rents a two-room house where she is staying with three people. Mariam takes care of additional family members. The family has access to electricity and no piped water and gets three meals a day.

Mariam has a shop in Ndeeba selling second-hand clothes. Airtime also owns a pay phone. Mariam has been in this business for three years. She works in a semi-urban area on the outskirts of Kampala. She works six days a week and receives an average of 20 customers a day. She sells to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale. Miriam incurs transport costs to and from Owino Market, one of the busiest markets in Kampala, to buy second-hand clothes.

Miriam's major business challenges are the ever-increasing prices of used clothes and the rainy season, which hinders her customers from reach her because she works in a muddy place. Miriam has been with MCDT for eight years and is servicing her sixteenth loan She wants to use this loan to buy more second-hand clothes, cables and Airtime. She aspires to see her business grower bigger and start selling wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy used clothes and Airtime

loans.name: Leticia

texts.en:
Leticia S. is a woman who has a lot of confidence and is determined to rise above poverty. She is 40 years old and mother to 4 children. She is happily married to Edwin S., a welder who is 42 years old. She lives in a village in Palanas, Jala-jala, Rizal province in the Philippines.

For almost two years she has been in the rice business. The income is not sufficient to sustain the needs of her family, so she also has a sewing business to bring in additional income. With her desire to put poverty behind her, in 2007, Leticia decided to join ASHI (Ahon SA Hirap, Inc.), an MFI and KIVA partner in the Philippines. Leticia has a bagful of hope because she'll have access to capital for her business.

Now on her fourth loan, she is requesting Php 20,000 pesos to pay for 15 sacks of rice worth Php 22,500. She believes that her business is in demand and will bring her enough income to sustain their day-to-day expenses. She dreams of sending her younger children to school and to renovate her house so its more durable and spacious. She also wants to open a grocery store in the future.

loans.use: Expand her rice business

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther B. is from the village of Mailag, Valencia City. She is 49 years old, married, and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Esther is starting a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income comes primarily from selling both food and daily-use products to the local community.

In 2009, Esther joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Esther has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Esther is requesting a 2nd loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to purchase more products for her store. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: Purchase products to sell

loans.name: Valeriana

texts.en:
Valeriana C. is from the village of San Vicente Bajo, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Valeriana is married and has six school-aged children. To make a living, Valeriana owns and operates a "sari-sari" retail store, a type of variety store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Valeriana has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Valeriana joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Valeriana has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Valeriana is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Valeriana from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ma Joyce

texts.en:
Ma Joyce F. is from the village of Puntod Lopez Jaena, Misamis Occidental. She is 34 years old. Ma Joyce is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Ma Joyce owns and operates a business venture in the agricultural sector raising pigs. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling pigs in the local community. Ma Joyce has been engaged in her business for more than 20 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Ma Joyce joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma Joyce has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,500 PHP from GDMPC. Ma Joyce is requesting a new loan of 3,500 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional piglets for sale. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Ma Joyce from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

loans.use: to purchase additional piglets for sale

loans.name: Jitume Group

texts.en:
Hadija S., age 36, is married with 4 children, ages 16, 14, 12, and 3 years old. She has a small charcoal stall and clothes shop. She opened the business in 2008 and works long daily hours from 8 am until 8 pm. By selling charcoal and clothes she is able to earn a monthly profit of around $410.

This will be Hadija’s 2nd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loan to expand the charcoal business and open the clothes business. She paid back her first loan successfully. She hopes to purchase additional stock for her charcoal business with this 2nd loan.
\t
Hadija will share this loan with her group of 25 members, who keep each other accountable for paying back the loan. In the picture, Hadija is standing in the center and right of the picture, wearing a yellow t-shirt.

loans.use: Purchase more charcoal

loans.name: Genelyn

texts.en:
Genelyn E. is from the village of Mailag, Valencia City. She is 28 years old. Genelyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Genelyn owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for sale. Genelyn has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Genelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Genelyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase young livestock to raise and sell in the future. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

To make a living, Minda owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Minda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie A. is from the village of Taboc Sur, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 20 years old. Tessie is single. To make a living, Tessie owns and operates a retail business selling personal products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling cosmetics product such as shampoo, soap, lotion, make-up, lipstick, etc., in the local community. Tessie has been engaged in her business for more than a year and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Tessie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Tessie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. Tessie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Tessie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

loans.name: Nathaniela

texts.en:
Nathaniela E. is from the village of Mailag, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 56 years old. Nathaniela is married and has 6 school-aged children. To make a living, Nathaniela owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling Ready to Wear items and cosmetics in the local community. Nathaniela has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Nathaniela joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nathaniela has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business. loans.name: Frederick

texts.en: Frederick O. O., 26, has recently returned home from Nairobi to Mombassa to raise cattle and chickens.  He sells milk and eggs to local hotels, restaurants and individuals in Bamfuri.  He has two employees and struggles with feed issues during the hot season.  He is using his KES 30,000 loan to expand into chickens to sell as broilers.  He would ultimately like to expand his business and have 10 cows and grow their feed himself.  Frederick is as yet unmarried and his goal is to have a happy family.  He describes himself as a happy man who works hard and is a good businessman.

loans.use: An expansion into chickens to sell as broilers

loans.name: Azizi Group

texts.en:
Irene M., age 43, is single with three children aged 13, 15 and 20 years.  She has a kiosk business where she has been selling water, soda and beer since 1992 and works daily from 10am until 10pm. She is able to earn a monthly profit of around $185.

This will be Irene’s 5th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to increase stock and to buy more umbrellas for shade and has paid back the loan successfully. She hopes for a loan to further increase her stock, but this time she asked for a smaller loan amount because she has moved to a new place with new customers.
	
Irene will share this loan with her loan group, Aziz, which totals 15 members. The members of the group hold each other accountable in paying back the loan.  In the picture, Irene is seated and is wearing a pink blouse and a dark scarf.

loans.use: To increase stock of beer, soda and water.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary Z. is a 47-year-old single mother of one child. She lives in Mshomoroni in Mombasa and owns a retail shop in the same area. She sells an assortment of cereals and household products and has been in business for two years.

Mary joined KADET recently after getting information from a friend and is now borrowing her first loan. She plans to increase the stock of maize, beans and peas in her shop in order to meet the demand of her customers. 

Mary hopes that she will be able to buy a piece of land soon and put up a permanent residential house and business premise.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase cereals.

loans.name: Majida

texts.en: Majida is a 48-year-old married woman with five children. Since 2001, she has been working in clothes sales to earn income for her family. Today, Majida is applying for a loan of $800 USD to buy more merchandise for her shop in order to increase her sales and income.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise

loans.name: Isdorah

texts.en:
Isdorah O. is married to Jacob Olila, and they are blessed with three school-going children. The family lives in Mombasa's Bamburi estate where Isdorah operates a greengrocery shop. She has been in the grocery business for the last four years. Her customers are mainly the households around her business.
Isdorah was introduced to Kiva partner KADET by a friend, and she is now accessing her first loan to finance her business. She plans to increase her stock of vegetables and also purchase some cereals in order to maximize her profits.
In the future Isdorah hopes to own a bigger and better grocery store and to diversify her business by opening a café. We wish Isdorah well as she embarks on achieving this dream.

About KADET
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To purchase vegetables and cereals

loans.name: Fatmeh

texts.en: Fatmeh is a 53-year-old married woman and the mother of five children. She has been working as a tailor since 1984. Her many years of experience have led her to becoming well known in her town, where she provides products such as clothes, chair covers, tablecloths, and so on. Today, Fatmeh is asking for a loan of $800 USD to buy a sewing machine.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Jaafar

texts.en: Jaafar is a 45-year-old married man with four children. He has owned a cafeteria for the past six years. Today, Jaafar is requesting to borrow $1,200 USD to increase his inventory in order to augment his sales and offer a variety of products to his customers.

loans.use: To increase his inventory

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah is a 38-year-old married mother of three children. She lives in Mombasa, in the town of Majaoni. Her husband, Francis, is a businessman in Mombasa.
For the last nine years, Deborah has been in the business of selling second-hand clothes in Majaoni. Her main customers are the families in the Majaoni area and passers-by. Deborah is borrowing her first loan from Kiva partner KADET, and plans to purchase two more bails of second-hand clothes, commonly known as "mitumba". She hopes that, one day, she will own a large clothes store and be able to employ several workers.

loans.name: Hanane

texts.en: Hanane is a 33-year-old single woman who lives with her parents. She has been a farmer since 1999. Today, Hanane is requesting a loan of $1,200 USD to buy additional tools for her job in order to produce more products and buy more agricultural foodstuffs.

loans.use: To buy additional tools

loans.name: Elda

texts.en:
Elda R. is from the village of Mailag, Valencia, Bukidnon. She is 46 years old. Elda is married and has 5 adult-aged children. To make a living, Elda owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Elda has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Elda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Elda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.name: Hayel

texts.en:
Hayel is a single 30-year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, Southern Lebanon. Hayel is newly engaged and is planning to get married very soon. Hayel is a car electrician who owns a garage; he also has been selling car accessories for nine years.

Hayel requested a loan from A. Majmoua in order to buy more car accessories to increase his income. Hayel has been a micro-credit client for two years now and has always repaid on time. His clients are those who own a car. Competition was one of the problems he faced but his experience is different from others. He plans to improve and expand his work in the future.

loans.use: To buy more car accessories to sell.

loans.name: Afif

texts.en: Afif is a 50 year-old man who lives in Nabatieh, southern Lebanon, with his wife and their three children.  For the last ten years, Afif has been a taxi driver. loans.name: Badenya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Badenya sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 27 ans et 1 enfant. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Konobougou, sous préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de commerce. Elles font le commerce d’articles divers et collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt solidaire avec l’institution et comptent l’utiliser pour acheter, des condiments alimentaires et  une grande quantité d’articles divers. 
Les produits sont achetés en grande partie à Bamako, mais les céréales sont achetées sur place et toutes les marchandises sont revendues sur place, au marché et au bord du goudron à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles estiment pouvoir  réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 25 000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices seront partagés entre autres la nourriture,  la santé et les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Badenya are married women averaging 27 years of age and one child each.  They live with their husband and children in large traditional families residing in the village of Konobougou, Sub-prefecture of Barouéli, Region of Ségou, Republic of Mali.  The group members know one another through ties of community and commerce.  They do commerce in a variety of goods and are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in want of continual financial support for their businesses.  They are on their first solidarity loan with this institution and intend to use it to buy some condiments and a large quantity of various goods. The products are purchased mainly in Bamako, but the grains are purchased locally.  All the goods are sold locally to customers composed of women and men at the market and along the asphalt. The group members think they can each realize an average profit of 25,000 francs CFA per month.  The profits will be spread among such things as food, health care, and the businesses.  

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy various items

loans.name: Deogracia

texts.en:
Deogracia L. is from the village of Campo 1, Aurora, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 44 years-old. Deogracia is widowed and has two adult children. Deogracia owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap and toothpaste in the local community. Deogracia has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Deogracia joined Kiva partner GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Deogracia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Deogracia is requesting a new loan of 3,000 PHP which will be used for the same purpose. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Deogracia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
With a passion for arts is our featured entrepreneur, Mrs. Jocelyn D.. She is 36 years of age, is married and is a resident of P1 Garang, Tangub City. Her husband, Bienvinido D., is the one who makes the designs and carves every furniture product they make. Jocelyn assists her husband in polishing and doing some varnish spraying work.

They started this business ten years ago and now they are earning an average net income of not less than Php 10,000 from the sales of their finished products.

Jocelyn joined Paglaum MPC just this year because she is very much interested in our products and services and for our being one of the most outstanding cooperatives in Northern Mindanao and for being awarded “Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines” during the search for the COOP-LGU Partnership Award 2006.

Jocelyn is given the privilege of obtaining a loan of Php 15,000 with the purpose of purchasing furniture materials and accessories. The future income from this loan will be used for supporting their basic needs and to save for the future for her two minor dependent children.

loans.use: To purchase furniture materials and accessories

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 38 ans et 2 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Konobougou, sous préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à des liens de voisinage et de commerce. Elles font le  commerce d’articles divers et collaborent  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe et le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé. 
Quant à l’utilisation du nouveau prêt, elles  comptent acheter,   une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires et d’arachide. L’arachide sera transformée en pâte. L’arachide est acheté sur place et dans les villages environnants, les condiments alimentaires sont achetés en gros à Bamako et le tout  est revendus sur place au marché et au bord du goudron à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 22 000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices seront utilisés pour la nourriture, la santé et  les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Benkadi are married women who average 38 years of age and 2 children each.  With their husband and children, they live in large traditional families residing in the village of Konobougou, Sub-prefecture of Barouéli, Region of Ségou, Republic of Mali.  The group members know one another through ties of community and commerce.  They do commerce in a variety of goods and are collaborating with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in want of continual financial support for their businesses.  They are on their second group loan.  The preceding one was properly repaid.  As for the use of the new loan, they intend to buy a large quantity of condiments and peanuts.  The peanuts, to be processed into peanut butter, are purchased locally and in surrounding villages.  The condiments are purchased wholesale in Bamako.  Everything is sold locally to customers composed of women and men at the market and along the asphalt.   The members of the group each hope to realize an average monthly profit of 22,000 francs CFA that will be used for food, health care, and the businesses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments and peanuts

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi de l’association Benkola sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 27 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Konobougou, sous préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et de commerce. Elles font le petit commerce d’articles divers. Elles collaborent  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur troisième prêt solidaire et tous les prêts précédents  ont été correctement remboursés. 
Ce nouveau prêt servira à  acheter,  une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires, d’habillements et de produits cosmétiques. Les articles sont achetés en gros à Bamako et le tout  est revendu sur place au marché et au bord du goudron à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles espèrent  réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 35 000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont partagés entre  la nourriture, la santé et les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi group of the Benkola association are married women who are, on average, 27 years and have three children. They live with their husbands and children in large traditional families in the village of Konobougou, located in the district of Barouéli, in the region of Ségou, in the Republic of Mali. These women are known among neighbors and clients. They are all active in selling a variety of materials, and collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to constantly have financial support for their activities. They are currently on their third group loan and correctly reimbursed the two previous loans. This new loan serves to purchase a large quantity of food products, clothes and cosmetics that are purchased in Bamako and re-sold at the open air markets to a clientele composed of both women and men. They are hoping to each earn an average profit of 35,000 FCFA [approximately 80 USD] per month, which then go to paying for food, health and other activities.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a variety of materials/products

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en: Leonora C. is from the municipality of Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old, is married, and has two school-aged children. In 2008, Leonora joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from PMPC. Leonora is now requesting a new loan of 14,900 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials. This loan will be her third from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. Shown in the photo with Leonora is her husband, who helps in the business, and their child. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

Elles se sont connues à des liens de voisinage et de commerce et font le commerce d’articles divers.

Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire et le premier prêt a été bien remboursé. 
Ce prêt servira à acheter,  une grande quantité de condiments alimentaires et de céréales. Les condiments sont achetés en gros à Bamako, les céréales sont achetées sur place et dans les villages environnants et le tout  est revendu sur place au marché et au bord du goudron à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 30 000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont partagés entre  la nourriture, la santé et les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi group of the association Démé are married women who are on average 34 years old and have two children. They live with their husbands and children in large traditional families in the village of Konobougou, in the district of Barouéli, Region of Ségou, Republic of Mali. They are well known both as neighbors and for working in retail selling various articles. They collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to ensure ongoing financial support for their activities. They are currently on their second group loan and reimbursed the first one on time. This loan will allow them to purchase bulk quantities of food condiments and cereals/grains. The condiments are purchased in bulk in Bamako, the cereals/grains are purchased on site or in surrounding villages and both are re-sold at the open air markets or on the side of the road to a clientele composed of both women and men. They hope to each make a profit of approximately 30,000 FCFA [approximately 69 USD] per month, which will go towards purchasing food, health products and other activities.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing condiments and cereals/grains

loans.name: Gertulde

texts.en:
Gertulde is 42 years old and is married with five children between the ages of 6 and 16. She lives in the Gicumbi district of Rwanda, in Northern Province, approximately an hour-long drive from Kigali city.

Gertulde has worked with livestock for five years and knows how to manage her business well. She employs five people to help her care for her milk-producing cows (only one of which is shown in the photo). 

Gertulde is requesting her first loan from Vision Finance Company and Kiva lenders in order to plant herbs for her cows and buy needed supplies. If this strategy is successful, her business will be able to produce much more milk which will increase her monthly sales dramatically.

Any profits resulting from this loan will be reinvested in her business and also allow Gertulde to feed her children more and better food.

loans.use: To purchase herbs and feed for her cows as well as supplies

loans.name: Florie

texts.en:
Florie M. is from the village of San Carlos, Valencia City, Bukidnon. She is 37 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Florie owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Florie has been engaged in her business for over nine years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month from these activities.
In 2009, Florie joined Kiva partner HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Florie is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her first from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.en: Bernadette is a married woman and the mother of two children. She works as a beautician providing beauty services to the ladies in her town. Today, Bernadette is asking for a loan of $1,200 to buy a laser machine in order provide this service to her clients.

loans.use: buy a laser machine

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 28 ans et 3 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Konobougou, sous préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à des liens de voisinage et de commerce et font le commerce d’articles en vue de prendre en charge certaines dépenses de leur famille. 
Ces femmes viennent de commencer leur collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso et cela dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur premier prêt solidaire et comptent l’utiliser pour acheter, des fruits, légumes et  une grande quantité de céréales pour la restauration. 
Les produits sont achetés sur place et  dans les villages environnants et sont revendus sur au marché et au bord du goudron à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 20 000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices seront partagés entre  la nourriture,  la santé et  les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the group Danaya are married women who are on average 28 years old and have three children. They live with their husbands and children in large traditional families in the village of Konovougou, district of Barouéli, region of Ségou, Republic of Mali. They met through being neighbors as well as a shared interest in retail. They sell various products in order to take care of certain spending needs of their families. They women just began to collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to have a constant financial support for their activities. They are on their first group loan and will use it to purchase fruits, vegetables and a large quantity of cereals/grains for restaurants. These products are purchased on site and in surrounding villages and are re-sold a the market or on the side of the road to a clientele composed of both women and men. They hope to each make a monthly profit of approximately 20,000 FCFA [approximately 45 USD] that will be spent on food, health products and other activities.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fruits, vegetables and cereals/grains

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is an 18-year-old young man living with his parents. In 2008, he decided to open his own business, a speciA. Lebanese food shop, after 3 years of experience in this field. Today, Hassan is applying for a loan of $1,200 to buy equipment and dishes to attract more clients to his shop.

loans.use: buy equipments and dishes

loans.name: Youssef

texts.en: Youssef is a 49-year-married man and the father of 3 children. He has owned a car painting shop since 1995, which provides enough income to provide for his family. After years in the business, Youssef is requesting to borrow $1,000 to renovate his shop and his tools in order to attract more clients and increase his income.

loans.use: renovate his shop and his tools

loans.name: Marcelina

texts.en:
Marcelina A. is from the village of San Carlos, Valencia City. She is 41 years old. Marcelina is married and has 3 adult-aged children. To make a living, Marcelina owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling food and daily use products in the local community. Marcelina has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Marcelina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marcelina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Marcelina's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional supplies of ingredients in bulk for her café.

loans.name: Deme Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Démé sont des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne  d’âge de 50 ans et 2 enfants. Avec leur mari et enfants elles vivent  dans des grandes familles traditionnelles et  résident dans le village de Konobougou, sous préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou, République du Mali. 
Elles se sont connues à des liens de voisinage et de commerce. Elles font le commerce d’articles divers et collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le souci d’avoir constamment un appui financier pour leurs activités. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de groupe et le prêt précédent a été correctement remboursé. 
Ce  nouveau prêt servira à acheter, des condiments alimentaires et  une grande quantité d’articles divers tels que les produits manufacturés. 
Les produits sont achetés en grande partie à Bamako et sont revendus sur place, au marché et au bord du goudron à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.  
Elles espèrent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen de 25 000FCFA  par mois. Les bénéfices sont partagés entre  la nourriture, la santé et  les activités.
texts.en:
The members of the Démé group are women with an average age of 50 years and two children. They live with their husbands and children in large traditional families in the village of Konobougou, in the district of Barouéli, in the region of Ségou, in the Republic of Mali. They met each other through being neighbors and sharing a common interest in retail. They sell a variety of materials/products and collaborate with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to ensure constant financial support for their activities. They are currently on their second group loan, the first of which was correctly reimbursed. This new loan will allow them to purchase food condiments and a large quantity of diverse articles such as manufactured productions. These products are largely purchase din Bamako and re-sold at the open air markets and on the side of the road to a clientele of both women and men. They hope to each make a monthly profit of approximately 25,000 FCFA [approximately 57 USD], which would be used to purchase food, health products and towards other activities.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a variety of products

loans.name: Samir

texts.en: Samir has been working as a taxi driver since 2004. He is married and the father of 4 children who are still in school. He works hard to make money for  his family. Today, Samir is applying for a loan of $1,000 to purchase fabric for the van and perform maintenance.

loans.use: purchase fabric for the van and perform maintenance

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya sont au nombre de huit femmes dont une célibataire et 7 mariées, majoritairement  dans des familles polygames. Elles ont  en moyenne  31 ans, 2 enfants et habitent dans  le quartier  Médine de la ville de Ségou  (4ème Région administrative  de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des activités de  commerce qu’elles mènent dans le même marché de Médine, à la même place de vente, habitent le même quartier et sont toutes membres d’une  association traditionnelle d’entraide.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les trois prêts précédents, elles sont à leur 4ème   de prêt  solidaire avec Soro Yiriwaso. 
Ce prêt servira à acheter, 6 sacs de gros oignons frais, 18 seaux de pâte d’arachide, 6 grandes  boites de concentrée de tomate, 5kg de poivre, 4 paquets de divers cubes maggi, 30 paniers de poissons frais essentiellement constitués de silures, 24litres d’huile alimentaires,  4sacs de riz et 10 colis de calebasses. 
Elles s’approvisionnent  dans les différents marchés de Ségou, à la foire de Kolongo, et de Tona. La vente se fait généralement dans les marchés,  en ambulant dans les quartiers,   au comptant et  à crédit  à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes. 
Elles  espèrent réaliser un bénéfice  moyen mensuel  de 31.875FCFA  qui servira à rembourser les prêts, à acheter des fournitures scolaires, à payer les coopératives scolaires et à participer aux événements sociaux.
texts.en:
The members of the group Danaya are eight women, seven of whom are married and one of whom is single, and are for the majority in polygamous families. They are on average 31 years old and have two children. They live in the Médine area of the city of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They met through a shared interest in retail activities that they each carry out in the same area of the Médine market and also live in the same area and are all members of a traditional association of mutual aid. After have correctly reimbursed the previous three loans, they are currently on their fourth group loan from Soro Yiriwaso. This loan enables them to purchase 6 bags of large, fresh onions, 18 buckets of ground nut paste, 6 large boxes of tomato concentrate, 5 kilos of pepper, 4 packets of diverse bouillon cubes of the brand name Maggi, 30 baskets of fresh fish [mostly brown bullhead fish], 24 liters of cooking oil, 4 bags of rice and 10 packages of calabash. They stock up in the various markets in Ségou and at the fairs in Kolongo and Tona. They generally re-sell the products in markets as well as traveling sales persons in neighborhoods to a clientele of both women and men. They hope to each make a monthly profit of 31,875 FCFA [approximately 73 USD] which would serve to pay back loans, to purchase education materials, to pay school co-operatives and to take part in social events.

Translated from French by Chloe Tuot, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a variety of activities

loans.name: C3756 Abahujwenimana Group

texts.en:
Marie Rose is 29 years old and is married with three children with ages 1, 6 and 8. In addition, she takes care of one dependent from another family who is 16 years old. Marie Rose lives in Nyarugenge, a region of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.

Marie Rose is the president of a group called Abahujwenimana. This is the group's second successful year in the business of selling fruits and vegetables. The hours of their business require that they work from early in the morning until late in the evening, depending upon customer traffic on any given day.

The members of this group, after having the idea of improving their business and increasing their sales, are requesting their first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. With this loan, these members plan to carefully source and then purchase a larger quantity of vegetables and fruits hopefully at lower prices. The group believes this will satisfy the needs of their customers and result in more profit for Abahujwenimana.

With this profit, they will reinvest in their business so that in the future, loans are not necessary; they can rely on equity and cash on hand. Also, they all plan and hope to continue taking care of their families and loved ones.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits and vegetables for sale

loans.name: Kadia

texts.fr:
Madame  Kadia  Traoré  est âgée de 46 ans, mariée  et mère  de 6  enfants.  Elle  vit avec son mari et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle au quartier Darsalam de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fréquenté l’école pour des raisons familiales (refus catégorique de son père de l’envoyer à l’école), elle  commença très tôt  le commerce auprès de sa grande sœur qui vendait du gâteau. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage, elle finit par évoluer à son propre avec l’achat vente des condiments alimentaires, activité qu’elle mène depuis maintenant 30 ans et jouit d’une grande notoriété. Elle vend au marché de Médine. Sa place de vente est au cœur du marché, à coté des vendeurs de viandes. 
Dans le souci d’augmenter son bénéfice, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son 1er prêt individuel. 
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 10 sacs de gombo, 3 sacs de piments et 2 sacs de choux pommés. Elle s’approvisionne à Loulouni dans la région de Sikasso.
Madame Kadia  Traoré  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Avec ce prêt, elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 45 000FCFA. Ce bénéfice va lui permettre de satisfaire ses propres besoins (achat de savons, nourriture et habillement). 
Son ambition est de terminer ce prêt pour commencer un nouveau cycle.
texts.en:
Ms. Kadia Traoré is 46 years old, married, and has 6 children. She lives with her husband and their children in a large traditional household in the Darsalam area of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having been able go to school due to family reasons (the categorical refusal of her father to send her to school), she began engaging in commerce very early on with her elder sister, who sold cakes. After several years of training, she finished by developing her own business buying and selling food condiments, an activity that she has run for 30 years now, and which enjoys an excellent reputation. She sells her goods at the market in Médine. Her sales location is at the centre of the market, next to the meat sellers. With the goal of increasing her profits, she turned to Soro Yiriwaso (one of Kiva's field partners), with whom she is on her first individual loan. She intends to use this loan to buy 10 bags of okra, 3 bags of peppers, and 2 bags of head cabbage. She obtains her supplies in Loulouni in the Sikasso region. Ms. Kadia Traoré sells her goods in cash and on credit to a clientele composed of women and men. With this loan, she foresees realizing a monthly profit of 45,000 FCFA. This profit will allow her to take care of her needs (buying soap, food, and clothing). Her ambition is to repay this loan and start a new business cycle.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food condiments

loans.name: Makhmadlatif

texts.ru: Махмадлатиф Оев проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст 41 год. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Махмадлатиф более 8 лет занимается торговлей. Он имеет собственный магазин, в котором торгует хозяйственными товарами. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Mahmadlatif O. lives in the town of Vakhdat. He is 41 years old, married, with six children. Mahmadlatif has been a merchant for more than eight years. He has his own store in which he sells household goods. He is applying for a loan to increase the turnover of his merchandise.

Translated from Russian by Anastasia Uglova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase the turnover of his merchandise

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.fr: M. Bernadette est née le 20 Août 1958 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin.Bernadette vit au quartier Oganla à Porto-Novo, depuis une dizaine d'année. Mariée à DANDJINOU Armand, un instituteur à la retraite, Bernadette est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés,dont deux sont à sa charge. Bernadette vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Bernadette a fréquenté jusqu'au cours secondaire. Il y a environs deux ans que Bernadette vend des ustensiles de cuisine (glacières, plats en séries, verres à boire) par le système de distribution. C'est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, et au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo, que Bernadette s'approvisionne. Bernadette a obtenu une fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé, et a bien remboursé le crédit. En vue d'augmenter son fonds de roulement et d'agrandir sa marchandise pour mieux vendre ses articles en temps de fêtes, Bernadette sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Bernadette ambitionne ouvrir plus tard sa propre boutique pour vendre ses produits.
texts.en:
Bernadette M. was born on 20 August, 1958 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Bernadette has lived in the Oganla area of Porto-Novo for ten years. Married to Armand Dandjinou, a retired teacher, Bernadette is the mother of four children, all in school, of whom two are in her care. Bernadette lives together with her husband and children. Bernadette attended school up to the secondary level. For about two years, Bernadette has sold kitchenware (iceboxes, plate sets, drinking glasses) through the distribution system. It is in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, and at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo, that Bernadette gets her supplies. Bernadette has obtained one previous loan through ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), and repaid this loan properly. With the goal of increasing her working capital and expanding her merchandise to better sell her items during the holiday period, Bernadette is seeking a second loan through ALIDÉ. Bernadette aspires to open at some later time her own shop to sell her products.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy kitchenware (iceboxes, plate sets, and drinking glasses)

loans.name: Shukhrat

texts.ru: Шухрат Имамов проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст 31 год. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Шухрат более 2 лет занимается торговлей. Торгует он в собственном магазине, хозяственными товарами. Кредит просит для закупа нового ассортимента, т.е. увеличения товараоборота.
texts.en:
Shukhrat I. lives in the town of Vakhdat. He is 31 years old, married, with two children. Shukhrat has been a merchant for more than two years. He has his own store in which he sells household goods. He is asking for a loan to purchase a greater variety of goods and increase his merchandise turnover.

Translated from Russian by Anastasia Uglova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of goods for sale

loans.name: Glenda

texts.en:
Glenda, of Brgy. Mabini, Valladolid, Negros Occidentala, is a 51-year-old woman who prays to the Lord to give her strength, good health and long life to continue her business and help her family. Her husband is a farmer who plants different kinds of vegetables and manages their small rice farm. The couple has four adult children between 24 and 31 years old. Glenda strives hard in her business to not only support their household needs but also to be financially independent.

Glenda started her business in 2002 when she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to borrow capital to put up a general store adjacent to her house. As soon as her first loan was granted, she bought a variety of items and products to sell, and any extra income from the store is always used to buy more goods to sell. As her loans have continued, she has also helped her husband by buying fertilizers for his vegetables and rice farm. Glenda also sells her husband's vegetable harvest in the local market and in the neighboring villages. Her business is going well, earning an average income of Php 10,000 per month.

Her previous loan of Php 10,000, fully repaid without delay, was used as additional working capital for her general store. Because of her good credit performance, she can borrow a larger amount, and this time around she is borrowing Php 15,000 for her 14th cycle loan to be utilized as revolving working capital for her general store and to purchase additional fertilizer for their vegetable and rice farm. The income from this loan will be used for house repairs.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To buy new stocks for her general store and fertilizer for the vegetable and rice farm

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk for her grocery.

loans.name: Dustmurod

texts.ru: Дустмурод Чакалов проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст 31 год. Женат, детей не имеет. Дустмурод более 2 лет занимается бизнесом, торговлей. Он в основном торгует  хозяственными товарами, на рынке. Кредит просит для увеличения товараоборота. На полученную прибыль хочет закупить вещи для будущего ребенка.
texts.en:
Dustmurod C., 31, lives in the city of Vahdat. He's married and has no children. For more than two years Dustumrod has ran a business on the market, selling mostly household items. He is asking for a loan to increase his goods turnover. With the profit he wants to buy supplies for his future child.

Translated from Russian by Alex Kostrubsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase goods turnover

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase ingredients to make snacks for her business.

loans.name: Dorcas Wakwasa

texts.en: Dorcas M. is married to David and they have three children: Peterson, Gabriel and Leah. Dorcas was introduced to KADET through existing clients and she is servicing her second loan. She has been in the clothes business for nine years and she intends to use the loan to increase her stock of clothing materials and fabric in her shop. The business is situated in a market area which is highly frequented by local residents and passersby. With the extra profits Dorcas will purchase more clothes to expand the choice for her clients. Dorcas’s future hopes are to supply clothes in supermarkets within the town. She believes she is focused and hardworking. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve the living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: The loan will be used to increase her stock of clothing fabric

loans.name: C2321 Twitezimbere Group

texts.en:
Jacqueline is 35 years old and is married with five children with ages between 2 and 10 years. She is the president of a group called Twitezimbere. This group has owned a shop for the past three years selling a wide variety of goods. It is well known in the community and employs four people. The business is open every day from 7 a.m. to 5 p.m. 

After having operated successfully in business for three years, Jacqueline and her group are requesting their first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company. The loan proceeds will be used to expand their offerings through purchasing additional goods such as household items and a variety of foodstuffs such as sugar, beans, rice, etc.

The members of Twitezimbere hope that the new range of products will appeal to their current customers as well as attract new customers to their store. All of this should result in a greater profit for their enterprise. With this profit, the members of Twitezimbere will continue to pay school fees for their children and build a secure future for their families and loved ones.

loans.use: To buy additional goods, household items and foodstuffs

loans.name: Rafiatou

texts.fr: H. Rafiatou est née en 1964 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Rafiatou vit depuis une quinzaine d'année à Djèrègbé sur la route de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à VODOUNON Jean, un mécanicien, Rafiatou est mère de quatre enfants. Certains de ses enfants sont scolarisés. Rafiatou vit ensemble avec som mari et ses enfants à Djèrègbé. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Rafiatou n'a pas été à l'école. Rafiatou vend des tomates fraîches et des noix de palme à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C'est à Adja au Mono, que Rafiatou s'approvisonne. Rafiatou mène cette activité depuis cinq ans environs, et est à son troisième crédit à ALIDé. En effet, Rafiatou a obtenu antérieurement deux crédits à ALIDé, et qui ont été bien remboursés. C'est pour augmenter son fonds de roulement et mieux satisfaire ses clients, à travers ses produits, que Rafiatou sollicite ce troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Rafiatou H. was born in 1964 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Rafiatou has lived for fifteen years in Djèrègbé, on the road to Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Married to Jean Vodounon, a mechanic, Rafiatou is the mother of four children. Some of these children are in school. Rafiatou lives together with her husband and children in Djèrègbé. The couple provide for the family together. Rafiatou did not go to school. Rafiatou sells fresh tomatoes and palm nuts at Dantokpa, Benin's international market. It is in Adja, Mono, that Rafiatou obtains her supplies. Rafiatou has run this business for about five years, and is on her third loan through ALIDÉ (one of KIva's field partners). Indeed, Rafiatou has obtained two previous loans through ALIDÉ, which were repaid properly. It is to increase her working capital and better satisfy her customers through her goods that Rafiatou is seeking this third loan through ALIDÉ.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy baskets of tomatoes and palm nuts

loans.name: Banana Bush Group

texts.en:
David K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called “Banana Bush”. He is 34 years old and is married with four children aged 7-20 years old. He is a high school graduate but could not continue to university due to lack of financial support. David and his family lives in Gbartala community, twenty kilometers from Gbarnga city, the capital of Bong county, Liberia.

David’s business is the sale of general goods. He buys general goods wholesale and sells at retail to residents of community. He has been running this business for five years and is hoping to improve his business to establish a shop.

David talks to customers with a good manner in order to encourage them to continue buying from him. He faces a problem with the bad road conditions when transporting goods from Gbarnga city to Gbatala.

David needs this loan to purchase new goods to be added to his business. He dreams of giving his family a better education to enable them to have a good future.

loans.use: To purchase new goods to be added to his business

loans.name: Julenne

texts.fr: Mariée et mère de 03 enfants, cette femme a commencé depuis 2005 le commerce de pagnes. Elle est très dynamique et fait son commerce de façon ambulante. La période des fêtes approche, elle veut augmenter son stock, c’est pour cette raison qu’elle sollicite de WAGES un prêt pour acheter une trentaine de pagnes de grande qualité et de qualité moyenne.
texts.en:
Married with 3 children, this woman began selling pagnes (a type of brightly-printed West African cloth) in 2005. She is very dynamic and runs her business door-to-door. With the holiday season approaching, she wants to increase her stock; it is for this reason that she is seeking a loan through WAGES (one of Kiva's field partners) to buy thirty pagnes of high and medium quality.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy pagnes (a type of West African cloth)

loans.name: Alphonse Wambua

texts.en:
Alphonse M. is married to Sera and they have two children, Elizabeth and Geoffrey.

The client was introduced to KADET through existing clients and has no previous credit history. Alphonse will use the loan to increase his stock of second-hand salon car tires. The area of the business is situated within the estates and has many customers. Alphonse will use the profits to expand the business and educate his children.

The client hopes to have a shop of new car tires, as he believes he is focused and determined.

About KADET:
