Eduardo, 54, has been an active worker with Nicaragua's fire brigade for the past 7 years. He is gratified that he is able to serve society and all those whom he can help. He lives with his wife, who is a street vendor of sweets. She produces enough income to meet basic utility costs like water and electricity. They have two sons; one who works for the army and the other who is a secondary school student, whom his father expects to help as much as possible. With this financing he wants to finish building his house which still needs a roof and windows. He will buy these materials to continue with construction so as to be able to enjoy a more proper dwelling. All this is thanks to the long-term, low-interest financing that benefits many Nicaraguan families allowing them to have homes.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy zinc metal sheeting, metal roof sheeting, doors and windows.

loans.name: Aïssa

texts.fr: Madame Aissa M. est une monitrice dans une garderie d'enfant ,elle est âgée de 48 ans et mariée .Pour arrondir sa mensualité elle exerce une activité de vente de produits cosmétiques et de parfumerie.Le but du prêt consiste en l'acquisition de nouvelles gammes très convoitées pour le revendre dans les maisons en faisant du porte à porte. ainsi elle pourra arrondir ses revenus et aider son mari dans la ration familiale
texts.en:
Mrs. Aïssa M. is a monitor in a day-care center. She is 48 years old and married. To supplement her monthly income, she sells cosmetics and perfume. She will use her loan to purchase whole ranges of new products which are in high demand. She will sell them hawking from house to house. Thus she can supplement her income and help her husband with the family expenses.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen her business

loans.name: Francisco Manuel

texts.es: Don Manuel se dedica a la compra y venta de metales reciclables, desde hace cuatro años, anteriormente su negocio era la venta de frutas y verduras ambulante en su camioneta el cual lo hizo durante quince años, decidió cambiar sus venta debido a que muchos perdía por que las verduras abecés se podrían al no venderse en el tiempo adecuado por las venta bajas y eso le generaban perdidas. Tiene 47años de edad  casado con cinco hijos  dos trabajan y tres estudian para una buena educación. Su esposa lo apoya con el negocio ya que en su casa mantiene  chatarra que llegan a comprar. Con este financiamiento es comprar hierro, cobre, bronce, aluminio el cual compra a un precio y revende a otro todo estos producto los compra a personas que ya no lo necesitan, la mas veces anda en una barata en cada barrio comprando el hierro por libra. Este negocio lo inicio debido a la buena demanda que se ha dado. Da las gracias a la institución por lograr poder incrementar sus ventas el cual le generara muchas utilidades al comprar por mayor.
texts.en:
For the past four years Manuel has been buying and selling recyclable metals. Before that he was as a traveling salesman selling fruit and vegetables from his pickup truck He worked in that business for fifteen years but decided to change because there were big losses if he couldn’t sell enough in the slow times, resulting in a lot of spoilage. He is 47, married, with five children: two work and three are in school so that they can receive a good education. His wife helps him at home where she sells scrap metal to customers who come to the house. With this loan he will buy iron, copper, bronze and aluminum for resale. People who buy these products already need them, but he usually goes around different neighborhoods buying iron by the pound. He started this business because of the demand. He thanks the institution for allowing him to succeed improving his sales, giving him the opportunity to buy in quantity.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy quantities of  iron, copper, bronze, aluminum for resale

loans.name: María De Jesús

texts.es:
La señora María De Jesús M. tiene ya más de dos años dedicándose a la elaboración y venta de manteles y servilletas echas a mano. 
Este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de su familia ya que es madre soltera y tiene una hija bajo su responsabilidad a quien le quiere dar lo mejor.
Solicita el préstamo para poder comprar material para elaboración de los manteles ya que tiene varios pedidos de manteles navideños, pero en este momento no cuenta con el dinero necesario para poder comprar el material y elaborar los pedidos y entregarlos a tiempo. 
Planea pagar el crédito con una parte de las ganancias de negocio.
texts.en:
Señora María De Jesús M. has made and sold hand-made tablecloths and napkins for more than two years. This business is the source of income for her family since she is a single mother and is responsible for her daughter to whom she wants to give the best. She is requesting a loan to be able to buy materials to make tablecloths since she has several orders for Chrismas tablecloths. Right now she doesn't have the money she needs to be able to buy the material to finish the orders and deliver them on time. She plans to pay for the credit with part of her profits from her business.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials to make tablecloths

loans.name: Juana Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Juana J. de 47 años de edad, es una mujer trabajadora que ofreces sus productos ambulantes a empresas, vecinos y da al crédito de la quincena vende ropa, zapatos, prendas de plata, el cual trabaja por catálogos de la Avon. Ocho años lleva en las ventas, cuando inicio lo hico con dinero que su hermana presto con bajos intereses. Luego para vender mas comenzó hacer préstamos en Afodenic  el cual ha invertido más y sus clientes han aumentado. Su casa es sencilla mitad de concreto y mitad de tabla poco a poco ha ido haciendo cambio. Con el préstamo anterior hico un muro en frente para poder estar un poco mas segura de la delincuencia. Tiene tres hijos dos casados y uno que estudia, ha pasado por difíciles situaciones tuvo una perdida de su mercadería por robo y quedo descapitalizada, hasta se atraso con los pago de la institución. Pero gracias a Dios logre superarme y seguido con mis ventas. Con este crédito comprare ropa variada, prendas, perfumenes y poder lograr colocar sus productos en esta temporada y cubrir sus pagos y poder sastifacer sus necesidades personales. Como apoyar a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Juana J., 47 years old, is a hard working woman who offers her products by visiting businesses and neighbors. She gives her customers credit for two-week periods. She sells clothes, shoes, and silver jewelry from Avon catalogs. Juana has been doing this for 8 years. She began with money that her sister loaned her at low interest rates. Later, to increase sales she began to borrow at AFODENIC, increasing her investments and her customer base.

Her house is simple, half concrete and half boards. Little by little, she has been making changes. With the last loan she built a wall in front in order to be a little safer from delinquency.

Juana has 3 children; 2 are married and one is still in school. She has passed through difficult situations, including one loss of merchandise by robbery which left her without capital, and caused her to fall behind in her payments to the village bank. But thanks to God, she was able to recover and continue with her sales.

With this loan, she will buy a variety of clothes, jewelry, and perfume, adjusting her products to the season, as well as cover payments, and satisfy personal needs, such as helping her children.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: TO BUY A VARIETY OF CLOTHES, COSMETICS, AND PERFUME TO SELL

loans.name: Marta Lorena

texts.es: La señora Marta Lorena es una mujer trabajadora, su negocio es la venta de ropa variada, cosméticos, que administra desde hace seis años, cuando inicio lo hizo con ahorros que su esposo daba, luego para invertir mas hizo prestamos para comprar al mayor. Ha pasado por situaciones difíciles pues su esposo murió y tuvo muchos gastos en lo de su entierro lo cual las ventas se vinieron abajo, poco inventario lo que ha sido difícil. Tiene 54 años de edad, procreo dos hijos los cuales han sido de mucho apoyo en mi vida los dos trabajan como cadete de taxi me ayudan. Sus planes es poder seguir invirtiendo y comprar mucho producto que llame la atención  a sus clientes, ella da crédito a sus clientes mas viejos de trabajar con ella.  Lo difícil es cuando no pagan en tiempo y forma y tiene ella que cubrir sus pagos. Con este préstamo quiere invertir en la compra de ropa, cosméticos, para cumplir con la demanda de encargos de sus clientas como la captación de clientes nuevos. Da las gracias a la institución por hacer posible este inversión en su negocio lo cual espera lograr nivelarse para poder saldar sus deudas.
texts.en:
Marta Lorena, 54, is a hard-working woman; she has sold assorted clothing and cosmetics for the past 6 years. She began her business using savings she got from her husband and later sought financing in order to buy stock at wholesale. She has had many difficulties because her husband died and the funeral expenses were high. Sales dropped and inventory was low. It has been very difficult. She has two sons who have been a great help to her in her life; they both work as taxi drivers. Her plan is to continue to invest by buying a lot of merchandise that will attract the attention of customers; she is grateful to her long-time customers for sticking with her. What is difficult is when they don't pay her on time and she has to cover her own costs. With this loan she will buy clothing and cosmetics both to satisfy her standing orders and to attract new customers. She thanks the institution for making this investment in her business possible and she hopes to break even and pay off her debts.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothes and cosmetics.

loans.name: Anta Mbaye

texts.fr: Madame Anta Mbaye F. est mariée et âgée de 56 ans c'est une aide infirmière en retraite qui travaille dans la confection et vente de draps pour être revendu dans le marché . ce prêt entre dans le renforcement de ses activités de production  et d'accroissement de son affaire et de sa rentabilité
texts.en:
Mrs. Anta Mbaye F. is married and 56 years old. She is a retired nurse who is now active in the clothing and bedclothes business at the market. She will use this loan to bolster her production activity and increase her turnover and profitability.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth

loans.name: Susana Del Carmen

texts.es: Doña Susana Castellón ha sido una mujer de pocos recursos económicos desde su juventud ha trabajado para apoyar a sus padres, luego que se caso ha tenido que trabajar para lograr tener sus propia casa. Procreo tres hijos que ha podido mantenerlos como madre soltera por que su matrimonio no resulto como muchas familias. Lo más difícil que ha trabajado como domestica donde hace mucho quehaceres por poco salario y a veces muchas humillaciones. Tiene 59 años de edad, vive en un barrio de Managua Laureles Sur, ella logro poco a poco hacer su casa pero es sencilla parte de madera en mal estado, es por eso quiere comprar materiales de construcción para comenzar a mejorar las partes malas como cambiar el techo de su casa que se moja en temporada de invierno, también el cerco lo tiene caído y por falta de dinero no lo ha reparado. Sus mejoras han sido mediante el financiamiento por que paga poco a poco y a si puede hacer las mejoras por que tiene que cubrir las necesidades de su alimentación como medicina ya que ni  asegurada. Da las gracias Afodenic por el pollo de poder hacer posible los cambios de su casa.
texts.en:
Susana Castellón, 59, has never had much money; from a very early age she worked to support her parents. Once married, she has worked to have her own home. She had three children and has had to support them alone because, like happens in so many families, she is a single mother. The hardest work she's done is as a domestic where salaries are very low, work is very hard, and one is subject to many humiliations. She lives in Managua's Laureles Sur neighborhood. Little by little she managed to build her house, which is very unassuming, partly made of wood that is in very poor shape. She wants to buy building materials so that she can start to improve the worst parts like the roof which needs to be replaced because in Winter it leaks. Also, her fence has fallen and, because of lack of funds, she has been unable to repair it. The improvements she has made have been thanks to the financing which she can repay bit by bit. This allows her to make improvements and still be able to pay for basic needs like food and medicine (she's not insured). She thanks Afodenic for making her home improvements possible.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy zinc metal sheeting to replace her roof and the fence.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.es: Imelda tiene 74 años de edad, no es el primer financiamiento que ha solicitado, por lo que se preocupo por recoger el dinero para realizar el pago de las cuotas. La actividad económica es la venta de ropa usada. Hace más de 3 años que se dedica a este negocio, con su propio esfuerzo y con los financiamientos ha logrado invertir en lo necesario de su negocio para obtener más clientes y nuevos productos. Ella solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de pantalones, ciertas camisas y algunos vestidos ya que se acercan temporadas festivas y tiene ciertos clientes que le solicitan este tipo de ropa porque no tienen el suficiente dinero para ofrecer más, esta es una ventaja que ella tiene pues les ofrece a sus clientes lo que necesita. Esta señora tiene muchos sueños y siempre piensa es su negocio y tener un lugar para ofrecer sus productos.
texts.en:
Imelda, 74, has sold second-hand clothing for the past 3 years. Thanks to her own efforts and financing she has succeeded in investing enough to get more customers and new products. She requests this financing to buy pants, certains shirts and some dresses since the Christmas holidays are approaching and she has customers who are asking for this type of clothing because they have limited resources themselves and can't afford higher prices. This is an edge she has because she offers her customers what they need. She has many dreams and always is thinking about her business and in having a place from which to offer her products. This isn't the first loan she has requested so she made the effort to pick up the money to start repaying.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Nialing

texts.fr: Nialing B. est une femme de 38 ans, elle est mariée et mère de trois enfants. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis 8 ans, elle est très expérimentée en matière de crédit. Elle développe un petit commerce de thé, de sucre, d'huile, etc. Ce prêt lui servira à renforcer son activé et générer des ressources qui lui permettront de prendre en charge sa famille.
texts.en:
Nialing B., aged 38, is married and the mother of three children. She has been a member of a village bank for eight years and is very experienced in the credit process. She runs a small business selling tea, sugar, oil, etc. This loan will enable her to bolster her activity and generate a profit which she will use to provide for her family.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To develop her commercial activity

loans.name: Sandra Del Carmen

texts.es: Sandra del Carmen tiene 34 años, tiene la actividad económica de abarrotería. Hace más de 4 años que se dedica a este negocio, sus inicios fueron muy difíciles porque anteriormente no tenía el capital suficiente para incrementar sus productos. Los financiamientos han sido de gran ayuda pues le ayudan a mejorar su negocio. Actualmente ella necesita este financiamiento para la compra de granos básicos que son lo más importante que sus clientes le solicitan porque ella ofrece estos productos de manera favorable. a pesar de los problemas que enfrento ella siempre sueña con proporcionarle mejoras a su vivienda.
texts.en:
Sandra del Carmen is 34 and has a grocery store. She has had this business for more than 4 years. At first it was very difficult because she didn't have enough capital to increase the amount of her products. Her financing has been a great help and helps her improve her business. Currently she needs this financing to be able to buy basic grains, which are the most important because her customers are requesting them because she offers them for a good price. In spite of the problems she has faced, she always dreams about making improvements to her home.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Benita Mercedes

texts.es: La señora Benita Merceder L. posee su propia actividad de venta de comestibles como lo son hot dogs, golosinas y bebidas comercializadas en el departamento de Chinandega. Es importante destacar que ella es muy trabajadora y actualmente no cuenta con buenas condiciones para desarrollar su actividad y es por esta razón que ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar dicho crédito y de esta manera continuar mejorando sus condiciones y si es posible cumplir un sueño de llegar a tener un local propio donde vender sus comestibles.
texts.en:
Señora Benita Merceder L. has her own business selling food like hotdogs, candy, and drinks in the department of Chinandega. It's important to point out that she is very hard-working and currently doesn't have good conditions in which to run her business. For this reason, she has turned to Ceprodel to request this credit so she can continue improving her conditions. If it's possible, she would like to fulfill her dream of having her own location in which to sell her food.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food and drinks

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Fe Y Progreso 3&4 Group

texts.en:
Yngris, 32, is a borrower who lives near San Pedro D. Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Fe y Progreso (Faith and Progress), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Yngris and her husband have four children and live in a small community called Batey Las Baja with the other borrowers from the group. Bateyes are rural communities that were built by sugar companies for their workers. They are isolated and lack any kind of reliable electricity, running water, or medical facilities. Despite these difficulties, Yngris runs a successful business selling clothing to her friends and neighbors. With this loan, her eighth with Esperanza International, she will purchase new pants, blouses and shoes. 

Yngris originally came to Esperanza because she had seen others with loans and the success it gave them. She and her husband decided that they could not miss this opportunity, and now Yngris is on her way to her dream of having her own boutique. Her business came slow before, but now with extra capital her business is progressing. With your support, Yngris can achieve her dream of growing her business. Thank you for lending to Yngris and the Fe y Progreso group!

loans.use: To buy pants, blouses, and shoes

loans.name: Mario Alberto

texts.es: El señor Mario Alemán es guarda de seguridad desde hace catorce años, no ha podido encontrar un empleo donde pueda ganar mas por que con lo poco que sabe uno es mas difícil y están escasos los empleos, lo mas triste es cuando se cambia de gobierno por que se dan varios cambios y teme que lo corran lo cual el solo depende de su salario. Tiene 4a años de edad, su esposa le procreo una hija que estudia su secundaria tiene 17 años de edad, el cual espera poder ayudar aunque todo esta caro, viven en Laureles Sur. Con este financiamiento logrará comprar piedra, cemento hierro para hacer un muro para poder tener mejor seguridad contra la delincuencia que asecha día a día en nuestro país, como estar en mejores condiciones con su familia.
texts.en:
Señor Mario Alemán has been a security guard for more than 14 years. He hasn't been able to find a job where he can earn more money because with the little that one knows, it is difficult, and jobs are scarce. The saddest thing is that with the changes in government, various changes have happened, and he's afraid that he will lose his job, and he depends on his salary. He is 40, and he and his wife have one 17-year-old daughter who studies in secondary school. He hopes that he will be able to help pay for this although it's very expensive. They live in Laureles Sur. With this financing, he will be able to buy stone, cement, and iron to make a wall so they will have better security against the delinquency that threatens the country day after day and so their family can have better living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stone, cement, sand, and iron to make a wall

loans.name: Eulogio Ramiro

texts.es:
En el departamento de Chinandaga, el seño Eulogio H. se dedica a atender su propia pulpería donde ofrece todo tipo de productos desde comestibles tales como pan, galletas, tortas y también bebidas como gaseosas y jugos. También el señor Eulogio vende productos como papel higiénico, jabones y ase todos estos comercializados en su establecimiento.
Solicita un crédito para invertirlo en la compra de dichos productos para comercializarlos en su pulpería y así generar ingresos para el mantenimiento de su hogar que tanto requiere de su apoyo.
texts.en:
In the department of Chinandega, señor Eulogio H. attends to his own general store where he offers all types of food products like bread, cookies, cakes, and also drinks like soft drinks and juices. He also sells products like toilet paper and soap in his store. He is requesting a credit to invest in the purchase of these products to sell in his general store so he can earn income to support his home that needs his support so much.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase products for his general store.

loans.name: Isaías

texts.es:
El señor Isaías M. y su esposa la Leonor Tapia están muy agradecidos por su cooperación en el crédito anterior el cual pudieron pagar la diferencia de su casa, ya están viviendo hay.
Solicita un nuevo préstamo para poder ponerle las protecciones en las puertas y ventanas 
ya que no seguridad  su patrimonio y familia y eso le esta preocupando.
Don Isaías es empleado de una compañía de trasportes en el departamento de chofer de una camión con una parte de este ingreso pagara el crédito.
texts.en:
Señor Isaías M. and his wife Leonor Tapia are very grateful for your cooperation with their previous credit, which they used to pay off their house. He is requesting a new loan to be able to put protection on the doors and windows since the security of his family and assets is worrying him. Don Isaías is an employee of a transportation company and drives a truck. He will use part of his income to pay back this credit.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To put protection on his doors and windows

loans.name: Benita Lorena

texts.es:
En el mercado El Bisne del departamento de Chinandega, la señora Benita Ríos se ha dedicado desde hace cinco años a su actividad de elaboración y venta de riquísimos alimentos que son preparados por ella y ofrecidos a sus clientes que a diario le visitan en el mercado.
Ella es una persona muy trabajadora que siempre está en busca de brindarle mejores condiciones de vida a su familia y por ende busca como mejorar las condiciones de su actividad. Por esta razón solicita el crédito para la compra de la materia prima para continuar elaborando los deliciosos alimentos en su localidad.
texts.en:
For the past 5 years, Benita Ríos has sold her delicious prepared meals to customers who visit her daily while shopping at the El Bisne market in Chinandega departmnent. She is a very hard-working woman who is always looking to offer her family better living conditions which leads her to seek ways to improve her business. She is requesting funds to buy ingredients to continue preparing her delicious meals.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her meal preparation.

loans.name: Haby

texts.fr: Haby B., 34 ans, mariée et mère de 5 enfants est membre du Banc Villageois de DIAO BA depuis 8 ans. Elle développe un petit commerce d'huile, elle en achète en grande quantité dans des fûts et revend au détail. Cette activité lui donne de ressources additionnelles qui lui permettent de participer à l'amélioration des conditions de vie familiale.
texts.en:
Haby B., aged 34, is married and the mother of five children. She has been a member of the village bank Diao Ba for eight years. She runs a small business selling oil. She buys the oil wholesale in barrels and retails it. This activity gives her additional resources which enable her to participate in the improvement of the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster her oil business

loans.name: Maria Emilia

texts.es: Maria Emilia es una señora de 57 años, su actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 13 años que se dedica a este negocio, por lo que es una mujer muy responsable y le gusta muchos su trabajo. Por lo que cuando dio inicio fue con muy pocos productos, y así poco a poco ha comenzado a establecer su pulpería en su vivienda para proporcionarles a sus vecinos que son sus clientes lo necesario. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo que será invertido en refrescos naturales, pan, galletas, golosinas o toras productos que son necesarios. El sueño de ella es mantener esta actividad económica que es lo necesario.
texts.en:
Maria Emilia, 57, has run a small general store for the past 13 years. She is very responsible and enjoys her work very much. When she first started, she had just a few products available but, little by little, she has seen her little store, which she operates from home, grow and offer her neighbors everything they need. The financing she is requesting will be used to buy natural beverages, bread, cookies, sweets and other needed products. Her dream is to keep this work going which is very necessary.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital.

loans.name: Liberia Silvia

texts.es: La señora Liberia B. es propietaria de una pulpería donde ofrece productos comestibles como pan, picos dulces, azúcar, galletas y golosinas. También vende productos como jabones, papel higiénico y ase. Ella solicita el crédito para invertirlo en la compra de dichos productos para comercializarlos en su establecimiento de la pulpería para ello espera muy confiadamente en que el crédito le será otorgado satisfactoriamente y así suplirá de productos el negocio.
texts.en:
Liberia B. owns a small general store where she offers food items like bread, picos dulces (a type of lollipop), sugar, cookies, sweets. She also carries products like soaps, toilet paper, laundry soap, etc. She requests financing to stock up on inventory items for her store. She is confident that the loan will be approved so that she can stock her store.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock inventory.

loans.name: Carlos Manuel

texts.es:
En el departamento de Chinandega, el señor Carlos C. se ha dedicado desde hace varios años a su actividad de sastrería donde elabora todo tipo de piezas de vestir y es muy visitado por los clientes que solicitan diferentes hechuras de vestir.

El señor Carlos C. es la persona que lleva el sustento a su hogar por lo que requiere mejorar las condiciones de su actividad para continuar llevando el sustento. 
Actualmente su máquina de trabajo está dañada por lo que requiere la compra de los repuestos para proceder a su reparación. Es por esta razón que el crédito lo solicitó para la compra de los repuestos con el fin de iniciar a lo inmediato la reparación de la máquina y así continuar en su actividad de sastrería.
texts.en:
Carlos C. has been a tailor for many years; he lives in Chinandega department. He creates all kinds of garments and is very popular with customers who come to request various clothing items. Carlos is the sole provider for his family and he would like to improve his business to continue to do so. His sewing machine is broken and he needs to buy replacement parts to fix it. This is the reason behind the request for financing; so that he can buy the parts and immediately begin to repair the machine in order to continue his tailoring.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy replacement parts for his sewing machine.

loans.name: Reyna Isabel

texts.es:
La señora Reyna Isabel C. posee su propia actividad de venta de comestibles como platanitos en bolsa, rosquillas, golosinas y bebidas como gaseosas y jugos. Ella vende a la intemperie donde está expuesta al sol y muchas veces a la lluvia por lo que se dedica arduamente a laborar en su actividad para mejorar sus condiciones.
El crédito que solicita lo utilizará para la compra de los comestibles y las bebidas para continuar comercializándolas en su local. Ella espera que el crédito le sea otorgado porque con este contribuye al mejoramiento de su nivel de vida.
texts.en:
Reyna Isabel C. sells food items like bags of fried banana chips, rosquillas (a ring-shaped cookie), sweets, beverages like soft-drinks and juices, out in the open air, exposed to the sun and often to the rain. For this reason she works very hard to improve her conditions. She requests financing to buy stock items to sell. She hopes the loan will be approved because it contributes to improving her standard of living.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food items and beverages.

loans.name: Teresa De Jesús

texts.es:
La señora Teresa H. tiene su propio tramo de ropa en el mercado Central de Chinandega donde ofrece todo tipo de ropa y en especial ropa para niños la que es comercializada a diario desde termpranas horas de la mañana.
Su negocio lo inició desde hace quince años y ella siempre se ha mantenido con una alegre sonrisa por lo que esto le ha ayudado mucho a desarrollarse en su negocio. El crédito que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de la ropa para continuar comercializándola en su tramo y así generar las utilidades para el mantenimiento de su hogar.
texts.en:
Teresa H. sells clothing in the Chinandega central market. She has all kinds of clothing but specializes in children's clothes. She tends her stall every day from very early in the morning. She began her work 15 years ago and she always has a cheerful smile to offer which has helped greatly in developing her business. The financing she requests is to buy clothing to stock her inventory so that she can continue to produce profits which support her household.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing.

loans.name: Leonila Del Socorro

texts.es: Leonila del Socorro tiene 41 años de edad, su actividad económica es una pulpería ella se levanta muy temprano, para ir al mercado en busca de las golosinas y los diferentes productos que ofrece en su pulpería, por lo que algunos distribuidores no llegan a dejarle los productos a su vivienda, pero a pesar de todos estos problemas ella sale adelante con su negocio. El financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de productos que necesita en su negocio que algunos de sus clientes solicitan. El deseo de seguir siempre con su negocio, mantener su record crediticio.
texts.en:
Leonila del Socorro is 41 years old and her business is a small grocery store. She usually wakes up very early in the morning and goes to the market to buy candies and other supplies to sell in her store. She needs to go to the market, as many wholesaler do not deliver at her place. Despite these problems, she manages to keep running her business. She is requesting a loan in order to buy more products for her store, so that she can satisfy her customers' requests. She wishes to be able to keep always working in this business and always with a positive credit balance.

Translated from Spanish by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating funds

loans.name: José Noel

texts.es:
El señor José Noel Z. se dedica a la actividad de taller de mecánica atendido en su casa de habitación en un local amplio en el departamento de Chinandega donde es visitado por varios clientes que llegan para que el señor Z. les repare su vehículo.  Es importante destacar que él también vende repuestos y aceites. 
El crédito lo está solicitando para llevar a cabo la compra de los repuestos y los aceites para utilizarlos en la reparación de los vehículos y también para ofrecerlos a sus clientes. Está esperando que el crédito sea aprobado para así mejorar sus condiciones en el negocio.
texts.en:
José Noel Z. is an auto mechanic and runs a vehicle repair shop in his yard at home. He lives in Chinandega department where many customers come to him for their vehicle repair needs. It's important to note that he also sells vehicle replacement parts and lubricants. The financing he is requesting is to buy vehicle replacement parts and lubricants which he needs for his repair work and to sell directly to customers. He hopes that the loan will be approved so that he can improve the state of his business.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy vehicle replacement parts and lubricants.

loans.name: Amigos Unidos 3, 4, & 5 Group

texts.en:
Paul, 36, is a borrower who lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. He is the coordinator for his group, Amigos Unidos (Friends United), and his story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Paul and his wife have four children, ages 1 month to 11 years. Together with the rest of the Amigos Unidos group, they live in Batey Los Gunoco. Bateyes are small rural communities built by sugar companies to house their field workers. People who live in bateyes generally have no running water, little to no electricity, and poor medical attention. Despite these difficulties, Paul has found success in his business selling clothing to friends and neighbors. With this loan, he hopes to buy more used and new clothing, including shoes, blouses, and pants.

Paul has big dreams for the future, and with your support he can get there. Paul dreams of owning his own disco one day, providing a fun place for the people in his community to spend their time. With the profits from his business through past loans, Paul has already begun building his own H. for his family. He hopes to finish the house soon with additional profits. Paul also hopes to send his children to college so they can become lawyers, doctors, architects, or anything they want to be. Paul’s dreams for himself, his business, and his family are lofty, but Esperanza believes in his vision and in the vision of the Amigos Unidos group. Thank you for lending!

loans.use: New and used clothing

loans.name: Aïssatou Assane

texts.fr: Aïssatou Assane D. est âgée de 39 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle est membre du banc Villageois de BIDIANKOTO depuis deux et demi et a eu l'expérience de 5 prêts qu'elle a bien gérés et remboursés. Elle fait de l'embouche ovine et parallèlement elle vend du mil. Elle participe à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Aïssatou Assane D., aged 39, is married and the mother of four children. She has been a member of the village bank Bidiankoto for two and a half years and received five loans which she managed well and repaid on schedule. She fattens sheep and at the same time sells millet. She participates in the improvement of the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To bolster her business

loans.name: María Argentina

texts.es:
Desde hace 26 años, en el departamento de Chinandega la señora María A. se dedica a la venta de carne, pollo asado, enchiladas, tajadas, gallo pinto, maduro frito y queso frito, así como también vende  gaseosas y refrescos todos preparados por ella misma todos los días para ofrecerlos a sus clientes.
Solicita un crédito porque necesita la compra de la materia prima para elaborar dichos alimentos en su establecimiento y para ello espera que el crédito le sea otorgado. Ella dice que se siente muy contenta porque a diario traslada su materia prima en un triciclo desde su casa hasta donde está el negocio y todos sus hijos le ayudan al traslado de los productos.
texts.en:
María A., who lives in Chinandega department, for the last 26 years has sold meat, roasted chicken, grilled meats, gallo pinto (a traditional rice and beans dish), enchiladas (tortillas wrapped around fillings and bathed in chili sauce), fried plantains, fried cheese. She also sells soft-drinks and beverages. She prepares all her dishes herself, every day, to offer to her customers. She requests financing to buy basic ingredients to prepare these meals in her establishment and she hopes the loan will be approved. She tells us that she is very happy because every day she transports her ingredients on a three-wheel cart from home to where her eatery is located and all of her children help her move the products from place to place.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients.

loans.name: Silvia Elena

texts.es:
La panadería de la señora Silvia es muy visitada por los clientes porque se ha caracterizado por elaborar todo tipo de pan como pan simple y pan dulce para ser comercializado en su establecimiento en el departamento de Chinandega. Ella es una dama muy trabajadora y tiene a su cargo unos trabajadores que le ayudan en la elaboración y horneado del pan. 
Todas las mañanas, desde muy temprano se realiza la distribución del pan en diferentes partes y por medio de ese viaje se va entregando y ofreciendo en diferentes lugares. 
Solicita el crédito para comprar la materia prima para elaborar el pan para su respectiva venta en su localidad.
texts.en:
Silvia's bakery in Chinandega department is very popular with her customers because it has been known for making all kinds of bread, both savory and sweet. She is a very hard-working lady and has under her supervision some laborers who help her make and bake the bread. Every morning, from very early, bread is distributed to various parts and during the trajectory bread is delivered and offered for sale in different places. She requests financing to buy raw materials to make the bread for subsequent sales in her location.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bread-baking ingredients.

loans.name: Virginia Del Socorro

texts.es: Virginia del Socorro tiene 28 años de edad, su actividad económica es la venta de leña que es algo muy común, por lo que el negocio de la señora, dio  inicio hace  8 años  dando apertura como la venta de tortillas   de una manera ambulante, dicha actividad hoy en día la realiza en su casa de habitación y su negocio se ha incrementado, por lo que ahora ella vende leña y granos básicos,  cuando empezó a vender fue por razón que ella como madre soltera tenía que sacar adelante a sus hijos, posteriormente ella se caso y su esposo le apoya de manera incondicional y a pesar de situación económica en que nos encontramos  le ha ido bien desde que dio inicio.   Ella solicita un financiamiento en la institución para poder trabajar y lograr tener una mejor estabilidad  económica. Su deseo son que sus esfuerzos den resultados y proporcionarle a sus hijos  una educación digna, y que no me les falte el pan de cada día.
texts.en:
Virginia del Socorro is 28, and she makes a living selling firewood, which is very common. She started her business 8 years ago by selling tortillas as a street vendor. Today she does this in her home, and her business has increased because now she sells firewood and basic grains. She started to sell because she was a single mother and had to take care of her children. Later on she got married, and her husband supports her unconditionally. In spite of the economic situation, Virginia's business has gone well for her since the beginning. She is requesting financing from the institution to be able to work and to obtain economic stability. Her wish is that her efforts give her results so she can offer her children a worthy education and so they will never lack food.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana, married with a grown daughter, lives in Nikopol and sells women’s suits and knitted wear. She owns two vending locations at different city markets. Her merchandise always sells well because of the lower price policy she has set in her kiosks. She has a loyal clientele, some whom even come from other cities to buy from her. A hard worker who usually works late hours, Tatyana has been in the trade for 10 years. Currently, her turnover capital is about 30,000 Grivnyas. Monthly net profit is usually about 5,000 Grivnyas.

Tatyana, always very committed to her family, tries to provide the best for her daughter, a college student. She is now requesting a loan of 13,000 Grivnyas to buy assorted merchandise for her vending locations to attract more customers.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Yelena

texts.en:
Yelena and her 11-year-old son, Nikita, live in Berdyansk. After Yelena resigned from her last job she couldn’t find a new job in her field for awhile. She was facing a tough financial situation at the time so she decided to take a risk and start her own small business. Currently, Yelena runs a small business selling footwear and clothing in the local market. Presently, she has 8,000 Grivnyas invested in inventory. Her monthly income is about 4,000 Grivnyas.

Yelena is a determined entrepreneur. She has been in this business for about eight years. She knows how to set goals and achieve them. Yelena recognizes that lending assistance has provided significant support for her business and has promoted its stable growth. She is requesting a loan of 10,000 Grivnyas to increase her turnover capital which will allow her to re-supply her inventory and increase her sales.

loans.use: To increase her assorted merchandise

loans.name: Diénaba

texts.fr: Diénaba BÂ est âgée de 37 ans, elle est mariée et mère de quatre enfants. Elle est propriétaire d'un restaurant qu'elle gère elle-même, son crédit lui permettra de mieux le développer et accroître ses revenus afin de pourvoir faire face aux besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
Diénaba Bâ, aged 37, is married and the mother of four children. She owns a restaurant which she runs by herself. This loan will enable her to further develop her restaurant and increase her income, which she will use to provide for her family.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen the financial situation of her business

loans.name: Lesya

texts.en:
Lesya is married with a son, Mykola. She is a small entrepreneur from the town of Khoost, Western Ukraine. Lesya runs a small business selling bicycles that are in high demand in their small town where very few people can afford to buy and own a car. Along with bicycles, she also sells different parts and accessories for them. Lesya works really hard to keep her business sustainable and running smoothly. Lesya has been operating for 2 years. Currently, she earns about 5,500 Grivnyas a month in net profit.

Lesya hopes to develop her business in the future. She is thinking about purchasing additional merchandise to facilitate her sales and business activity as a result. This time she is requesting a loan of 5,500 Grivnyas to help her offer a nicer variety of this type of merchandise.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Diénaba

texts.fr: Diénaba B. est une femme mariée elle a 41 ans et mère de 6 enfants. Elle est membre de Banc Villageois depuis deux ans et demi. Elle fait de l'embouche bovine et la vente de bétail. Grâce à cette activité elle participe à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Diénaba B., aged 41, is married and the mother of six children. She has been a member of a village bank for two and a half years. She fattens and sells cattle. Thanks to this activity she participates in the improvement of the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To strengthen her cattle business

loans.name: Union De Mujeres En Desarrollo 1-4 Group

texts.en:
Mercedes, 34, is a borrower who lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Union de Mujeres en Desarrollo (Union of Women in Development), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Mercedes and her husband have three children, ages four to fourteen, and they live in La Joya, a small town northwest of San Pedro. Mercedes has built a house of cement blocks for her family, a marked improvement over the typical wooden home. She is grateful for her loans because she knows she can pay off her home with the increased profits from her business. With this loan, her second from Esperanza International, she will be purchasing undergarments for both men and women. Mercedes will then sell them to friends, neighbors, and others in nearby towns at a small markup.

In the future, Mercedes hopes to expand her line of products to include all types of clothing for men, women, and children. She also hopes to continue improving her home to make it more comfortable for her family. Mercedes’ ultimate goal, however, is to send all of her children to college. With your support, Mercedes can continue striving towards those goals. Thank you for lending to Mercedes and the Union de Mujeres en Desarrollo group!

loans.use: To buy undergarments to sell to neighbors and friends

loans.name: Delia Albertina

texts.en:
Delia Albertina B. V. is a single mother of three living in the Paraiso district of Guayaquil. Ms. B. sells chickens and guinea pigs; she currently has around 100 chickens and 18 guinea pigs. She buys the young chickens in bulk for 57 cents and spends 6-8 weeks feeding and caring for them. When they are fully grown, Ms. B. is able to sell them for $1.25/lb.

Ms. B. is requesting a loan in order to buy chicken feed (corn) and a water distributor. The holidays are approaching and chicken sales go up for Christmas and New Years. Therefore, Ms. B. wants to be ready with an ample supply. In the future, she wishes to expand her chicken coop and improve the coop's lighting system.

loans.use: To buy chicken feed (corn) and a water distributor.

loans.name: Mariama

texts.fr: Mariama C. a 43 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle vend des fruits, du savon, du thé, du sucre, de l'huile végétale et d'autres divers produits. Elle soutien son mari dans la prise en charge de la maison à partir des bénéfices qu'elle réalise de son activité.
texts.en:
Mariama C. is a 43-year old woman who is married with 4 children. She sells fruit, soap, tea, sugar, vegetable oil and other products. With her income she helps her husband support the household's expenses.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her working capital

loans.name: El Progreso 1, 2, & 3 Group

texts.en:
Maria, 27, is a borrower who lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, El Progreso (Progress), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Maria, her husband, and their three children (ages five to twelve) live together with all of Maria’s extended family. They live in Batey Santa Lucia, a small community north of San Pedro. Bateyes are small rural communities built by sugar companies for their field workers. Bateyes are typically very hard to reach, have no potable water, and little to no electricity. Santa Lucia is a particularly small and isolated batey, but despite the difficulties, Maria makes the most out of her opportunities by selling clothing to her neighbors. Since the community is small and people need new clothing only so often, Maria will also use this loan to purchase food to cook meals for her friends and neighbors.

In sugarcane-based communities, during six months of the year there is little work to be done. This time is called “Tiempo Muerto”, or dead time. Maria says that it is during this time that she especially needs her business. Once “La Safra” (the harvest) starts, her family is not as desperate for income. She has smartly balanced her business around the growing season, taking out more money during Tiempo Muerto than during La Safra. With her smart business planning, Maria hopes to continue making profit to support her family and hopefully send her children to college. With your support she can do it, so thank you for lending!

loans.use: Rice, beans, plantains, and clothing

loans.name: Saliamata

texts.fr: Salimata D. du Banc Villageois de BIDIANKOTO est âgée de 37 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle développe un petit commerce de tissus teintés, elle s'approvisionne en marchandises au Mali, pays limitrophe au Sénégal, pour revendre au détail au marché de son quartier ou à domicile. Elle participe aux dépenses quotidiennes de la maison.
texts.en:
Salimata D., with Village Bank of BIDIANKOTO, is 37 years old. She is married, with 4 children. Salimata is developing a small business selling dyed fabrics. She purchases materials in Mali, a country bordering Senegal, and resells them either from her home or in her neighborhood market. Her income helps with her household's daily expenses.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improve her retail business

loans.name: Aïssatou Demba

texts.fr: Aïssatou Demba D., est une femme de 33 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle est membre du banc Villageois de BIDIANKOTO depuis deux ans et demi. Elle développe un petit commerce en vendant sur table divers produits tels que du riz, de l'huile, du thé, du sucre etc. Avec ses bénéfices elle participe à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille en prenant en charge la santé de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Aïssatou Demba D., a 33-year-old wife and mother of 3, has been a member of Village Bank of BIDIANKOTO for 2 1/2 years. She has a small business selling miscellaneous products from a small table, including rice, oil, tea, and sugar. With her income, she helps improve her family's circumstances by paying for her children's health care.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her ability to self-finance

loans.name: El Progreso 4 & 5 Group

texts.en:
Santa, 28, is a borrower who lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, El Progreso (Progress), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Santa and her husband live in Batey Santa Lucia with their three children, ages two, nine, and ten. A batey is a small rural community built by a sugar company to house their field workers. Bateyes are usually isolated with little or no access to electricity, potable running water, or medical services. Santa Lucia is particularly remote, and the community is quite small. Despite those difficulties, Santa has a successful business selling clothing to her community. With this loan, her second with Esperanza International, Santa plans on purchasing more merchandise and styles of clothing to sell to her customers.

Santa’s dream is to eventually be able to sell clothing in other communities. Before she had access to loans, this dream could never come true. Now, it is almost within reach as her business grows and she increases her profits. She will soon be able to pay for rides to other towns to expand her customer base. Santa’s dream for her family is that her children will all be able to go to college, an opportunity she never had. Thank you for lending to Santa and the El Progreso group!

loans.use: New and used clothing

loans.name: Petrona De Los Angeles

texts.en: Petrona has two parts to her business: from a small loan that she received, Petrona opened a small general store in her home; she also began selling clothing. Small general stores are called “Pulperias” in Nicaragua and are very common. One street may have three or four within a couple blocks. Because they are characteristically located in homes, the stores are dotted throughout neighborhoods and provide convenient access to daily use items. Though there is a good customer base, there is a lot of competition for these stores. Petrona reports that there is much demand for the products that her store offers as well as the clothing items she sells. The challenge facing her business is working with a small amount of capital. Petrona’s dream is to continue to grow her business so that she can increase her income.

loans.use: To increase stock.

loans.name: Mburukuja Group

texts.en:
The Mburukuja committee is obtaining its first loan. The women in the committee work very hard and use their loans for their individual businesses.

They will be using their loans to invest in their businesses: buying fabric for dressmaking; ingredients for pastries and baked goods; vegetables and fruits; staple goods; cosmetics such as lipsticks, creams, shampoos, deodorants, colognes, etc.; fabric for clothing and clothing repairs; bedsheets and towels; shorts, lingerie and underwear.

The women in this committee are dedicated to improving their lives and the lives of their children and providing them with greater opportunities for the future.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for their businesses

loans.name: Dieynaba Kémo

texts.fr: Dieynaba Kémo S. est une femme de 33 ans, elle est mariée et mère de quatre enfants. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de BIDIANKOTO depuis deux. Elle fait de l'embouche bovine, avec ce prêt elle va acheter des bœufs de l'aliment bétail pour les engraisser et des produits vétos. Cette activité lui permet d'avoir des ressources pour prendre partiellement en charge sa famille.
texts.en:
Dieynaba Kémo S. is a 33-year-old woman who is married with 4 children. She has been a member of Village Bank of BIDIANKOTO for two years. She fattens cattle for market. With this loan, she will purchase cattle, feed, and veterinary supplies. Her business provides income that allows her to contribute to her family's financial needs.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase her herd

loans.name: Unidos Por Siempre Group

texts.es:
Doña Marilyn, tiene actualmente 44 años de edad, tiene un hijo y vive en la casa de sus abuelos, el mismo que se encuentra ubicado en la zona Alto San Pedro. Doña Marilyn tiene como actividad la venta de electrodomésticos, productos electrónicos al crédito y prestamos de dinero. El crédito solicitado es para comprar productos por temporada de navidad, ya que tiene muchos pedidos.
Doña Wlilma, tiene actualmente 60 años de edad, no tiene hijos que dependan económicamente de ella, vive en la casa de sus papas, que llega a ser la misma casa en la que vive dona Marilyn. Su actividad principal es tambien la venta de electrodomésticos, productos electrónicos al crédito y prestamos de dinero. El crédito solicitado es para comprar productos por temporada de navidad, doña Wilma tiene mayor experiencia en dicha actividad que doña Marilyn.
texts.en:
Marilyn is currently 44 years-old and has one son. She lives in the house of her grandparents, located in the Alto San Pedro area. Marilyn works selling electric appliances, also offering credit or a loan to customers. The loan she is asking for will be used to purchase products to sell during the Christmas season, as there is a lot of demand. Wilma is currently 60 years-old and has no children who depend on her economically. She lives in the home of her parents, that now has become her home. Her principal economic activity is also the sale of electrical appliances, through credit and loans. This loan will be used to purchase products for the Christmas season. Wilma has more experience in this business than Marilyn.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Credo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of electrical appliances and other electric products to sell during the Christmas season.

loans.name: Rosa Elsy

texts.en:
Rosa is 35 years old, she is married and has a four year old.

Rosa sells books and she is also a high school teacher. She began her business two years ago in the hopes of putting together some savings. She goes to the city of Chinandega to buy the books and then sells them. The majority of her customers are high school students. She has a good customer base and there is much demand for her products.

Rosa reports that the loans she has received have greatly helped her and her family. The challenge facing her business is working with a small amount of capital. Rosa’s dream is to continue to grow her business so that she can increase her income.

loans.use: To use as working capital

loans.name: Kadia Demba

texts.fr: Kadia demba D. est une femme de 35 ans, elle est mariée et mère de trois enfants. elle est membre du banc Villageois de BIDIANKOTO depuis deux ans et demi. Elle fait de l'embouche Bovine. Avec ce prêt elle va acheter des bœufs et de l'aliment de bétail pour les engraisser et des produits vétos pour assurer la prophylaxie médicale. Elle améliore les conditions de vie de sa famille à partir des revenus qu'elle réalise.
texts.en:
Kadia Demba D. is a 35-year-old woman who is married and the mother of three. She has been a member of Village Bank of BIDIANKOTO for 2 1/2 years. She fattens cattle for market. With this loan, she will purchase cattle, feed, and veterinary supplies. Her income helps improve her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Promote her cattle business

loans.name: Oñondivepa Group

texts.en:
The committee "Oñondivepa" has been working with Fundacion Paraguaya for almost a year. The entrepreneurial women who are part of the group, use their loans for their individual businesses, which include: purchasing ingredients for cooking food, baked goods and pastries; purchasing milk and sugar, flour and salt, for their pantries; fruits and vegetables, such as melon, watermelon, bananas, and oranges; buying and selling second-hard clothes and shoes.

They all do this with the goal of improving their lives and that of their families.

loans.use: To buy more merchandise for their businesses

loans.name: Mujeres Talentosas Group

texts.en: The Mujeres Talentosas committee is in its 10th loan cycle. The women in this group are incredibly hardworking. For example, Lourdes Peralta, who is 36 years old, has a young child who stays with her neighbor during the weekends so Lourdes can work. Lourdes sews baby clothes and sells them around her neighborhood. Her dream is to own her own home. She works very hard. She is the only breadwinner in her family. She lives in a small house in very poor conditions. The Fundacíon would like to renovate her house so that she can have a higher quality of living. Lourdes is part of this committee so that she can improve her life through her business.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Edgar Antonio

texts.en:
Señor Edgard Antonio has a long credit history with Fundación León 2000 and this will be his third Kiva loan. This loan will again support his business of selling watches and wallets. 

For nearly 14 years Señor Edgard has operated this business and his goal is to continue to maintain it so that he can build a savings account for his retirement. So far the business is going well; Edgard reports that he doesn’t have problems with his health and the business itself is without problems. 

Every week he makes the two hour trip to Managua to purchase new merchandise for his inventory.

Edgard is 53 years old, he is married and has two adult children. Both of his children have formed their own families.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Grupo De Mujeres La Palmeras Group

texts.es: El grupo de mujeres las Las palmeras son originaria de la  comunidad de chimente del municipio de Totonicapán ellas viene trabajando hace mas de diez años en la crianza y venta de pollos pero cada año necesita de mas capital  porque el negocio prospera actualmente tiene tres granjas de pollos aproximadamente cinco mil quinientos pollos hoy necesitan compras tres mil quinientos nuevos pollos  y como la alimentación, y aprovechar la época de verano y como de navidad en poder vender algunos pollos, con este negocio han podido sostener las necesidades de las familias,
texts.en:
The women’s group “los pollitos” (little chickens) are originally from the community of Chimente in the town of Totonicapan. They have been working for more than ten years raising chickens to sell, and each year they need more capital since the business has been prospering. Currently they have three chicken farms with approximately five thousand five hundred chickens. Now they need to buy three thousand five hundred new chickens and their food, to take advantage of the summer season. Also with Christmas coming, they would like to sell some chickens. They have been able to provide for their families’ needs with this business.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To get more capital

loans.name: Karla Vanessa

texts.en:
Karla began selling plastic bags 10 years ago when she worked in the market. Her mother also sold bags and although Karla started on her own, her mother has been supportive. Nearly everything that is sold comes in plastic bags. In the markets these bags are used as the only packaging material and are often reused in a business and around the house. Karla dreams of having a more established location for her business; for the moment she sells her bags on foot, walking from vendor to vendor.

Karla has a long relationship with Fundación León 2000 and has been able to manage six loans for both her business and personal use. Karla will use this loan for the purchase of more plastic bags of various sizes.

Karla is 28 years old, is married, and has three children, ages 11, 7, 3. The youngest isn’t in school yet, but the older children are in 5th and 2nd grade, respectively.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Maria Danelia

texts.en:
For five years Maria Daniela has maintained her business selling firewood. The business began as a way for Maria to contribute to the household income. Maria decided to sell wood because she came to an agreement with the people who sell tortillas that they would buy their wood from her. Many stoves are fueled by firewood.; food stands that make their food on site especially need the portability of a firewood-fueled stove.

Maria Daniela reports that late payments from clients are her greatest challenge. She has a strong credit history with Fundación León 2000 and because of her loans has been able to purchase a cart to collect and transport the firewood.

This loan will go towards the purchase of more firewood, and Maria will also purchase a few pigs. Investing in pigs is a good investment as there is a steady demand for pork. Pork is a large part of the Nicaraguan diet and the sale of the meat will greatly add to Maria’s income.

Maria Daniela is married and has two children under the age of 15. Her goal is to rebuild the walls of her house out of bricks. The walls are currently made of wood and do not hold up well to the elements.

loans.use: To buy more firewood and some pigs

loans.name: Maribel Andrea

texts.es: La señorita Maribel Andre es originaria de la comunidad de Chimente del municipio de Totonicapan donde hace cinco años inicio su propio negocio en la confeecion de playeras, gorras, sus principales punto de ventas son los departamento de Totonicapàn, Chimaltenango y Santa Cruz del Quiche hoy necesita de un credito para la compra de materiales, como tela, forro, cono, y otros para aprovechar las fiesta de fin de año y como el inicio del ciclo escolar dos mil diez para los uniformes de los niños y niñas, y con los ingreso poder mejor el nivel de vida de su familia
texts.en:
Maribel Andre is originally from the community of Chimente in the municipality of Totonicapan. Five years ago she started her own business making shirts and hats which she sells in Totonicapán, Chimaltenango, and Santa Cruz del Quiche. Now she is asking for a loan in order to buy materials like cloth, lining, and cones to be able to make items for new years eve parties and school uniforms the start of the school year in early 2010. With her earnings she will be able to improve her family's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Cathy Coffman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying materials

loans.name: Edda Del Socorro

texts.en:
For 11 years Senora Edda has had her used clothing business. Edda lives in a small rural community where there are few places to buy clothing, new or used. This means that she has little competition and a good customer base. Edda has an excellent credit history with Fundación León 2000, she has managed 16 loans with the Fundación, though this is her first Kiva loan.

Senora Edda is 59 years old, married, and has two adult children. She dreams of adding a small bookstore to her business. Senora Edda reports that her business is challenged when sales are slow.

loans.use: To buy more used clothing

loans.name: Dominga Salome

texts.es: Doña Salo es originari de la comunidad de Chimente del municipio de Totonicapn  que se encuentra situado a 42 kilometros del municipio de Totonican a veinte kilometros del municipio de Chichicastenango Santa Cruz del Quiche doña Salome necesita un credito para la remodelacion de su vivienda, para aprovechar la época de verando para no tener consecuencias en la época de invierno su activida principal es ser amda de casa con los ingreso que obtiene los fines de semana ha podido darle educacion a sus tres hijos y alimentacion ell necesita de una vivienda digna para su familia por eso necesita de la ayuda de Asdir en un credito.
texts.en:
Mrs. Salo is from the town of Chimente in the municipality of Totonicapán which is 42 kilometers from the city of Totonicapan and twenty kilometers from the city of Chichicastenango, Santa Cruz del Quiche. Mrs. Salome needs a loan to remodel her house. She wants to take advantage of the summer season so as not to have consequences in the winter season. Her main job is as housewife. She has been able to educate and feed her three children with the income she gets on weekends. She needs a decent house for her family. That is why she needs help from Asdir for a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Haynes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase materials

loans.name: Bendicion De Mujeres Trabajadoras Group

texts.en:
Luz lives in San Pedro de Macoris, in the Dominican Republic. She is the group coordinator of “Bendicion de mujeres trabajadoras”, and her story is representative of the other group members.
Luz makes a living selling clothes on the street. She spends several hours daily walking along the streets and offering her merchandise. She has also started to sell snacks made of rice and oil. Diversifying one’s business, as small as it may be, is a means of improvement and allows borrowers to make their incomes steadier.
Luz took her first two loans with Esperanza last year, after her cousin, who is also a member of Esperanza, told her about the microfinance institution. That was the very first time she was given a loan, and she was able to repay it successfully. With this new loan, she is planning to go to the capital city (Santo Domingo) to buy her merchandise. 
She is the mother of four children, ages 7 to 15, all attending school. Her dream is to be able to finish building her house, and to keep expanding her business.
Thanks for your support.

loans.use: To go to Santo Domingo to buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Fatima Del Carmen

texts.en:
Fatima owns three bicycle taxis for the transport of people in the city of Chinandega (some bicycle taxis are used to transport cargo.) A very enterprising woman, Fatima works in the hospital and also sells clothing and cosmetics to her coworkers. Through her clothing business, Fatima serves as a sort of personal shopper for her coworkers. This loan will go towards the maintenance costs of the bicycle taxis as well as the purchase of clothing and cosmetics merchandise.

Fatima is married and has three children, ages 18, 17 and 8, all of whom are currently in school. Fatima reports that the loans that she has received have improved her living conditions and her business. Fatima would like to open a bookstore in the center of the city.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Maria Esperanza

texts.en:
Maria is 36 years old and married. She has two children; they are ages 17 and 14 and both attend school.

Maria’s business began in 1998 when she took over the small general store that her mother was running. Small general stores are called “pulperias” here in Nicaragua and are very common. One street may have three or four within a couple of blocks. Because they are characteristically located in homes, the stores are dotted throughout neighborhoods and provide convenient access to daily use items. Though there is a good customer base, there is a lot of competition for these stores.

Maria says that her business has grown little by little and because of it, she has been able to improve her house and generally improved her quality of life. Maria dreams of having a large store that she can pass on to her children so that they will have a way to support themselves.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Candelaria

texts.es: la Señorita Candelaria es originaria de la comunidad de chimente su fuente de ingreso  es la confeccion de playeras, camisas pantalones, mochilas dicho trabajo se lo heredo su querido padre hace cuatro años conjuntamente con sus dos hermanas como se ven en la fotografia, deciden hacelo mas grande el negocio y ellas mismas vender el producto  en el mercado de Chimaltenango y San francisco el Alto Totonicapan, visita las oficina de ASDIR para solicitar un credito que lo invetiran en la compra de forro, ciperes, conos,telas, botones. Con ello surtir su mercaderia y poder satisfacer la necesidad de sus clientes
texts.en:
Candelaria comes from the community of Chimente. Her source of income comes from making t-shirts, tops, pants and backpacks. She inherited this job four years ago from her beloved father along with her two sisters, who you can see in the photo. Together they decided to expand the business and sell the products themselves in the markets of Chimaltenango and San Francisco el Alto Totonicapan. They visited the office of ASDIR to apply for a loan which they will use to purchase lining, zippers, thimbles, fabric and buttons. With these items they will re-stock their merchandise so they can satisfy their customer's needs.

Translated from Spanish by Suzanne Grasso, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase working capital

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.es:
La señora  FELICIANA E. D. V., tiene  56 años, vive en el distrito Huanchaco D. la provincia D. Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal  FUENTE D. VIDA. Ella presenta estudios hasta 1ERO  D. primaria, refiere que ella quedo huérfana a la edad D. 7 años por lo cual empezó a trabajar desD. niña para poder ayudar a sus hermanos pequeños, tiene 3 hijos todos mayores quienes la apoyan eventualmente. La socia se dedica  a la venta D. cerveza en su domicilio Y con sus primer crédito D. 300.00 nuevos soles compro cajas D. cerveza al por mayor  y con su próximo crédito D. 3,000 nuevos soles comprará cajas D. cerveza al por mayor y también fertilizantes para arar sus chacras que tiene en la sierra para poder sembrar papas.
Feliciana sueña con tener una buena cosecha D. papas.
texts.en:
Mrs. FELICIANA E. D. V., is 56 years old, and lives in the Huanchaco District of the Province of Trujillo, La Libertad State – Perú. She's a member of the Communal Bank FUENTE D. VIDA (Fountain of Life). She attended school up to the first year of grammar school. She was orphaned at the age of 7, and from that time on she has worked, since childood to help her younger brothers and sisters. She has three grown children who will help her eventually. She sells beer in her home. With her first loan of 300.00 nuevos soles she will buy a case of beer wholesale and with the next loan of 3,000 soles she will buy cases of beer wholesale, and also buy fertilizer to plough her farm on the mountain where she plans to plant potatoes. Feliciana dreams of having a good crop of potatoes.

Translated from Spanish by Jo Longnecker, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wholesale beer and fertilizer

loans.name: Damaris Raquel

texts.en:
Damaris began her store eleven years ago when she needed to find a way to support her children. She is 34 years old and is a single mother with two young children. She had a small general store in front of her house, but now focuses her business on the sale of clothing and jewelry.

This loan will go towards the purchase of more merchandise, since Damaris wants to have a good inventory for the Christmas season. Damaris dreams of establishing a store in the market in Jinotepe so she would not have to continue selling her products on foot, but ultimately the most important aspect of her business is to continue to support her children.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Sonata En Invierno Group

texts.es:
SONATA EN INVIERNO

En esta alcancía comunal participan diez mujeres trabajadoras, empeñosas, ellas tuvieron el ingenio D. buscar la manera D. trabajar como microempresarias, empleando sus habilidades en las tareas que mejor sabían desenvolverse, estos se dedican a confeccionar prendas D. vestir, tejidos en lana e hilo, cosmetología, venta D. comida ambulatoria, venta D. zapatos. Es así que en esta oportunidad Jhovana A. y Rosenda S. nos cuenta sus experiencias:

Jhovana, tengo 40 años y soy madre D. dos niños D. catorce y dos años. Tuve que trabajar por necesidad debido que los ingresos D. mi esposo eran eventuales por no contar con un trabajo estable. Utilicé mi habilidad D. costura (confección y bordado) en hacer prendas para niños: polos, casacas y pantalones con la máquina D. coser que me regaló mi esposo cuando aún éramos enamorados. Al inicio no veía ganancias, pero eso no me impidió en continuar haciendo los trabajos que mejor sabía hacer; un día el ruido D. mi máquina despertó la curiosidad D. mis vecinos para que les hiciera arreglos D. compostura, confecciones, lo que me ayudó mucho porque con el tiempo me hice conocida, llegando incluso en confeccionar uniformes para los niños D. un inicial en la cual desempeñaba la labor D. auxiliar, también hice camisas para otro colegio, vendía zapatos. Era indispensable adquirir una máquina semi industrial para cumplir los pedidos D. mis clientes, ello me llevó a solicitar un préstamo a EDAPROSPO – PROSPERIDAD lo que me ayudó mucho porque compré lo que necesitaba además los siguientes créditos invertí en materiales D. bordado, telas, greca, esponja delgada, hilos dorados, hilos D. todos los colores para la confección D. trajes típicos D. la sierra peruana. El esfuerzo y perseverancia hizo posible comprar carrito sandwichero, todas las noches salía a vender afuera D. mi casa hamburguesas, pollo brouster, he dejado D. hacerlo por un tiempo hasta que mi hijito D. dos años crezca un poco más. Las ganancias D. estas ventas son D. gran apoyo en mi familia porque solvento los gastos D. alimentación, pagar el colegio particular a mi mayor hija y en los momentos en que mi esposo no tiene trabajo. He podido además construir mi casita D. esteras a material noble a fin D. darles comodidad a mis hijos que lo necesitan. El préstamo que requiero es para comprar los pedidos D. mis clientes esta vez zapatos, botines, zapatillas y seguir trabajando muy duro con el propósito D. darle lo mejor a los miembros D. mi hogar.


Rosenda, tengo 40 años D. edad, casada, madre D. dos hijos (20, 15 años). Me decidí a trabajar en tejidos a fin D. apoyar a mi esposo que actualmente está en el extranjero en los gastos que comprenD. una familia. Empecé a dictar clases D. tejidos a crochet y palitos,  macramé en un stand que alquilé, aprovechaba en vender los materiales para la confección D. chompas, ponchos u otros, así mismo en mi tiempo libre estuve ofreciendo zapatos a mis conocidos y amistades, más D. un año atrás tuve que dejarlo porque los ingresos no resultaban rentables; actualmente estoy trabajando con un pequeño grupo D. mujeres que se dedican a tejer, la persona para quien trabajamos se encarga D. exportar nuestros productos. 
Los préstamos que he recibido lo invertí en comprar los materiales para la confección D. chompas a hilo y lana, gorros, chalinas, zapatos tejidos, vestidos D. algodón. Los ingresos que obtengo son para costear la carrera D. repostería a mi hija mayor cubriéndole sus materiales y pasajes, además D. los gastos básicos del hogar. Mi meta es comprar una máquina tejedora, porque pienso más adelante acondicionar un espacio D. mi casa en hacer un taller, lo que me permitirá a futuro incrementar mis ingresos. Necesito del capital para tarrajear la pared que instalaré mi taller dándole un ambiente apropiado.
texts.en:
In this Alcancia communal bank are 10 hardworking women. They had the bright idea of setting up micro enterprises, putting their best skills forward in the tasks that they knew the best. They work making clothing knit out of wool and cotton thread, cosmetology, selling food in the streets, and selling shoes. In these businesses Jhovana Asensio and Rosenda S. will tell us their experiences. I’m Jhovana. I’m 40 years old and have 2 children, one 14 and the other 2. I had to work because my husband’s work was sporadic so we couldn’t count on a regular income. I used my skill as a seamstress (dressmaking and embroidery) to make children’s clothing: polo shirts, jackets, and pants on a sewing machine that my husband had given me when we were going together. In the beginning I wasn’t making any money but this didn’t stop me from continuing with what I knew how to do best. One day the noise from the sewing machine prompted the curiosity of my neighbors and they started bringing me clothing to alter and to make. This helped me a lot and I became known and then started making school uniforms for their children. This started a siD. business and I began to make uniforms for another school and I also sold shoes. With this work I needed a semi-industrial sewing machine to fill my orders and that brought me to EDAPROSPO-PROSPERIDAD to ask for a loan. That helped me greatly because I could buy what I needed and subsequent loans helped me invest in materials for embroidery, fabric, patterns, sponge rubber, gold thread and all colors of thread that are used in typical clothing of the Peruvian mountains. All the hard work and perseverance enabled me to buy a sandwich cart. Every night I would go outsiD. my house and sell food such as hamburgers, roasted chickens.
